name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Statements by the European Council and the Commission on the inauguration of the new President of the United States and the current political situation (2021/2502(RSP)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  Remote intervention is also planned from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Charles Michel
text: président du Conseil européen. – Monsieur le Président du Parlement européen, Madame la Présidente de la Commission, Monsieur le Haut-représentant, chers membres du Parlement européen, In front of the White House in the four corners of Lafayette Square stand statues of European heroes of the US Revolutionary War: French Generals Lafayette and Rochambeau, Polish General Kościuszko, and German General von Steuben. They and many other Europeans spared no effort and spilled their blood to help build freedom and democracy in America, and hundreds of thousands of Americans spilled their blood twice last century to protect freedom and democracy in Europe. Ever since, the United States has been our closest ally in defending democracy and rule of law. American democracy has stood strong and often served as an example for advocates of freedom around the world, and this is why the events at the US Capitol shocked us so much. But the darkness of violence will never dim the light of democracy. Law, order and democracy have prevailed over this disgraceful attempt to overturn the election. American democracy has proven its strength and resilience, and today Joe Biden takes the oath of office as the 46th President of the United States. This will be, I hope, a day of peaceful transition and a great day for American democracy, like it has been for over two centuries. Dear Members of the Parliament, today is more than a transition. Today is an opportunity to rejuvenate our transatlantic relationship, which has greatly suffered in the last four years. In these years, the world has grown more complex, less stable and less predictable. This requires, more than ever before, that we Europeans take our fate firmly into our own hands to defend our interests and promote our values. A Europe that plays a stabilising and constructive role on the global scene in line with our true weight in the world; a stronger Europe to contribute to a better, fairer and greener world; a stronger Europe in defence and in preserving peace and security. And to do this, we need strong and reliable partners, and this is why the European Council reaffirms the strategic importance of our partnership with the United States as the world’s foremost and closest relationship. We share values, common interests, cultural and historical ties, and a geopolitical reality. Together we must stand as the bedrock of the rules-based international order working for peace, security, prosperity, freedom, human rights and gender equality – values harshly challenged in the world. Dear Members of the Parliament, on the first day of his mandate, I address a solemn proposal to the new US President: let’s build a new founding pact for a stronger Europe, for a stronger America, and for a better world. Je voudrais adresser de manière solennelle aujourd’hui, en ce jour d’entrée en fonction de Joe Biden, un appel à construire ensemble un pacte fondateur nouveau pour une Europe plus forte, pour des États-Unis plus forts et pour un monde meilleur. Dear colleagues, we should work on five priorities: first, boosting multilateral cooperation; second, combating COVID-19; third, tackling climate change; fourth, rebuilding our economies, ensuring fair trade and promoting the digital transformation; and fifth, joining forces on security and peace. This won’t be easy, but together we are up to the challenge.  The EU and US, we have our differences, and these will not magically disappear. America seems to have changed, and how it is perceived in Europe and the rest of the world has also changed. Likewise, the way the United States views the European Union may also have to change. The EU chooses its course and does not wait for permission to take its own decisions. Still, what unites us is so much greater than what divides us, and the events of 6 January have revealed that we share one particular challenge in common: protecting democracy and the rule of law. 6 January was a lesson to us all – a wake-up call – that even in our well—established democracies we too often take democracy and the rule of law for granted. Protecting democracy requires constant vigilance and constant work to foster cohesion in our societies. This is true in America, and it is true right here in Europe. Mesdames et Messieurs, chers collègues, ce nouvel agenda pour l’Europe et pour les États-Unis que nous souhaitons mettre sur la table est un agenda ambitieux et c’est pourquoi, en ce premier jour de son mandat, je souhaite inviter le président Biden en Europe pour participer à une réunion extraordinaire du Conseil européen à Bruxelles, réunion qui pourrait se tenir en parallèle à un sommet de l’OTAN. Vous le voyez, nous sommes prêts, nous voulons être rassemblés, nous voulons être mobilisés pour travailler ensemble avec les États-Unis, pour construire un pacte nouveau fondateur pour une Europe forte, pour des États-Unis forts et pour un monde meilleur.

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: President of the Commission. – Mr President, in all beginnings there dwells a magic force.   There is a magic in every beginning. I cannot help but think of this famous line of the poet, Hermann Hesse, when looking forward to the inauguration of Joe Biden in a few hours from now.  Joe Biden's oath will be a message of healing for a deeply divided nation, and it will be a message of hope for a world that is waiting for the US to be back in the circle of like—minded states. This time-honoured ceremony, on the steps of the US Capitol, will be a demonstration of the resilience of American democracy and the resounding proof that, once again, after four long years, Europe has a friend in the White House, and he will be standing next to Kamala Harris, the first woman to be Vice-President of the United States. This is a historic achievement and this also makes this day very special.  This new dawn in America is the moment we've been waiting for so long. Europe is ready for a new start with our oldest and most trusted partner, and this is why the Commission has recently adopted a new forward—looking transatlantic agenda. It focuses on where we can, together, join forces to push for global change, based on our common values, interests and global influence. From climate change to health, from digitalisation to democracy, these are global challenges that need renewed and improved global cooperation. The European Union and the United States must lead from the front and bring an alliance of like—minded partners with us.  There is of course no greater need for global cooperation in the short term than in tackling the pandemic, which has been so devastating on both sides of the Atlantic. As you know, the European Union has been leading the global response since day one, and it was so encouraging that so many US organizations and foundations have helped build and design the COVAX Facility, our global alliance to bring vaccine to the low and middle-income countries. Now I am looking forward to the US government joining our common effort. This will be a strong message. Beyond this, we will propose to the United States to step up our work on health prevention, preparedness and response at the G20 Health Summit in Rome in May.  I'm delighted that, on day one as they, the new American administration, announced, the United States will rejoin the Paris Agreement. This will be a very strong starting point for our renewed cooperation, and of course way more is to come. We want to deepen our partnership on emission trading and carbon pricing, we want to join forces with the United States to fight the loss of biodiversity and the destruction of nature. We want to develop the technologies that will drive us to climate neutrality. It is with this new green tech alliance that we will look forward at everything from offshore to climate change, from hydrogen that is clean to sustainable batteries and to circular economies that we have to build up to fight this climate change. We will be ready to engage from day one on.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. The relief many of us feel about the change of office in Washington should not obscure one thing: President Trump may be history in a few hours, but his supporters will remain. More than 70 million Americans voted for Trump in the election. Just a few days ago, a few hundred of them stormed the Capitol in Washington, the heart of American democracy. These television pictures were a shock to all of us. This is what it looks like when words become deeds. This is what it looks like if the rapid digital spread of hate messages and fake news is becoming a threat to democracy. We should see these images from the United States as a reminder, despite all the primal confidence in our European democracy. We, as Europeans, are not immune from such developments. On the contrary. They have been around for a long time. Last August, a few hundred right-wing extremists wanted to storm the Berlin Reichstag. It was only thanks to the courage and prudence of a handful of police officers that they did not succeed. And we remember Jo Cox. The British Labour MP was murdered by a far-right perpetrator in June 2016, in the heated days leading up to the Brexit referendum – an act that still stifies today. Of course, there are differences to the storm on Capitol Hill. But there are also people here who feel disadvantaged, who are angry, people who adhere to rampant conspiracy theories, an often confusing melange of completely abstruse brains. And, of course, there is also social media here, which spread this hatred and contempt for our democracy millions of times unfiltered. Ladies and gentlemen, of course we must respond to the concerns and needs of each and every one of our citizens. Your fears, for example, fully justified – to be economically dependent in the pandemic. We will do this, for example with the multi-billion dollar NextGenerationEU investment and reconstruction programme. In the end, however, we may not be able to convince everyone that there are no dark powers at work in our democracies. But there is one thing we, as politicians, can and must do: we must ensure that these hate messages and misinformation can no longer spread unchecked. We must democratically enshrine the unbridled and uncontrolled power – that is a political power – of the large Internet corporations. For in a world where polarizing opinions have the greatest chance of being heard, the path from offside conspiracy theories to dead police officers is not far away. Unfortunately, the storm on the Capitol has shown that, too. Let me first make one thing clear, so that we do not get a false tongue-in-side into our debate: we in Europe value innovation. We are enthusiastic about the possibilities of state-of-the-art technology. We are open to new things, because without the new, without innovation, without the advances in technology, there is no tomorrow, we will not be able to keep what is important to us. But new technologies must never lead to others determining how we live, and that is what this is all about. As you know, the Commission launched the Digital Services Act and the Digital Markets Act in December. Roughly simplified, we want to achieve that in future online is banned, which is also prohibited in the analogue world. We want the platforms to create transparency about how their algorithms work. For it is not acceptable for decisions that have far-reaching effects on our democracy to be taken by arithmetic programmes that no human being controls. And we want clear guidelines that Internet companies take responsibility for the content they distribute. Because that, too, is important to me. As true as it may have been, Twitter shut down Donald Trump's account five minutes after 12 – such serious interference with freedom of expression should be done on the basis of laws, not the rules of the game of corporations, based on the decision of parliaments, politicians, not Silicon Valley executives. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Especially in the field of digital, we have a lot to offer in Europe to the new government in Washington. Our European path can set an example for international policy-making – just as our General Data Protection Regulation has been for a long time. As a first step, I can imagine, for example, a joint Trade and Technology Council. Together, we can create a global rule book for the digital economy – from data protection and privacy to the security of critical infrastructure. A set of rules based on our values: human rights and pluralism, inclusion and the protection of privacy. Honourable Members, this day brings good news. The United States are back, and Europe stands ready to reconnect with an old and trusted partner to breathe new life into our cherished alliance. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, yes, today is a day of great expectations: of a better future, of hope, of a new chapter in the transatlantic relationships, when the inauguration of Joe Biden as President and Vice—President Harris will take place. Four years of splitting societies, of fake news, even of the escalation of violence against the institutions who represent our democracy, are now behind us. The first message, while still having the pictures of the Congress and the Senate in America in mind; the unbelievable pictures from the office of Nancy Pelosi or the plenary of the Senate. The main message for me, is first of all, that as a Member of a Parliament, the European Parliament, as elected Members of a Parliament, we are close to our colleagues in Washington. We are together defending the institutions, the Parliament, as a heart of democracy – we will always fight for it. I think it would be arrogant in these times to try to give our American friends any kind of lesson. We are facing similar – even the same – challenges. The first was already expressed by our Commission President: social media, the digital world. I think the new way of communication has made these things possible. It is a fact that compromise is boring in a social media feed and an extreme position of provocation is attractive, it is re-tweeted. That is a reality, and this has a lot of impact in our daily life, as politicians in our political life. The big tech giants need clear rules, and the business of the big tech giants must be to serve societies and not destroy our European way of life. A second consideration for me is that more than 70 million people still voted for Donald Trump. Around half of American society. That is the real challenge: how to win them back to serious centre—based politics. I think it would be wrong to attack them as populistic voters. I think we have to take their concerns seriously.  To ask for a strict control of the border is not radical, to ask for regulation of the globalisation, with regard to China, is not radical and to defend American jobs is also not radical. We have to take their concerns seriously. The third point I want to mention is – yes – we will have a restart of the transatlantic relationship with Joe Biden in office, and President Michel if you will allow, I think it would be great to have Joe Biden in a Council meeting; but the better option for having Joe Biden in Europe to present his ideas for the future of the transatlantic relationship would be to have him make a speech in the European Parliament, probably in Strasbourg, because he’s aware of Europe’s history. That could be a really great place to restart. But, this restart also means for us as Europeans to be prepared, and there I have some thoughts, for example, on security, about NATO cooperation. Are we really ready to build up our European defence pillar; are we really ready to give in and to invest more?  On trade, I still have the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) discussions in mind. We have to learn from the mistakes we made about transparency, for example, on the TTIP debate eight years ago. In the TTIP debate, there were a lot of anti—European arguments on the table as well. Are we really prepared for a restart? That is what we have to reflect upon. The last point I want to mention is, having the developments in America in mind, we together have to define a clear red line as to what extremism is all about and to fight against violence in politics. We did it in the European Parliament last year with the rule of law mechanism to establish a binding mechanism where we defend the values of the European way of life and defend our institutions. The European Union is about being united in diversity, that is our main message and the same message could also be for our American transatlantic relationship: ‘united in diversity’. Let’s defend our common values and our institutions.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr. President, America's democracy lived one of the darkest chapters in its history on January 6. The assault on the Capitol is the appalling result of populist national rhetoric to undermine the foundations of civil and peaceful coexistence within American society. All democracies are vulnerable, even those we thought were stronger. American democracy is strong and will overcome this crisis. President Biden and Vice President Harris should help create a climate of concord that heals the wounds of division and polarization. Rejection abroad, racism, aversion to women, anti-Semitism, denial of climate change or anti-vaccine activism represent the delusions of an increasingly present far right in Western democracies. Together with this iliberal ideology, which advocates fear of the different, let us not forget that the growth of inequalities, tax evasion, deind industrialization and high unemployment have also, of course, contributed to millions of people in the United States and the European Union losing faith in democracy. It is time to understand that ignoring the scourge of inequality represents not only an unacceptable injustice from a moral point of view but also the origin of the worst political cataclysm of the last lustro, from Brexit to Trumpism. We see populsmos in turn fueled by a nativist ideology that rejects societies of equal human beings in rights. The horrific scenes of the Capitol also show that we need to fight misinformation more effectively and guarantee citizens' right to truthful information. The digital services law proposed by the Commission should help us regulate the removal of illegal content from online platforms with full respect for freedom of expression. Another challenge shared with the Biden and Harris Administration is the reconstruction of a multilateral system that ensures respect for democratic norms and institutions. In the Social Democratic family we are committed to a revitalized Transatlantic Partnership. We need to formulate joint strategies under the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, the Nuclear Agreement with Iran, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization. Let us not fall into a false debate which forces us to choose between the European agenda and the transatlantic agenda. A European Union with strategic autonomy would be the best partner for the United States. On both sides of the Atlantic we have to learn that democracies are built every day. Let us be aware of what we are playing and let us not forget what the second president of the United States, John Adams, had in mind in the foundation of his country: freedom, once lost, is lost forever. In our hands is preserving it.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, the attack on the Capitol and on the foundation of democracy was outrageous. While shocking and in extreme contrast to America’s political tradition, this event has easily recognisable roots — populist, the pursuit of individualistic interest while in public office, extreme polarisation and huge lies, made up and propagated even by the country’s highest office. No democracy in the world is immune to these dangers. In Europe there are numerous politicians that flirt with the same recipe and it is our duty to stand by our values, confront them and call a lie a lie.  Dear colleagues, today’s inauguration of the 46th President, Joe Biden, and of the Vice-President, Kamala Harris, gives a new opportunity to the United States and to the transatlantic partnership. It is an opportunity we Europeans and Americans cannot miss. We need to roll up our sleeves and reshape our long-standing partnership. Let’s put trade tensions behind us, as our farmers, for instance, are eager for a moratorium on the sanctions, and let’s build a common vision on how to deal with our common challenges. Let’s level up our commitment to fight climate change and openly discuss how to deal with digital giants — two very important files for both Europeans and Americans — and let’s identify how to support countries in the world to recover from the pandemic and back on track. And, most importantly, we Europeans should seize Mr Biden’s proposal to build an alliance of democratic countries that cherish freedom and respect human rights, while we in Parliament should be a strong partner for this initiative. We can prove to the world that democracies are resilient, fit for the challenges of this new century and ready to fight populist disinformation and authoritarianism. (Applause)

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is changing its president today after giving the world a damning spectacle: I am of course talking about the shocking images of the Capitol. This desecration of the temple of American democracy is serious and the deaths, among the police as well as among the demonstrators, are all tragedies. Violating the symbolic institution of the US Congressional buildings is inexcusable, but this stormy demonstration was by no means a coup d'etat. Joe Biden lamented the unprecedented aggression of American democracy. He had said nothing when, a few months earlier, the same buildings were invaded by the radical extreme left and the Black Lives Matter movement. The other damning spectacle that should worry us is the exclusion by almost all social networks of a democratically elected and still-in-office president. This is an unprecedented historical assault on this essential democratic principle: respect for freedom of expression. Social media has disconnected Donald Trump, arrogating the exorbitant right to create new rules. They believe that the terms of use of their services take precedence over the constitution of sovereign states. Joe Biden shows his willingness to re-establish American world leadership with bellicose accents. This can only worry us after Donald Trump's tenure marked by years without military adventure, arguably his most significant accomplishment, after half a century of American military interventions at the whim of successive presidents. When Joe Biden says, and I quote, "We have to prove to the world that the United States is ready to lead again, not only with the example of our power but also with the power of our example," it is arrogant, it is not America that we love. Beyond man and his style, Donald Trump's election defeat does not call into question the political agenda he has developed in the United States and which is, everywhere the planet, carried by people: regulation of the globalized economy, questioning the role of the policeman of the world of the United States, rejection of political correctness, listening to populations in the face of growing inequalities. These themes are those carried by the National Rally in France, the Lega in Italy, the AfD in Germany, all of our allies in Europe. And it is this deep respect for the peoples that will bring us to power to protect in Europe weakened democratic practices and seriously undermined civil liberties in the name of a good back for health security.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, dear colleagues, the shocking scenes from Washington have not materialised out of thin air. They were the direct result of Trump egging them on, but also of four years of daily lies, a contempt for facts, of relentless attacks on free media and portraying dissenting opinion as evil or a conspiracy. And this proves that even the strongest democracies are vulnerable when challenged on a steady and aggressive basis. I very much hope that the inauguration today goes well and smoothly, and I wish President Biden a lot of success. Dear colleagues, imagine that the riots to overturn a free and fair election would have happened here at the European Parliament or in the parliament of one of the Member States. Sounds unbelievable, sounds far away? But do we really think in Europe we are safe from the threats of populism and demagogues, from disinformation and attacks to overthrow the rule of law? Remember the Brexit campaign five years ago, filled with blatant lies and false promises. Think of the Polish Government’s unbelievable disregard for women’s ownership of their own bodies. Think of what we sometimes hear here in this Chamber. And perhaps most emblematic: don’t forget Viktor Orbán’s systematic dismantling of Hungary’s rule of law, blaming every imaginable or unimaginable foreign foe, from George Soros to migrants, to indeed the EU itself. And let’s keep all of this in mind when looking at the events across the Atlantic. Those events should inspire humbleness rather than fuel a false belief that we’re safe from all of this in the EU. We must learn from those shocking events in Washington. Firstly, we should take seriously those who announce that they want to destroy democracy. Many participants in the Capitol riots had announced their intentions in plain view. It shouldn’t have come as a surprise. Far-right groups are also underestimated in Europe. They commit murders, they purchase weapons, and yet there’s very little attention to what they’re planning. They are a real threat, both on this side and on the other side of the Atlantic. And secondly, let’s remember that democracies are fragile and are always ‘work in progress’, and the EU has not always been agile enough to prevent the erosion of rule of law in several Member States. We must relentlessly work to safeguard fundamental rights and rule of law. And thirdly, we need to look into the role of the social media tech giants in this crisis. Disinformation, amplified by algorithms, has divided societies and has even cost human lives. At the same time, the cooperative executives have acquired unbelievable power. So let’s bring social media under democratic scrutiny. That can wait no longer.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the United States has always been a beacon of freedom. I wonder how long that will last. Nobody disputes that the breach of the Capitol was a criminal act and that the perpetrators have to be punished.  The question is: where does the United States go from here? Freedom of expression is under siege. Big tech companies cancel accounts arbitrarily, rather than on the basis of democratically adopted legislation. As rapporteur of the Competition Report 2020, I’m of the view that big tech companies abuse their dominant position. Their power must be broken. If need be, structural unbundling should be the reply.  Democrats are traumatised after four years of Trump. I can understand that. But revenge, retribution, exclusion and cancelling 74 million voters is not the answer. We can agree that many of the divisions in the United States are also found in our societies. The new incumbents – and I wish them luck today – should refrain from criminalising dissent. Raising inconvenient questions is the core of democracy. If politicians and media do precisely that, censorship will prevail and the US will become the People’s Republic of America. That would mean the end of freedom in the entire world.

name: Martin SCHIRDEWAN
text: Mr President, I would like to like to like the Left Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the Four years of Trump have undermined confidence in US democracy, weakened organizations like the United Nations and the World Health Organization, and destroyed and ended international agreements. That is why Joe Biden's inauguration today is a good one for hope, but above all for expectations of a different policy of the United States. The shocking images of the storming of the Capitol and the failed coup attempt did not come out of nowhere, as other colleagues have already pointed out. Democracy in the US has been under constant attack from the White House over the past four years. Democracy is under threat, not only in the United States, where we have also seen the emergence of a new fascist movement, but democracy is also under attack in other regions, including here in the middle of the European Union, and enemies of democracy who have made common cause with Trump in recent years are also sitting in this House. Some have already spoken, but others will do so in the course of this debate. The transatlantic relationship must be turned back on its feet in the future, and from my group's point of view, there are very specific demands on the administration of Joe Biden, which should certainly meet with broad support here in this House as well. Firstly, a return to multilateralism: instead of further weakening international organisations such as the United Nations or the World Health Organisation, we need to strengthen them. Secondly, a common policy committed to climate protection. The announced re-entry of the US into the Paris agreement on climate change is a first step to be welcomed. Thirdly, joint work on a stable world peace order. This applies to relations with China as well as with Russia. But this also means nuclear disarmament and the re-entry of the United States into the anti-nuclear agreement with Iran. Fourthly, US policy must be geared towards the restoration and strengthening of democracy by defending citizens' rights and freedoms, but also by resolutely combating social inequality, which is increasingly gutting social cohesion in the United States, but also here in Germany, in the European Union. Anyone who really wants to protect democracy must finally find the courage to limit the economic and political power of the large corporations and the super-rich and to redistribute social prosperity. This applies on both sides of the Atlantic.

name: Tiziana BEGHIN
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is a natural partner of the European Union, a fundamental ally of our values, rights and multilateralism, but our mutual friendship has been neglected over the last four years, and the whole world has suffered. The outgoing President has pursued policies that have proved damaging to the European Union, almost breaking the deep bond that unites us. Now is the time to put an end to the harmful antagonisms and to re-establish our commercial, political and human ties. That is what the citizens are asking for. That is why I hope that President Biden will immediately demonstrate his goodwill and abolish American tariffs on European products, thus getting our reports back on track. Furthermore, if we really wanted to maintain a positive aspect of the presidency that has just ended, I hope that it will not engage your country in further external conflicts and that it will strengthen public confidence in democratic institutions. I would like to end by congratulating President Biden on his victory. The world expects a lot from him.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: Madam President, Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, relief and hope are undoubtedly the dominant feelings in Europe in the face of the end of the Trump presidency and many interventions here have underlined this this morning. But relief and hope should not, for us Europeans, mean euphoria and amnesia. Our historical, cultural, commercial and security ties with the United States, the special place of this great country in the world, naturally make it our priority and privileged partner. We can therefore only welcome the arrival of a new administration that respects this transatlantic link and is concerned with restoring trust relations with its allies. Our interests often converge but they are not always the same, which is why the euphoria I sometimes notice here would not be a responsible attitude. It will take action to overcome real litigation, such as the so-called unfair trade surcharges that hit some of our sectors. And it is the Burgundy that tells you that wine taxes are particularly incomprehensible to people who love the United States. Nor should we forget that the Trump parenthesis is not entirely accidental. To be too happy about his departure, we quickly forget why he arrived and how he won four years ago. In a text from 1941, in the midst of a dark period, Raymond Aron, updating the lessons of the great Greek thinkers, explained to us how democracies perish from within, with the mortal danger of demagogues taking advantage of their weaknesses, their contradictions, but also the lack of results of public policies. Let us remember this in the United States and here in Europe. The perspective we must build with the United States must be lucid, not naive.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, in just a matter of hours, reason and leadership and loyalty to the values of the US Constitution will return to the White House. And let me congratulate soon-to-be President Biden and, in particular, the first female Vice-President of the United States, Kamala Harris, on this historic day. Today is historic for multiple reasons. Never has the threat of violence loomed so large over the inauguration of an American president. And the wounds of four years of lies, disarray and division run deep. The incoming Biden-Harris administration will have to reunite the American people, heal these wounds and build back better. Not only do the American people need that, but so do our transatlantic relations. From today on, the US, the EU and all democratic allies must take responsibility as a team. Together, we must tackle this covid crisis, the climate crisis and the global crisis of democracy, side by side as equal partners with equal responsibilities.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: – Madam President, Biden’s inauguration is a victory for democracy. But even with Biden, it cannot be business as usual. First, we need to redefine our transatlantic relationship by establishing a stronger and more integrated European pillar, especially in defence. And secondly, we have to increase our fight against at least a dozen mini-Trumps in Europe who try to poison democracy on this side of the pond: Farage, who manipulated Brexit with lies; Orbán, who is killing Hungary’s democracy further every day; and then I don’t even talk about Salvini, Le Pen and Dewinter. People vote for these pied pipers of Hamelin because they feel insecure about their future, so the best way to fight them is not to wait for Biden, but to speed up European cooperation and integration – the COVID recovery fund, the euro bonds, the European health union, the role of Frontex – that’s what we need to kill the Trump virus here in Europe.

name: Susanna CECCARDI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to join in the concern that many people have recently expressed about what has happened in the United States in recent days. Violence is never the solution, and effective condemnation must also be linked to the opening up of a prospect of dialogue. But it is a fact that events such as those seen on 6 January are important indicators of the state of health of a democracy. The hope for a stable partner, equal to the geopolitical challenges that lie ahead, is that President Biden understands the malaise of American democracy and the socio-political dynamics that led to the capitol hill assault. When millions of people who believe that an election result is rigged choose to occupy the centre of political power, the first thing to do is to ask what caused this unease. The prevailing narrative, fueled not only by politicians but also by the media and experts, and attacks aimed at undermining the legitimacy of the Trump presidency have progressively eroded confidence in institutions, generating this dangerous boomerang. The path to reconciliation passes through an inclusive political debate, which returns to consider the demands of those 75 million liberal and conservative Americans, without disqualifying them from the outset. Therefore, freedom of expression and excessive power concentrated in the hands of some private individuals will be crucial issues in the coming months and will also affect the Old Continent very closely. In the long run, the prospect of turning social media into virtual ideological bubbles will contribute to further radicalisation of positions, coupled with inability and a lack of predisposition to dialogue and mutual respect. Trump's expulsion thus accelerates the process of turning his opponent into an enemy. Relations between the two sides of the Atlantic are solid and we will all work to ensure that, in the course of this administration, they become more and more so.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for At last, Donald Trump's presidency is turning into history. At last we can put his fossil nostalgia, his nationalism, his racism and unstable actions behind us.  However, it is all too easy to think that we are now spared all this just because Trump is away from the White House. That's wrong. Instead, it is more important than ever that we continue to fight to uphold, strengthen and defend democracy.  Donald Trump has shown how easy it is to get people to believe in conspiracy theories. How easy it is to incite, confuse and spread hatred and racism. Unfortunately, he has many followers. Here in Europe, too. President-elect Joe Biden has a great responsibility on his shoulders. But so have we.  Democracy must be defended. Every day, in every room, in every meeting.

name: Witold Jan WASZCZYKOWSKI
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab In this House, I would like to ask for a sober and honest assessment of the situation in the United States and for an honest assessment of President Trump's policies. I think we are wrongly demonizing the president. It wasn't he who attacked the Capitol. There have been numerous provocations. Looking at European-American relations from the perspective of my part of Central Europe, the US is a European power that in the 20th century came to Europe's aid many times.  Looking at relations with the United States during donald trump's presidency, it should be mentioned that he strengthened these ties – military, energy ties, supported the Issue of the Tri-Sea. I admonish myself for a sober assessment.  I believe that President Biden will uphold the actions and commitments that President Trump has made to our part of Europe.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her As of today, President Joe Biden faces the sheer titanic task of enabling a deeply divided society to find ways out of the ditch while reintegrating it into the international community. What gives hope is the millions of young Americans who have worked so much idealism for the Us of Civil Rights that they have been able to defeat the conservative billionaires and the evangelicals behind Trump. Without them, it will not succeed – black lives matter. Trump lived on conflict and destruction of what is. No previous US president has instigated more trade wars than he has. The EU and the US must now also reorient their economic and trade policies to not only serve the big players, but also to improve the living conditions of all citizens in real terms. The potential of the US, the EU, China, and many others must be exploited to finally address the key issues for humanity together. The path to this goal has long been agreed in the UN with the 17 Sustainability Goals – the period to 2030. That is the task that we must also work together in partnership relations with the United States.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Madam President, exactly a century ago, in his campaign for the Presidency, Warren Harding said, ‘America’s present need is not heroics, but healing; not nostrums, but normalcy; not revolution, but restoration; not agitation, but adjustment’. A hundred years later, the US is facing the same problems, and I must say the people have voted and the Congress has finalised the decision. But if the new administration looks back to the past instead of the future, populism will prevail. President-elect Biden, we might have ideological differences, but there is one thing that binds us together, and that is the respect for democratic institutions, rule of law and fair politics. Needless to say, these are just some of the many things my country, Hungary, is lacking currently. Just like the President a hundred years ago, you must navigate your country back to the path of normalcy, and the same normalcy should be brought back to US—EU relations. Don’t deal with the past because, if you do so, the polarisation of the US society will be worse. Show us an example of good governance and let us learn from the examples you are setting. I promise you my party and I will be working hard to take my country back to normalcy next year.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, today the entire world is looking at Washington DC as Mr Joseph Biden is inaugurated as the 46th President of the United States. President Biden deserves all the best wishes for the enormous challenges that are lying ahead of him. Today’s inauguration certainly opens a new chapter for our American friends, but it also opens a new chapter in our transatlantic relations, which have been under such tremendous pressure since 2017. Strategic goals are important. They are crucial for our relations, to renew the trust that is at the heart of our alliance, to agree on a common strategy to address global challenges, and to adapt our political, military, technological and economic cooperation, so that we have the most effective alliance for protecting freedom, securing peace and supporting a rules-based order in an increasingly challenging world. As Commission President Ursula von der Leyen pointed out this morning, there are certainly massive challenges we should tackle jointly, such as the COVID-19 pandemic, the economic recovery, trade and digital technology, climate change and, of course, foreign policy and security issues. So let us give a fresh impetus to our transatlantic relations. Things can only get better, and I am convinced they will get better.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: – Madam President, for 70 years the international order, the representation of democratic values, has been based on cooperation between the US and the European Union. For the last four years we have lost our transatlantic partner. Congratulations to President Biden and Vice-President Harris. Our hopes and expectations are that the new administration will seek to refresh our relations on what we are — allies working together for a multilateral system based on fair rules, shared values, democracy and the rule of law.  But the European Union has to strive to redefine the relationship as one of an equal to an equal. That also requires bigger investments from our side. Where we agree, we should act together. Where we disagree, like regulating giant tech companies, we should negotiate our differences and reach common solutions. The United States is much better than the events we witnessed two weeks ago and I firmly believe that our cooperation partnership can be much better than it is today.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: – Madam President, a few hours ago the 45th President of the United States issued his farewell address. Today he will be leaving in a separate ceremony. He spoke of unity yet departs the White House through a separate door. He spoke of having started no new wars, yet I remind him that he brought no new peace either. On 6 January I was astonished to see the mob trample over George Washington’s tomb in the Congress Rotunda, and no one even stopped, because no one even knew any more that it was there. It made me think whether we do enough about democracy education, whether we speak enough of it, whether we are compassionate when we speak about it. Could this happen here, Monsieur Le President, Frau Präsidentin? Here in this Parliament or there at the Berlaymont, or in the Bundestag or Casa Poporului in Romania, where I come from? If the answer is yes, then we have our work cut out for us. Frau Präsidentin, Mr Giuliani encouraged the mob to do trial by combat. I encourage you to do justice by education, by cooperation, by love.

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has been rapporteur for "Democracy is the need to occasionally follow the opinions of other people," Winston Churchill said. It is just the case that in the United States in 2016, those who are not otherwise listened to have organised a majority. Democracy has not perished from this. In 2020, more people have gone to the polls than ever before, and even the inferior Donald Trump has collected more votes than Barack Obama did in his election and re-election. We should be prepared to accept that there are people who disagree, and instead of being happy here now that they have finally been got rid of, we should ask how they can be included. The storming of the Capitol was without question a crime, and it is a warning to each of us. But shutting down a Twitter account with 80 million followers is a major attack on democracy and free exchange of views. In this respect, I can only ask the victors to exercise humility and reason at the moment of victory and not to triumph.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, when President Lincoln spoke at Gettysburg, expressing the resolve that government of the people, by the people, for the people, shall not perish from the earth, the doors opened to a new birth of freedom in that young nation. The secular and venerable achievement of building a popular democracy became a shining example to many nations.  Today, the battle to defend and develop democracy has become a global battle. We can find encouragement in the actions of those who, on 6 January, gave priority to their constitutional obligations when the rioters challenged democracy. But the forces of darkness cooperate internationally. That is why we must help in building the global alliance for democracy. We must contribute to that primarily by allowing a new birth of freedom, of justice, of respect, and of defence of the public good on our own shores. Welcome President Biden. Welcome Vice President Harris.

name: Carlo FIDANZA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a new season is opening today and we wish the new Us Administration well. Many certainties are common in this House, but many more are the unresolved questions. Do you really think that Joe Biden will solve the problems of vision and leadership of a lost and soulless Europe? Are you really under the illusion that, once the monster Trump is brought down, tens of millions of patriots disappear in Europe and around the world who believe in the values of identity, sovereignty, family, religious sense, merit, work ethic?  Are you democratic enough to want to rule the world with web multinationals, which censor the freedom of expression of citizens and political leaders, even when they respect the law? Are you really so irresponsible as to think that the world will be more peaceful and secure if we return to the Obama-Clinton doctrine, which paved the way for wars, Islamic fundamentalism, refugees and illegal immigrants? And do you really believe that agreements can be made with the Chinese Communist regime without worrying about rebalancing global trade in defence of our production? For us, transatlantic relations are not something to bent on the interests of the party but the framework within which to respond to the great challenges of our time. We will continue to work in this direction.

name: Idoia VILLANUEVA RUIZ
text: – Mr. President, Biden takes office today, following the violent assault on the Capitol that leaves behind five dead and a broken democracy, an assault encouraged by the still president of the United States, Trump— "To my fierce followers, let us fight!" —.  There are still many details to be known, but we do know the scandalous difference between the actions of the security forces under Trump's tenure in the face of protests by progressive movements such as Black Lives Matter and the lack of media and collusions in the assault on the Capitol. This attack calls for the strong condemnation of the international community to its encouraging and conniving. Trump has fueled to the limit hatred, racism, machismo, denialism.  It's not about the last ponytail. It is a political movement, followed by political groups that are here today: in Spain, Vox, bleached by the People's Party; in Italy, Salvini; Hungary, Orban. An expression of the same movement that tries to attack who we are: coexistence, democracy, rights, freedoms, using hatred and the intoxication of public debate. Those who shut up are also and will be guilty.  Today we must value and defend what they want to destroy: the common. Only through social policies and redistributive economies can we defeat the inequality, uncertainty and fear that these monsters fuel. Today, from here, I say to all those who are suffering fear, uncertainty and feel pointed out: not a step back!

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: Madam President, the planned invasion of far-right reactionary forces on Capitol Hill, as well as the tragedy that preceded the American elections, expose all those who "fall from the clouds" for so-called American democracy; that of dozens of wars, dismemberment of countries, coups and overthrows of elected governments with blood-blooded peoples, both with Republicans and with Democrats. With both, the American people have experienced exploitation, unemployment, repression and racism over time.  The depth of the rot of a society in deep decline lies beyond the Trump administration, and those who cultivate false hopes for a pro-grassroots Biden administration will soon be disproved, arguing that it will put the brakes on Turkish aggression. Trumpism cannot de-incriminalize the same rotten capitalist system as its holy contradictions and class polarization.  All of this is directly linked to the acute problems of the American economy, china's questioning of US primacy and increased competition with the European Union. The people must be vigilant, not to pay for the crisis in the US with a new round of sharpening aggression and escalating imperialist plans.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: – Madam President, in a few hours Donald Trump will become nothing but an appendix to the history books. As President von der Leyen pointed out, we cannot say the same about Trumpism, a virus that is still very much alive. Trump has confronted democratic institutions, the separation of powers, international organisations, the free press, and even science. Never has an American President hurt so much and harmed so many in such a short time. As Europeans, there is one lesson to be learned from these last four years. When it comes to our destiny, we cannot rely on the United States alone. Not anymore. The myth has fallen. If we want to maintain peace and international order, if we want to protect our democracy, free press and human rights, Europe must react now. It is time for Europe to take a step forward. The world needs European values and principles more than ever. We have suffered two world wars, and two cruel dictatorships in fascism and communism. We know well what it is to live without freedom, justice or rights. We have a moral duty to prevent something similar from happening again. And the commitment goes beyond our borders. It is a commitment to the world and to history. From Europe to the United States: welcome back, we missed you.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: – Madam President, the first priority to relaunch EU—US relations is to fight the pandemic and the related economic and political challenges. Cooperation is needed so that the least developed countries will also get their fair share of vaccines and their economies will not break under the weight of increased debt loans. We should show the world that true leading democracies can stand together across the globe and by the weakest members of the international community. To quote the words of former President Wilson, from 100 years ago: ‘Make the world safe for democracy.’ Today, we need to make the world safe for democracy, also with the US, and make the global digital world safe for democracy. There is a lot to be done, not least to regulate platforms and emerging technologies, such as AI, in line with human rights and democratic principles. While intensified cooperation is our aim, we need to continue strengthening Europe’s independence capabilities. As a stronger autonomous actor, we will have more to give to the world and to our partners.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, we all congratulate President Biden and Vice—President Harris, and in particular of all the girls out there, we congratulate Vice—President Harris. The transatlantic relationship is crucial for us, but the pre-Trump era will not come back. In fact, the relationship had already profoundly changed, but Europe didn’t seem to notice. A strong partnership needs two strong pillars, and Europe has indeed rapidly grown stronger and more powerful in recent years, and Renew welcomes that strong and self-assured Europe.  But, we should not be blind to the weaknesses in our own European democracy. Events in Washington two weeks ago are a warning for Europe as well. We don’t have one single big Trump but we have many ‘mini Trumps’, and like in the United States they are part of the political leadership of the EU, and they get their podium, not just on social media Madam President, but also traditional media, and yes they get protection from traditional parties as well.  So, today we enter a new era. Let’s make it the era of liberal democracy, shoulder to shoulder, with our American friends.

name: Tom VANDENDRIESSCHE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, free speech is fundamental in our democracy. With this fundamental right, citizens control those in power. This is guaranteed by the constitution of every nation-state and by the European Convention on Human Rights. Social media and the Internet are the modern marketplaces where we exercise this right to free speech. These platforms, however, are not free markets but are dominated by an oligarchy, a Silicon Valley that does business everywhere but does not pay fair taxes anywhere. Multinationals such as Facebook, Twitter, Google, Apple and Amazon control the information in our democracy through their monopoly. They then appropriate the power to determine what the truth is, and to censor what they find undesirable. In so doing, they determine who still has free speech in our democracy as a fundamental right. Moreover, they also appear to have the power to deny their direct competitors – Parler – access to the market and thus liquidate them. This is a fundamental shift of power from the people to the shareholder, from democracy to oligarchy, from the constitution to the user agreement. This is downright dangerous for our democracy, which is built on the free market and free citizens. That's why we need to break up these companies. And if that is not enough, we must deprive them of access to the European market. The European Union has the power to do so. Use them. Time for action.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: – Madam President, hope is back in Washington. In these dark hours, we look to the dawn of Inauguration Day. Democracy remains under threat in Europe and in the United States. But Joe Biden gets it. Kamala Harris gets it. They want to tackle injustice. They want to match our European Green Deal and address the climate emergency. So America, welcome back to the Paris Agreement. We missed you, Mr Kerry. Let’s talk. Let’s build this new transatlantic partnership, link climate action to racial justice, tackle poverty in Baltimore, in Brussels and in Dublin.  Martin Luther King said: ‘We are not satisfied, and we will not be satisfied until justice rolls down like waters and righteousness like a mighty stream.’ Those words ring as true today as they did half a century ago. Today, there is a ripple of hope. I’m Irish, but my mother was from Chicago. So I wish you well. Ireland and the EU are your friends. We don’t always agree – we’ll call you out when we don’t – but today is a good day. A day of hope.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, isn’t it ironic that, for four years, we listened to the Democrats claim that walls are immoral, unnecessary and ineffective, yet today in Washington DC, an eight—foot wall circumvents the Biden inauguration ceremony. For four years, the Democrats and the far left used every single opportunity to attack the Second Amendment of the American Constitution, allowing citizens to bear arms. Yet today they have organised 30 000 very well—armed federal troops, flown in from all over the country.  This sort of hypocrisy is of course nothing new for the Democrats and the far left. Last summer, we witnessed the eruption of violence in many American cities with zones being occupied by the Antifa and BLM mob of Marxist extremists. The far left media and the Democrats call them peaceful protesters. However, when the protesters are not extreme Marxist terrorists, but patriots, suddenly they are called terrorists. One thing is sure: in history you either go down as a patriot or as a coward. The Democrats, dear friends on the left, are the cowards today because (inaudible)

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, I agree with those who have said here that hate speech always ends in violence, that discourse against democracy always ends up trying to destroy it. But we all know, and it has also been said, that Trump and hate speech have their supporters on this side of the Atlantic, and therefore forgive me if I cannot take very seriously speeches of shock and indignation at what happened on Capitol Hill from the caucus that continues to house Viktor Orbán's party.  In this time, the time we live in is a time of struggle for democracy and freedom and all democratic forces have to choose which side they are on and act accordingly. To act accordingly is also here, in the European Union, to look at what has made the far right born. The far right feeds on the social wounds that also exist in Europe that many European policies have sought to reinforce and those who today are eager to resume bad memory adjustment programmes will do well to take this balance and this historic exercise.

name: Ivan Vilibor SINČIĆ
text: – Dear Chairman, colleagues and colleagues, I have warned before about the dictatorship of billionaires that threatens us.  Kicking the American president off social media is scandalous, it's a blow to democracy and free speech. This decision was not made by some institutions on the basis of the law, but made by company owners, managers. It's about people who have riches bigger than entire nations. While here the corona crisis choir cuts Europe's budget, while 10% or 15% of Croatia's GDP has disappeared, they are getting richer and accumulating an increasing number of money into their accounts. States are getting weaker, corporations and their owners are getting stronger.  That's not all. Also, according to research by the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, 147 companies hold 40% of the world's wealth and 737% hold 80% of the world's wealth, otherwise with intertwined ownership among themselves. It's time to make it impossible for corporations to eat democracy. A limit should be introduced on the wealth of these people and thus on their power and the funds should be used as one of the sources of income for the universal unconditional basic income program.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, the past four years have been very challenging for transatlantic relations. We have seen tweets replacing official communication between allies. We have seen temperament replacing long—standing policies. Now that this has ended, we’re looking forward to working with a US President who respects the freedom of speech. A President who respects the democratic order. An American President who wants an independent and strong judiciary. And let me be clear: one can only defend the rule of law around the globe if one respects and defends the rule of law at home.  Now is the time for us as allies, the European Union and the United States of America, to defend human rights around the globe. The fundamentals of American democracy and of European democracy are the same: respecting existing rules and institutions, respecting the international order and our allies and, first and foremost, respecting our values. Challenging these values has only served autocrats in recent years.  America has a fresh start. Transatlantic relations have a fresh start. We should be looking forward, but we should also learn from the lessons of recent years, and the lesson is clear: fake news and hate policies are dangerous. They lead to violence. That is why we should also tell people here in Europe: stay away from extremism, stay away from hate policies, stay away from populism, stay away from lies. They are dangerous. To conclude, I would like to bring up an issue which is important to 30 million EU citizens. Today, the citizens of Cyprus, Croatia, Bulgaria and Romania still require a visa to enter the United States. Let’s work together with the new American administration to ensure full visa reciprocity between the United States and the European Union.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr President of the Council, it is well known that President Biden and Vice-President Harris face an unlikely task in their own country to unite their people, strengthen democracy and once again become a global player on which we can rely. But let today be above all a day of hope and perspective. Hope and perspective, for example, for a restart in global climate policy because they will rejoin the Paris Agreement. But more will be needed. We will need a really ambitious climate policy, as we have the Green Deal. Hope and perspective also for a re-active United States in the United Nations, the World Health Organization and the World Trade Organization.  So let us strengthen that partnership, but let us do so from the european Union's own strength and let us not be at the hands of the United States, but make sure that we are equal partners and take up our role in the world together.

name: Liesje SCHREINEMACHER
text: – Madam President, today marks a very important moment. A moment followed by many people in Europe and around the world: the inauguration of the United States’ President Joe Biden. It is also a moment of hope: of hope that our transatlantic ally and partner has finally returned and is ready to cooperate in a way that today’s situation asks of us. Recent events have shown that the US is suffering from great polarisation, which this President will have to address. This will not be an easy task, and this is also something that we in Europe are all too familiar with. Yes, the United States has changed, but so did Europe. So of course, our transatlantic cooperation will not be the same as a few decades ago. But having said that, I do hope that the Biden administration will join us in our ambitions and will join forces to promote multilateralism, rule-based trade, provide security and fight climate change. With that, I wish President Biden and Vice—President Harris all the strength, wisdom and courage in the years to come.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the United States is and will always be the polar star for democracy and freedom in the world. Beyond the political spectrum, the new American Government will always find in us in the League a serious and reliable ally, firmly aligned with the Atlantic Alliance in defence of the values of the free West. Today, more than ever, it is necessary to relaunch relations between Europe and the United States forcefully in order to face together the great challenges of our time. And the first challenge to be won together is against Communist China, which represents the greatest threat to our freedom and democracy. It is scandalous that Europe and the Italian GOVERNMENT of PD and 5Stelle are silent accomplices in the misdeeds of the Beijing regime. The game on 5G and the trade agreement between Europe and China, so dear to Merkel and Macron, are there to prove it. No more ambiguity, no more double games, no more blood-stained business with China. Ladies and gentlemen, it is clear to everyone that the Chinese dictatorship is waged an economic war and a war of civilisation against the Western world. Together with our American allies, we must be prepared to defend our freedom and democracy by all means. Italians, Americans and free men from all over the world will never die slaves to china's communist dictatorship.

name: Marcel KOLAJA
text: – Madam President, let me make one thing clear: I condemn the recent attacks on the Capitol as well as Donald Trump’s statements. However, I am also concerned about how much power dominant online platforms have, and by the fact that they have been taking over essential functions that belong to democratic institutions. Deciding what is appropriate and denying people the right to speak by suspending their accounts without a court order is a dangerous practice.  Today it is Donald Trump, but whose account will be suspended tomorrow? This is not how democracy and justice should work. In a democratic society, only independent courts can decide what is illegal. We need to update our legislation. Reform bills introduced via the American legislation regulating platforms have not been successful. Now it’s time for Europe to lead by example with the Digital Services Act.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, of course how much I hate, how much phobia, how afraid of Trump. It was said when he won that it was the end of the world, that fascism was coming, that it was going to end American democracy, that it was going to ruin it, that it would be war. There has been no war on the part of the United States, he is the first president not to do one in generations. Hate, phobia and fear to value what has happened are bad advisors. Trump is accused of storming the Capitol here. He called for a peaceful demonstration. But Biden and Harris are not accused of mass violence, fires, looting, murders throughout 2020 with the Black Lives Matter, even though those offenders, when they were arrested, were bailed out. Here the censorship that has taken place has been silenced. We are really violating all our principles by appealing to them. He did not protest the violence of black lives matter. He did not protest the censorship that has been applied to media reporting the corruption of the Biden family, which has never come to light. We are denying our principles, and we will also pay dearly.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which "It must have been Trump, but it is over now," one would say almost melodically on this day, which makes it possible again to look at the full spectrum and potential of transatlantic relations. As foreign policy spokesman for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I am pleased that the new team in Washington is also talking about revitalising American diplomacy. Returning to as many areas of the multilateral, rules-based relationship network as possible is an expectation that we also clearly express in our interests. The Paris climate agreement has been mentioned, the JCPOA with Iran must be revived. Other key words of our expectations in the area of arms control: the renewal and renegotiation of the New START agreement, hopefully renegotiating open skies. We Europeans want double zero double zero solutions on both sides, we must fulfil our share of the defence burden – 2% – we must work together to strengthen countries like Ukraine against an aggressive Russia and abolish all punitive tariffs on each other, make the WTO fully operational again and jointly commit China to china in this framework. I hope that in the medium term we will get something like a TTIP 2.0. In the long run, this strengthens our democracies over a systemic rival like China.

name: Sven MIKSER
text: – Madam President, the events we witnessed at the US Capitol on 6 January were horrible and reprehensible. They surely do not represent what America is all about, but unfortunately they do represent a danger that continues to lurk, even after the inauguration of the Biden—Harris administration – and not only in the darker corners of US society, but also here on the European continent. It is the danger of authoritarianism that feeds on untruths and conspiracy theories peddled by power-hungry extremists at home and taken advantage of by our external adversaries. The new administration in Washington represents an opportunity to welcome the US back as one of the global leaders in fighting the COVID pandemic and in fighting climate change. There are other policy areas – trade, digital technologies – where it takes more time and patience to restore the transatlantic trust and cooperation, but we must welcome this opportunity with open arms because it represents a chance, among other things, to actually score a final victory against populism and authoritarianism.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, America is back. This is how the new Biden administration summarised their foreign policy, and this is great news. Four years of assault on the multilateral order left us all in danger. Challenges like climate change, disinformation or the pandemic kept rising and our capacities to respond kept shrinking. So we welcome our key ally back to the table. Europe is ready to work together, with more unity and resolve than ever before.  But let’s not try to turn the clock back to the pre-Trump era, it won’t be possible. Autocrats are emboldened, also in Europe, and corruption – at the root of the surging authoritarian trend – is rampant, also in Europe. Civil liberties are at a historic low. The US is no exception. But are we, in Europe? I don’t think so. So where do we go from here? Let’s come together at a global summit of democracy and let’s put human rights and democracy at the centre of our fight, and let’s focus more than ever before on the fight against corruption.

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new US Administration will find a reliable ally in the League in Italy and in Europe. We will always stand shoulder to shoulder with the United States, which has been, is and will always be a point of reference for democracy in the world and for the values of the West. In order to defend these values, Italy, the United States and Europe will have to fight together and have as their lid the containment of Chinese influence in Europe. Unfortunately, on this point, I regret hearing the Italian Prime Minister, Mr Conte, the other day put the world's largest democracy and communist dictatorship on an equal footing. This is unacceptable to the representative of an important country such as Italy, founder of the European Union and member of the G7. The Atlantic Pact is serious. It is tragic and alarming that the Italian Prime Minister does not think so. We believe that strengthening transatlantic relations will mean not signing that wretched trade agreement between the European Union and China on which this Parliament has rightly, Lega in the first place, promised battle.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: Madam President, the appalling assault on the Capitol shows us once again, once again, the fragility of our democracies and that it is essential to constantly defend our rule of law. This is not an isolated incident that would only affect the Americans. Let us remember the German Parliament at the end of August 2020. Our Western democracies have for too long made the mistake of underestimating the dangers of the far right. Has this extreme right, which has marked our common European history in its flesh, have we already forgotten it? What happened on Capitol Hill must be the warning that finally makes us realize that it is time to take seriously the serious divisions and democratic crises that our Western societies are currently going through. This blindness must stop and I appeal to you, Mrs von der Leyen, Mr Borrell, Mr Michel and Mr Sassoli, to start a deep reflection on these subjects. If we do not do it now, tomorrow it will be too late because, as a Spanish proverb says, tomorrow is the word that does not want to do anything.

name: Assita KANKO
text: – Madam President, as the era of ‘America first’ comes to an end, we can begin to look forward to a presidency of ‘Allies first’ from the Biden administration. Europe has spent the last four years carving out its own strategic autonomy. Now we have an opportunity to make the transatlantic alliance great again. By speaking in unison as Democratic allies, our words and actions can be strengthened in the face of the existential challenges that we face: autocrats like Putin, challenges related to the tech revolution, violent Islamic extremism and the threat of climate change. I urge the EU to support Biden’s efforts to unite democracy so that we can reinvigorate multilateralism in our own free image. The recent events in Washington have shown how fragile all of our democracies can be, but I also do we agree with my colleague Danjean that we need to look deep inside the issues and face reality. The free world has the chance to come together in the defence of our common values which have been neglected for too long...  (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Andrius KUBILIUS
text: – Madam President, besides congratulating the new US President, today is also a good occasion to reflect on recent events and how fragile our democracy is. It should become a common inspiration, on both sides of the Atlantic, to become much more serious about challenges towards democracy. Our democracy on the European continent is also suffering from different diseases. Globally, democratic values are being attacked by autocrats in Belarus, Russia and China. Democratic values are also being attacked by an internal ‘cancer of democracy’, by the slow erosion of democracy, and by populism. Joe Biden has promised to organise a global democracy summit. It’s a great idea. Let’s prepare ourselves for that big event. Why not have an EU Conference on the Future of Democracy next to the Conference on the Future of Europe? The defence and promotion of democracy should become our common most important strategic agenda.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, the taking over of the new Us Administration is an opportunity for a global geostrategic reconfiguration and for strengthening relations between the United States and the European Union in a context of pandemic and growing threat of populism and authoritarianism in the world.  Trump's term leaves marks that don't go down with his electoral defeat. We live in a time when the concept of borders is broken. In democracy, foreign policy, in order to have popular legitimacy, has to be understood and accepted internally. That is the case in the United States and that is the case in the European Union. Strategic autonomy is increasingly a key condition for healthy cooperation.  The EU and the US have strong challenges in which their cooperation is key: international security, climate change, health, digitisation of societies are at the top of the agenda. It is an agenda in which cooperation and competition will be side by side and where the ability to successfully confront a centralised model of competing powers will be decisive. We have to be pragmatic, making our values and principles the central axis of transatlantic relations so that the European Union and The United States relationship is a positive sum game for their peoples and for the world.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: – Madam President, it is often said that the US and the EU are founded on the same principles and values, and that is true. But, beyond principles, a partnership is built on trust and reliance. As genuine long-standing partners, we need to know that we can rely on one another in moments of hardship, and this is a moment of hardship for all of us. We need, therefore, to stand by President Biden in his efforts to heal the deep fractures of American society, just as President Biden needs to stand by us Europeans when we are dealing with our own challenges. We can both deliver for all citizens if we work together to fight COVID, to restore multilateralism and a global order based on the rule of law, to meet climate objectives, and to face the digital transformation of our societies and economies.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Europe and the United States have long-lasting ties of friendship, and our security is guaranteed above all by the presence of American troops. And that's still relevant. It is naïve to think that a change of White House host will free us from the NATO membership obligations that President Trump has strongly reminded us of. The pressure for greater financial involvement of European countries in the North Atlantic Alliance will not go away.  We have seen scenes in recent weeks that should not have happened in a democracy. However, the reaction of the biggest social networks was even more shocking. It would be wrong if the 45th president of the United States were only associated in the future with an assault on Capitol Hill, but it would be even worse if the 46th president's term were associated with the beginning of internet censorship and the end of free speech. Whether this or not, the Americans chose not only the head of state, but also the informal leader of the free world. May President Biden do the job. God bless America – and Europe.

name: Traian BĂSESCU
text: – Madam President, today's inauguration of Joe Biden's term is good news for Europe, for America, for the free world.  We must note, however, that the event at the Capitol can only be the definitive signal.
