After two years of street demonstrations, in the great democracies of Europe and America, it all culminated in January 6, the events at the Capitol.  We have to ask ourselves why populists succeed in Europe and America. We need to see what is wrong with our economic, social and political system. And my belief is that the European Union, together with the United States, must reshape the process of globalisation.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Let us not forget that this is a good day when the United States is now swearing in its new president, Joe Biden. A president who wants to strengthen democracy, who believes in multinationalism, who wants to be a force for climate action.  The bloody storming of the Capitol is the result of Trump having long undermined the American electoral system. The EU is right to condemn his actions. But even if Trump, this angry clown, is soon to be relegated to the margins of history, we should not forget that there is a risk that there are many people who want revenge and then it can become even more dangerous, even for the world.  Nevertheless, the great challenge for europe is to stand up for new transatlantic cooperation. Take this opportunity with Biden-Harris, with a climate-oriented European Commission. Make sure to make this year successful for Glasgow. Make sure to fill transatlantic cooperation with climate and ensure that we have a future together that will be even better.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, when 60% of Europeans think that the US system is broken and few think Americans can be trusted, the transatlantic bond is at breaking point. We must urgently rebuild this trust. On trade, isolationism must end. For starters, we need a functioning WTO and all tariffs against the EU lifted. On digital, we need common US—EU regulations on the digital world, from the internet to cyber security. We must not break our digital bond by Europe going alone. To ensure our continued place in the 21st century, we need a renewed US—EU partnership. I hope we now have a partner on the other side of the Atlantic that we can call: a partner that understands the importance of this bond. Here in Europe we must stop promoting protectionist solutions under the banner of sovereignty and remember that we should build bridges, not walls.

name: Danuta Maria HÜBNER
text: – Madam President, I would like to focus on the proposed EU-US trade and technology council. But first let me say that we see on the other side of the Atlantic an American President who values international cooperation and a Transatlantic relationship. I believe if we stand together again and do our trade policy thoughtfully it will give us both greater agency in the global world. Talking about the council, I think it could become a platform to deepen our mutual involvement through facilitating regulatory compatibility in areas of geopolitical relevance. While generating geopolitical benefits in areas like the digital economy, the council could help to avoid the risk of separate regulatory spaces and incompatibility. Benefits from common standards will be particularly high in the areas of new regulatory requirements for technology, investment and security. In this context, the council could also look into innovative approaches to standardisation. After four years of largely dysfunctional relations, there is also the need for this House to intensify our Transatlantic dialogue because we have many converging interests and we face common global challenges.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Michel, Mr Solana, today the United States is finally turning the page. After four years of unilateralism, it is time to get back to politics together. We are sure that the new President Joe Biden will contribute, as promised, to the construction of a renewed international system based on new multilateralism and constructive dialogue with the European Union. There will be many issues to be addressed together. I will cite two of them: global action in the fight against climate change, starting from the Paris Agreement, and a global transatlantic agreement on digital and data, including the issue of the taxation of web giants. Today, right-wing nationalists and populists throughout the world, and their conscious or unknowing allies, are suffering a setback, but the fight for more democracy and social justice throughout the world must continue and it is a battle that must unite peoples, especially at such a difficult time in the history of our world.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Madam President, the storming of Capitol Hill on 6 January was not because people weren’t listened to; it was because they were actively encouraged by a partisan, divisive president. The days of Trump politics are over and I hope that they’re over here in Europe as well. For too long, we haven’t listened to the centre. We’ve been placating and appeasing the right. From now on, I think it’s important that we build a transatlantic alliance based on inclusive politics, on politics that are seen by the progressive centre as necessary.  I wish Joe Biden the best of luck. I wish Kamala Harris the very best as well. They’re both people I passionately believe can bring politics back to the centre and ensure that we have a strong transatlantic alliance that works for citizens and doesn’t appease the right, either in the States or here in Europe, of which, unfortunately, there are many in some governments in Europe and, unfortunately, in this Parliament too. So, from now on, let’s work together to ensure that the transatlantic alliance is strong, is emboldened and is confident in what we’re trying to achieve with regard to the environment, the economy and for the citizens of Europe, the States and the world in general.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: Madam President, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has With Joe Biden and his administration, we have a chance to open a new chapter in the transatlantic relationship. Our values of freedom, democracy and the rule of law unite us. Not everything will change tomorrow, but in areas where we have equal interests, we should work closely together again. The new president's announcement that he will immediately rejoin the Paris climate agreement is good news. The new President's announcement that he will rejoin the WHO is good news. The reform of the WTO was also on the common agenda, as was the joint fight against Corona.  The expectation of good cooperation is high, but the horrific images of the storm of the US Capitol on 6 January are also remembered. The storm was fueled by the echo chambers on the Internet. This development must also serve as a warning to us in Europe. Here, too, there is hatred and misinformation in the echo chambers of the Internet. We must not leave it to the tech companies to decide what can happen on social media. That is the task of the parliaments, and we must now address this.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, Mr Borrell, Mr Michel, I would like to talk about cooperation with the United States in our respective foreign policies.  The coordination of these policies will be useful for the free world, because the promotion of democracy and democratic values and practices is important at a time of great polarization between mature democracies and authoritarian liberal systems. This World Summit for Democracy and a predictable transatlantic common agenda, including private actors, are essential. As regards relations with Turkey, both the Council and the Commission have spoken very recently about our coordination with the United States in relation to Turkey, but Turkey is not a State to be part of the United States. It is a State that wants to be a member of the European Union and, therefore, the nature of our relationship is very different. For us, Turkey is not a third country. For us, Turkey is not a neighbor. And Turkey's obligations to the European Union stem from its status as a candidate and the demand for democratic reforms. I say this because the Council, Mr Michel, sometimes does not insist too much on democratic conditionality, which for this House is indispensable.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, Mr President, the Americans are more than friends, they are brothers. They liberated our territories 76 years ago, I will never forget it. 80,000 died there in my area of Bastogne. Thank you, Mr President, for your commitment to the commemorations. So of course, we have been hit, hurt by these past four years, by the last few weeks, in the last few days. A new era is opening up, which provides opportunities to strengthen these fraternal and quasi-carnal relations, especially, certainly, in relation to the climate, in the fight against global warming. I hope - let us not be naïve - for the taxation of GAFA without a trade response from the United States.  And I very much hope that we can also see and review the agreement with China based on these new contacts and this new relationship that we will develop with the United States, with the Biden administration. It would be folly to go and sign this agreement without having new contacts and without seeing it again in the light of these relationships.

name: Alfred SANT
text: – Madam President, with the Biden administration we should expect that relations with the US can now resume on the basis of a civilised and coherent dialogue. However, the deep dilemmas that gave rise to ‘Trumpism’, both inside and outside the US, will remain, and it will be difficult for President Biden to clear them. First, President Biden will have to try and bridge the deep divide between Americans who are riding with success the ongoing technological changes after having recovered from the effects of the 2008 crisis, and the other half of US society, which has been losing out in the post-modern economy and was badly mauled by the financial crisis. COVID—19 is likely making this divide deeper. Meanwhile, outside the US, the President will have to determine how best to manage the race with China for global predominance. Europe needs to position itself correctly in this context. Given its ideological and cultural affinities with the US, it will seek to promote close cooperation with the Biden administration. However, it should not appear as a member of the US racing team, nor be one.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: – Madam President, over the last four years the US Administration has implemented policies that challenged its partners and surprised its force. With today’s inauguration of the new President of the United States, a new chapter will commence. Nevertheless, the US is entering a new unprecedented era as a divided society. It will also impact its place in the world and, by extension, its ability to work with Europe on common peace and security issues in our neighbourhood and worldwide. This will require extra efforts on our side to export, support leadership and resources to maintain our important transatlantic partnership. I highly welcome the fact that an American return to multilateralism is high on the new Administration’s agenda. Re-joining the Paris Agreement is a big step forward in its global fight against climate change. I congratulate the new President of the United States of America and his Vice-President and wish them and their people and the people of America good luck.

name: Lina GÁLVEZ MUÑOZ
text: – Madam President, our high representative, Josep Borrell, wrote the other day that the latest events in Washington should be a call for attention for the defenders of democracy. But he also referred to growing inequality. Let us not forget that inequality has an effect on democratic health and has had them especially after the austererian exit from the last crisis. The American case shows us that the emphasis on equal opportunities, but maintaining those economic policies that create inequality and which we have also followed here in Europe, does not result in greater equality or greater social mobility; it generates outrage and even hatred and makes you feel excluded from a political system that many people do not feel represent you, as we saw the other day clearly in the take-off of the Capitol. Trump is not the source of this outrage, but is the symptom. We will therefore do well to work together with the new Biden administration against inequalities and misinformation and to defend the promotion of the rule of law and democratic values. And it will also be essential to collaborate in regulation in the digital field.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Madam President, let me start by wishing our US allies and partners well. I am confident that the restart that the world expects will materialise.  But I also want to refer to the scenes that we witnessed in the last month. I don’t often quote Arnold Schwarzenegger, but he was right when he said that it started with ‘lies and lies and lies and intolerance’. The world watched transfixed as the shining city on a hill was ransacked and violated before our very eyes. The mob, after being egged on, enabled and encouraged for years, stormed the United States’ seat of democracy.  There are many lessons for us to learn here. In Europe, the shock gave way to realisation that the weight of the world’s democratic order now rests more heavily on our shoulders. It is true of course that the new administration of Joe Biden and Kamala Harris brings with it new hope of better cooperation, of new Transatlantic expectation, of optimism and a return to normality. But Europe’s role on the world stage cannot be undervalued. Our belief in liberal democracy, founded in values and the rule of law, matters, not just to all our citizens, but to millions more people around the globe looking to us for hope. With increasing hostility to our east and uncertainty to our west, Europe matters. Standing up for the rule of law matters. Defending democracy matters. Leaders’ words matter. Never underestimate how fragile our democracy is.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. –Madam President, Members of the European Parliament, after this interesting debate, it’s clear for all of us, and especially for the Commission, that the Transatlantic partnership remains the most important and strategic relationship for the European Union and its Member States. The stability and prosperity of both sides of the Atlantic is deeply affected by our ability to work together. All of you have been expressing hopes, that we share, that a very good understanding of what Europe means for the US interest and policy is a cornerstone of our future relations.  We are also very much aware that in the past four years, they have delivered an important lesson for the EU for a policy engagement with the US. What has happened has to be taken into consideration in order to build our future relationship, and we should improve our capacity to anticipate the US internal drivers that at the end shape the US foreign policy. Certainly we have now a historic opportunity to rebuild and to reinforce our relationship, to effectively address together the needs and challenges of the 21st century. In the post-corona world, Transatlantic cooperation will revitalise the international rules-based order. As I said yesterday, you had to make multilateralism great again, based on our common values, interests, and pursuing global influence on the Western world.  Dear Members of the European Parliament, most of you have been expressing your convincement that a more assertive, more capable and more resilient Europe will be the best partner for the US. Enhancing Europe’s strategic autonomy will allow for a better cooperation when it comes to the security risks of today and those of the future, and I am sure that the new American administration will understand that and will put in practice a pragmatic framework for this new Transatlantic partnership.  You have been talking about the specific areas of cooperation: being partners and multilateralism. This will mean that we need to push for reforms of the United Nations organisations that preserve its democratic foundations, but being more ready, more able, to face pressing global problems. It’s very good news that the Paris Agreement will be accepted by the US as the framework to fight against climate change. Only with that the new Presidency will make a strong difference on the role of the US in the world.  Thank you very much for all your interventions. I think that together with the Council we will be able to build a new partnership based on dialogue among equals, to preserve the security and defence of democratic values in the world. (Applause)

name: Charles Michel
text: President of the European Council. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this attack on the Capitol on 6 January, we followed it with amazement and experienced it as an electroshock which demonstrates the fragility of what we deeply believe in, because it is the DNA of the European project, the values of freedom, the rule of law, democracy.  If we choose it, this shock can be life-saving because a new page is now opening up in the United States that gives the ability, if we are committed, to be able to build with this ally to which we are attached for historical reasons, for reasons based on values, this new founding pact which must be an opportunity to be mobilised around the three pillars that must be the pillars for this European project.  On the one hand, the values of democracy, the rule of law, this constant, constant commitment. In recent months, in the European Parliament/Council debate, we have committed ourselves in Europe to make concrete progress to this commitment to governance and democracy. We must remain vigilant and committed to this issue. The second essential pillar is the prosperity we want, it is to improve our living environment by building on climate change as a lever to change the paradigm of our development, our ability to meet the needs of our fellow citizens. This idea indeed that we must support innovation, strongly support this ambition, climate neutrality by 2050 and the strengthening of the 2030 targets that we decided a few weeks ago in the Council. Finally, the third point I want to highlight is the commitment to a Europe mobilised globally, international cooperation, measuring what our strengths are and working to correct our weaknesses. A more resilient Europe, a more robust Europe, is the call I want to make on this symbolic, important day: the inauguration of a new presidential term in the United States. We open our arms, we reach out, we know of course that there will be sometimes difficult or tumultuous debates, but we share the essentials. I thank you for being engaged in this parliamentary, democratic debate, you can count on the European Council to maintain this strategic commitment in the service of a fundamental alliance for our common future.

name: Katarina BARLEY
text: The debate is closed. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. " One of the most important events on the international stage recently was the swearing-in of Joe Biden as the 46th President of the United States, a country of great importance in terms of joint relations with the European Union. We look forward to working closely with the new President to further strengthen both the Polish-American Strategic Partnership and on many levels at European Union level. It is in our common interest to consolidate the strategic partnership in the security and defence dimension and to further develop cooperation in the economic, energy and energy security spheres. Europe and America need each other. Bearing in mind the role of the United States in the global political and economic system, I am convinced that we can and should now focus on the most serious challenges and threats to the international community, particularly the mastery of the Covid-19 pandemic and the reconstruction of economies, the promotion of human rights, the fight against disinformation and false narratives. European defence initiatives should remain complementary to and not displace NATO capabilities. It is therefore very important that all EU initiatives enable cooperation with NATO, especially with the United States, the United Kingdom and Norway. It is in our common interest to have a strong Commitment from the United States to Europe. I believe that we will successfully continue the existing and all new lines of cooperation.

name: Josianne CUTAJAR
text: in writing. – The 2020 US presidential election was historic for many reasons. Never have so many Americans cast their vote in the country’s history, in what may be viewed as a firm expression of disapproval for the misconducts of the Trump presidency. The outgoing administration has disregarded centuries of US_EU cooperation — one that helped bring peace to our own continent. President Biden has vowed to undo the wrongdoings of his predecessor, starting with the reinvigoration of the transatlantic relationship. A strong EU-US partnership means strengthening the international public good and common values, including democracy, security, human rights and gender equality. Biden has also promised to re-enter the Paris Agreement, bringing back to the table a player that can afford an enormous contribution towards decarbonising our world. A new US administration will also allow for new consultations on the benefits and threats posed by digitalisation. In particular, we expect the US to help us fight disinformation and hate speech — the plague of our century. This election was historic for many reasons, though one of them stands out. Kamala Harris’s election as the first woman VP is a landmark achievement in gender equality, setting the tone for many more to come.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "The 46th President of the United States, Joe Biden, is now hoping for a new beginning. It is a new opening after the difficult years of Donald Trump's presidency, which has made the tools of political struggle out of misinformation, fake news, sharing and exclusion. It is also a testament to the fact that democracy is resilient – resistant to hatred and lies.  But we can't be naïve – this resilience, if too strainy, can end. History brings us a lot of evidence in this case. Democracy must be fought every day, nurtured every day. It cannot be attacked or weakened.  Joe Biden's presidency is a hope for the United States to return to mainstream international politics in a constructive, not destructive, role. For the European Union and the world as a whole, America, with its constructive presence in international bodies, is extremely important. Today, for the first time, a woman will also serve as US Vice President. History is written before our eyes. I keep my fingers crossed for President Biden and for Vice President Harris. The United States deserved wise leadership.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The United States of America plays a key role in the global economic and political system What will happen there will sooner or later translate into much of the world. Therefore, the worrying situation in the US must be closely monitored. In recent weeks, we have witnessed events that should not have happened in a democratic state. I am referring to electoral irregularities or internet censorship. Here the President of the United States is already openly censored not only by internet companies, Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, but also by big TV stations. Corporations rule on what is true. We are seeing the process of large corporations taking over, including the so-called Big Tech, full of power on an unprecedented scale. This will inevitably result from denial of the values on which the US and Western democracy were built. If, on the other hand, we look objectively at Donald Trump's policies, we have to judge them positively. This was certainly the case from the point of view of the interests of the countries of Central and Eastern Europe Polish. Military, economic and energy ties have been strengthened. The US supported the Tri-Sea Initiative to provide a sustainable basis for the region's economic development. The initiative was set up as a forum for cooperation between 12 countries: Austria, Bulgaria, Croatia, Czech Republic, Estonia, Lithuania, Latvia, Polish, Romania, Slovakia, Slovenia and Hungary. I hope that Joe Biden will uphold these actions and commitments.

name: Gheorghe-Vlad NISTOR
text: in writing. – Dear colleagues, esteemed participants. It is with utmost pleasure that I welcome the inauguration of the 46th President of the United States of America, Joseph Biden. I hope that the auspices of his tenure will be favourable both to USA - EU relations, and also for our friends and allies all over the globe. The incoming administration’s messages are most encouraging and, even if this will not materialise in a return to the old order with which we were all accustomed, it will for sure represent a strengthening of our historic and, I emphasise, natural alliance. Even at the low points of our relationship, the US was a committed ally. We can again work together to restore and deepen relations and focus on mutual interests. The bilateral relationship must be built with the desideratum of restoring a true multilateral order, especially in these trying times for humanity and for the planet we inhabit. The responsibility is now, probably, much higher than it was during the Second World War and the ensuing Cold War era; we must now work together to actively protect our ideals, secure recovery and future prosperity and protect our planet.

name: Urmas PAET
text: Writing. – A new time has begun in US domestic and foreign policy. The assumptions for a rapid improvement in European-US relations during President Biden's tenure are very good. Rapid positive developments in the eu-US cooperation can be expected, for example, in the fight against climate change, where President Biden has already decided to rejoin the Paris climate agreement, as well as in trade relations. Surely Biden's presidency will also create a more positive atmosphere in NATO. Biden was also one of the supporters of Estonia's accession to NATO at the time. Estonia only has the EU-US to win from good relations.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing. – The inauguration of the new US president Joe Biden represents for EU an opportunity to relaunch the transatlantic cooperation, which has severely suffered in the last four years. Trump's unilateral action, withdrawals from treaties and international organisations often led to a divided and less stable society as well as deterioration of our EU-US relations. EU and US were the oldest and the most trusted allies. The recent events in Washington showed us how fragile democracy could be. Therefore, now more than ever, the US and the EU must act as partners and together rebuild the multilateral system based on our shared values of democracy, the rule of law and human rights. Only together we are more powerful to face the threats posed by extremists and populism that are challenging our democracies, tackle the emerging problems due to global pandemic, climate change and digitalisation and finally secure the peace, prosperity, security, freedom and human rights equality.

name: Mihai TUDOSE
text: in writing. – President Joe Biden is called upon to pull the US out of the crisis of extreme disunity and to halt the growing global imbalance. American society has reached a dangerous share of tension, after years of incitement to intolerance and violence. The Biden administration must close America's wounds. But also to set foot on the threshold of a world more turbulent than ever after the end of the Cold War. The U.S. repling gave way to the offensive of eastern imperialism. There is an urgent need to reweld the transatlantic relationship, in order to work closely together in the face of the geostrategic and economic challenges facing, increasingly, the democratic world. It has become apparent, under the pandemic accelerator, that it is imperative that we act together, the EU and the US, in a partnership of the force of the one who faced the dictatorships of the last century. We who have known in the East the horrors of communism understand well the stakes of the current attempt to reconfigure the balance of forces in the world. That is why, in the spirit of the solidarity provided for in Article 5 of the North Atlantic Treaty, it is time to state loudly the Euro-American will not allow any further steps forward to aggressive dictatorships - from their interference in our democratic processes and harmful initiatives like Nord Stream2, going as far as the military threat and even the use of force.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the presentation of the Programme of the Portuguese Presidency (2020/2928(SDR)).

name: António COSTA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President of the European Parliament, Madam President of the European Commission, ladies and gentlemen presidents of the political groups, Commissioners, ladies and gentlemen, with the COVID-19 pandemic Europe is experiencing its greatest post-war challenge. In less than a year families have been devastated by the loss of almost half a million human lives and we have been dragged into a devastating economic and social crisis across the 27 Member States. But this crisis has also proved the added value that the European Union is, in the access of all European citizens, on an equal footing, to the long-abid vaccine against COVID, in the joint and robust response to the economic and social crisis, in ensuring financial stability. I would like here to welcome the tireless work of the Commission, Parliament, the European Central Bank, Council President Charles Michel and the Croatian and German Presidencies in the European response to this dramatic crisis. The start of the vaccination process and the approval of the Multiannual Financial Framework and the Next Generation EU Programme open a door to hope. Portugal therefore assumes the Presidency of the Council at a decisive moment to set in motion, to implement, to implement the historic decisions we have taken in recent months. That's why we chose it as a motto: time to act: for a fair, green and digital recovery. A motto that sums up the three main priorities of the Portuguese Presidency: economic recovery, the development of the Social Pillar and the strengthening of the strategic autonomy of a Europe open to the world. The first condition of recovery is the success of the vaccination process. It is essential that we continue to work in coordination because we will only together overcome the virus, restoring full freedom of movement and the full potential of the internal market. But also the indispensable international solidarity for the eradication of the pandemic on a global scale, whether in our neighborhoods, on the African continent or in Latin America. At the same time, we must implement the instruments of economic and social recovery. On the one hand, the new Next Generation EU. This means that national parliaments must complete the ratification procedures for the Own Resources Decision, that this Parliament can vote on the regulation already agreed and that the 27 national recovery and resilience plans can be adopted. Because in order to overcome this crisis, we will only win it together throughout the Union. On the other hand, we must also start implementing the programmes of the new Multiannual Financial Framework, in particular those which, thanks to the determination of this European Parliament, have benefited from an important strengthening, such as Horizon Europe, EU4Health, or ERASMUS+.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the utmost attention that the fight against the pandemic requires us all does not allow us to neglect the strategic challenges we had and we still face. That is why the European recovery must be based on the drivers of the climate and digital transition. We're in a health emergency, but we're still in a climate emergency. We have a planet to protect and we can't afford to waste any more time. It is therefore urgent to implement the European Ecological Pact, from the outset by adopting the new Climate Law, which I take as one of our main political objectives. We are ready for the work we have left with you, ladies and gentlemen, to get a political agreement from this Parliament as soon as possible. This is indeed the decisive decade, which will require greater effort and ambition to achieve our commitment to achieve carbon neutrality in 2050. But this is also the decade of Digital Europe. A day without betting on digital is another day behind in this demanding global competition in which Europe has to be on the front line. In this sense, we will pay particular attention to the new Digital Services Package which the Commission has just presented and which offers us key legislative instruments for the protection of individual rights and democratic sovereignty and to bring greater competition to the digital market, stimulating empreendorism and creativity. In a moment, recovery cannot be limited to responding to the needs of the present with sets of stimuli for the conjuncture. The recovery must be based on investments and reforms that will allow us to emerge from this crisis more resilient, greener, more digital than we were before this crisis. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, climate and digital transitions are essential, undeferred and exciting social change. But I am very concerned about small and medium-sized enterprises and millions of European workers. Companies fear losing competitiveness by not being able to keep up with the investment effort that modernization requires. Workers fear for the future of their own job, new forms of work and the virtualization of social rights that have been hard won over the years. Therefore, in line with the European Parliament's report "A Strong Social Europe for Fair Transitions", our second priority is to implement the Social Pillar of the European Union as a basis for Europeanconfidence in Europe's ability to lead climate and digital transitions. We need to strengthen qualifications – new skills, upskilling, reskilling – so that our citizens are actors and not victims of these transitions. We need to invest more in innovation to strengthen the competitiveness of our businesses and we need to strengthen social protection to ensure that no one is left behind. The central event of our Presidency will be precisely the Social Summit, which we will organise in May, in the city of Porto, with the social partners, civil society, the Presidents of the Institutions and the Member States. The main objective of this Summit is to give a strong political impetus to the Action Plan that the Commission will present in March and which materialises the ambition expressed by our citizens to implement the 20 General Principles proclaimed in Gothenburg in 2017. There's no time to waste here either. Here too is time to act. The development of the Social Pillar is fundamental to giving confidence to Europeans that the changes we are living in are not a threat, but, they can and must be, an opportunity. The populism that undermines our democracies feeds on fear and realizing the Social Pillar is therefore the best vaccine against inequalities, fear and populism. Finally, our third priority will, as I have already said, strengthen the strategic autonomy of a European Union open to the world. As this pandemic has already been evidenced, Europe cannot be entirely dependent on the supply of essential goods on the part of third parties. We must therefore strengthen our strategic autonomy. This is a very demanding debate because it involves industrial policy, competition policy and trade policy. But that cannot mean either a protectionist drift or the myrific promotion of "European champions", wasting the enormous advantage of the capillarity of an economic system based on small and medium-sized enterprises and a system of research, development and innovation distributed across 27 Member States. Finally, strengthening strategic autonomy also means affirming Europe as a global actor, valuing, as our citizens are asked, the social and environmental standards that distinguish and distinguish us. We naturally want to continue to strengthen neighbourhood partnerships to the east and south, and the strategic partnership with the African continent and our transatlantic relations with the United Kingdom and the United States of America.  And on this day when President Joe Biden will take office, I cannot fail to address the best of his mandate and to mention the need to relaunch ever closer relations with the United States and also not forget that the United Kingdom, a new neighbour but an old Ally, will always remain a great partner of the European Union. The main hallmark of our presidency for the Indo-Pacific region will be to promote a closer and more strategic partnership between the world's two largest democracies, the European Union and India. We will host a European Union-India Summit also in the city of Porto, focusing on cooperation on digital, trade and investment, pharmaceuticals, science and space. One last word on a central issue of Europe's relationship with the world: migration. We are aware of the different existing sensitivities, but migrations are a reality since there are human beings on the planet. And so it will continue to be as long as the human species can survive. It is also undeniable that its management requires common European action. We must therefore continue work on the new Pact for Migration and Asylum, trying to strike the right balance between its internal and external dimensions, without forgetting legal migration. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is time to act in the vaccination process, it is time to act on economic and social recovery, it is time to act to develop the Social Pillar, it is time to act to strengthen the strategic autonomy of a Union open to the world, but it is also time to act for the future of Europe. And that is why we need the Conference on the Future of Europe as a forum for debate between Member States and with our citizens about what we want to build together as a Union in the future. The Conference should focus on the anxieties and anxieties of citizens and not on the issues of the institutions. The Conference should be policy-oriented and the common responses to the strategic challenges we have to face in a world less Eurocentric. As the Presidency of the Council we will do everything we can to make sure that the Conference can be launched as soon as possible so that we can conclude it with an open and enlightening debate. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let me conclude.  It was the values of Europe that brought Portugal to Europe. It was the desire to consolidate the regained democracy, to be able to share a common area of freedom, security and peace, prosperity, after 48 years of dictatorship, the longest in Europe of the 20th century. , we will continue with ongoing processes in this area. The challenges ahead are immense. But on the basis of the work done by the Commission, Parliament and the Council, I believe that we are now all better prepared to overcome this pandemic, to overcome this unprecedented crisis and to build together a better future. That is why we assume the Presidency with a very clear motto: Time to act, for a fair, green and digital recovery. (Applause)

name: Ursula von der Leyen
text: présidente de la Commission. – Cher Monsieur le Président, cher Premier ministre, cher António, Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, j’ai eu le privilège de commencer cette nouvelle année par une visite à Lisbonne. Cette ville de renouvellement et de nouveau départ était le lieu idéal pour discuter de nos priorités politiques avec le gouvernement et le parlement portugais. Une fois encore, cher António, merci beaucoup pour votre hospitalité. Mesdames et Messieurs les députés, c’est dans les périodes de grand bouleversement que notre tissu social est le plus mis à l’épreuve. Nous le constatons en Europe et dans le reste du monde, les évolutions démographiques, sociétales et technologiques sont allées plus vite que notre capacité à répondre aux attentes des gens. Pour trop de gens, c’est une source de frustration et de division. Mais leurs attentes n’ont pas changé. Their expectations have not changed. They want jobs for a decent living, they want fairness, equality and social protection in times of need. They want to know that if they work hard and do their fair share they will not lose out. These are the unwritten rules and norms that make up our social market economy.  But while expectations have not changed, society and economy have, and our current rules are based on old realities. They do not entirely reflect any more the speed and the scale of transformations we are embarking on. So, as we overcome the pandemic, as we prepare necessary reforms, and as we speed up the twin green and digital transitions, I believe it is time to also adapt the social rule book. A rule book which ensures solidarity between the generations, a rule book that rewards the entrepreneurs who take care of their employees, which focuses on jobs and opens up opportunities, which puts skills, innovation and social protection on an equal footing. The good news is that with Next Generation EU we have all chosen to recover from this crisis together, rather than scrap for ourselves and widen social disparities.  With our SURE programme we have shown our commitment to protect jobs and workers. This has helped provide EUR 90 billion to support employees and employers in 18 Member States of the European Union, but there’s much more to do. This is why we will update our industrial strategy to make sure we can create quality jobs in the post-pandemic world, because the green digital and fair recovery must be a jobs recovery.  In the next month we will address some of the underlying societal trends. In March, indeed, we will bring forward our action plan on the European pillar of social rights, and I’m looking forward to the social summit in Porto in May where we can send a united message, along with social partners, with trade unions, with employer unions and the EU institutions. I want to thank you, António, for your leadership on this.  Honourable Members, as we all know, any recovery depends on overcoming the pandemic. I will not repeat what you already heard yesterday in your debate on the vaccine strategy, but I want to say this. Staying united at 27 on vaccines was the best choice. It was Europe at its best. And if anyone has any doubts, I simply urge you to look at the list of the top 50 countries in the world who have vaccinated the highest percentage of their population. All 27 Member States are on that list. Without a common EU approach, how many Member States would have been on that list? Without a common EU approach how many Member States would not have been able to negotiate a single contract? What would it have meant for our Union if one Member State had vaccinated almost all of its citizens before others have even started. But by working together the Commission was able to secure the broadest portfolio of vaccines in the world. As you know, this gives us access to 2.3 billion doses and this is more than enough for Europe, and our neighbourhood.  And a word on our neighbourhood. We need to support them to start vaccinating their front-line workers, from the Western Balkans to the Eastern Partnership, to our African partners in the south. This is why the Commission is proposing an EU vaccine-sharing mechanism. This will channel vaccines either directly or through the COVAX Facility, in which the EU is the largest contributor, to low and middle-income countries. In total, Team Europe has already provided almost EUR 40 billion of support to our partners since last April, and we need to show the same leadership when it comes to vaccines.  I know some will ask how we can talk about sharing vaccines with others when we are not all vaccinated ourselves. To them I say: this is not only a matter of solidarity, but also a matter of self-interest. We will only come out of this pandemic together. This is true for our health. This is true for our economies. This is true for our supply chains, and this is also true for our geopolitical credibility and influence. Those who show support to their partners with doses and deeds will not be forgotten. But those who do not will be remembered, but for very different reasons, and I am determined that Europe must be on the right side of history and humanity and I know this House feels the same way too. Honourable members,  Es ist ein Wettlauf gegen die Zeit. Wir sind mit beispielloser Geschwindigkeit vorangekommen. Was wir in zehn Monaten bei der Impfstoffentwicklung geschafft haben, braucht in der Regel zehn Jahre. Selbstverständlich haben alle Staaten weltweit auf der Strecke mit Schwierigkeiten zu kämpfen – sei es bei der Produktion, beim Vertrieb, bei der Logistik. Aber das werden wir überwinden, und wir werden das rasch tun. Aber auch hier gilt, dass es nur gelingt, wenn wir gemeinsam handeln. Ich werde morgen auf der Videokonferenz mit den Staats- und Regierungschefs Kernpunkte ansprechen: Wir müssen schneller werden beim Impfen. Das Tempo in Europa ist noch viel zu unterschiedlich. Wir müssen die Unternehmen mehr dabei unterstützen, die Produktionskapazität zu erhöhen, und das können wir auch, und das ist schon auf dem Weg. Und wir müssen die Ausbreitung der neuen Varianten des Virus präzise verfolgen. The spread of these variants is a cause for severe concern. This is indeed a race against time. The EU urgently needs to speed up genome sequencing. Currently only one Member State is testing above 1% of positive tests, and many have not even yet started. This makes it very difficult to identify the progress of the variants or to detect potential new ones. We should aim for every Member State to scale up sequencing to 5% to 10% of the positive tests. And I know not every country has the capacity to do so, but our agency, ECDC, does and every Member State has access to that capacity, but only two so far have used it. My last point is about preserving our single market. The message is clear. The blanket closure of borders in this situation makes no sense. They harm the functioning of the single market and they are not as effective as targeted measures, and this is why we need a common approach to test, trace, travel and borders, and the Commission has put everything on the table to ensure that we can do that.  Honourable Members, all of this will take continued efforts from us all and I’m delighted that we will have the Portuguese Presidency alongside us to make it happen. Together we will overcome the pandemic and, as the Portuguese Presidency so aptly says in its motto, it’s time to deliver. (Applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, a warm welcome to the new Portuguese Presidency and a warm welcome to Prime Minister Costa. It is good to have you here in the European Parliament.  The Portuguese people know how important a united Europe is. The Portuguese people know and believe that to be a European is not losing anything but winning a lot. Having the history of Portugal in mind, I think it's obvious that you are looking beyond the horizon, you are looking for new things, and you are not afraid of the unknown. This spirit is exactly what Europe needs now, the spirit of an explorer. So welcome, it's good to have you here.  I would, of course, like to start by referring to the issue of COVID, because we will continue to be concerned about all this in the next six months under the Portuguese Presidency. Historical crisis, and in the start of 2021, we show that we are better than we were in 2020 at the beginning of the crisis. On the part of the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, I would like to fully support the approach of Ursula von der Leyen. We do not want first and second class Europeans on this continent. We are all the same and had the chance to access the vaccine at the same time. If there is now criticism of the European Union: last week, in a conversation with the CEO of BioNTech, I was able to experience and learn that BioNTech received EU funding 15 years ago. Without this EU money, BioNTech's research successes would not exist. We Europeans have made it possible for us to give an answer so quickly. We should be proud of that. Now it is necessary to overcome the supply bottlenecks, to really vaccinate the vaccination cans provided, that the authorities on the ground implement this. We need proof of vaccination for the European Union that there is no fragmentation in proof of vaccination, and we should be proud of what has been achieved. This should motivate us to show the same ambitions in the fight against Alzheimer's and cancer, to move forward as quickly as we did at Corona. The second thing that concerns us, of course, is economic development. The People's Republic of China had 2% economic growth last year – an increase of 2% – and we Europeans almost 8% were down. The weights in this world are being fundamentally redistributed, and that is why 2021 must be a year when we talk about jobs, jobs, jobs, about economic issues. We support the priority of a social Europe, and the most important thing in a social Europe is that our people have jobs, that the young generation in particular has jobs. A new lost generation must be avoided at all costs. That is the idea of a social market economy, and in this context, Prime Minister, I would like to emphasise that trade is important for Europe. As Portuguese Prime Minister, you know the importance of contacts with our South American friends: there is an agreement on the table with Mercosur, and we now need a Portuguese Government that shows us the momentum that these agreements are right and important. Last but not least, 2020 is the year of the crisis, and 2021 is hopefully the year of departure, and that is why I hope that you can start with the conference on the future of Europe, that you will get off to a good start. The time for crisis management should be over, we should now talk about the future of Europe, and the Lisbon Treaty shows that we are currently working on Portuguese roots. If Portugal now opens the new chapter, it would be a great signal. All the best for the Presidency!

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Mr. Prime Minister Costa, we welcome you to the Portuguese Presidency. We go through exceptional circumstances with a pandemic that has altered our lives and caused devastating consequences at the global economic level. In these months we have seen how the European Union has reacted to coordinate national responses and avoid harmful competition between us. We have managed to approve an ambitious budget and a recovery plan. The question now is whether all citizens will also notice this shared effort we have made.  The Union is an area of prosperity and social protection, and we are proud of our model, but let us be honest: it is not the same for everyone. And, in recent years, the gap between higher and lower wages has grown. Not to mention unemployment, especially young people, energy poverty or the lack of decent housing. The pandemic has exacerbated these inequalities and puts us in front of the mirror as Europeans. Why does the Recovery Fund set a minimum of 37% for green investments or 20% for digital transition and does not refer to a threshold for social spending and health systems? The Portuguese Presidency wants to address this deficit and, therefore, it is crucial to seize the window of opportunity. The COVID crisis makes clear the need to act and we have the experience of António Costa to ensure the right leadership for this historic moment. The Presidency's motto could not be more accurate: "Time to act: for a fair, ecological and digital recovery". Without a doubt, it is time to accelerate our transition to a more sustainable model by leveraging new technologies. But let's not forget that recovery, first and foremos say, has to be fair. The money we are going to invest should help narrow the gaps. More than that, the time has come to reform economic governance so that the social pillar is just as important as economic growth, and in that we have much to learn from a country like Portugal. We should suspend fiscal rules until 2023 and use this time to reform them, introducing, for example, the golden rule for social investment.  One of the key moments will be the Porto Social Summit in May. There we must put forward an action plan with clear strategy, with measures and with timetable, and they have the cooperation of my political group. We are concerned about the lack of progress on issues such as child guarantee or unemployment insurance, two proposals to which the European Commission committed itself. We ask the Portuguese Presidency to include, in addition, in its priorities the creation of a European health response mechanism in order to advance the Health Union.  This social dimension will also be reflected – I am sure – in a special commitment to introduce the gender dimension into all policies, and also the fight against all kinds of discrimination. And let us not forget an important issue: the new Pact on Migration and Asylum, which needs a mechanism to realize the principle of solidarity and ensure that our migration policy lives up to our values, remains pending. Finally, I hope that the Portuguese Presidency will be able to unlock the start of the Conference on the Future of Europe. We have to act with responsibility and unlock this situation. Let us not deceive ourselves: the important thing about this Conference is not the familiar faces, but the voices of millions of European citizens who want to lead us on the path of Europe to be built.

name: Dacian CIOLOŞ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Madam President, Prime Minister, welcome and good luck for your presidency. Your success will also be ours, you have all the beginnings to succeed and I know that Portugal, given its history and geographical position, knows very well what the added value of the European Union is and knows how to add value to the European project. The work we have done in recent months is enormous. Europe has made progress under the pressure of this pandemic, it is true, progress that many thought impossible until a year ago. But we are only at the beginning. You take, Prime Minister, the rotating presidency of the Council at a time when we need to transform the test: we must make 2021 the year of rebirth and for that, there is no miracle, we must overcome the pandemic and for this every European must have quick access to a safe and effective vaccine. Congratulations to the President for what the Commission has achieved, but you know that we are still counting on you to coordinate the vaccination campaign. But we also need to take care of our economic and social fabric, I know that is your priority. The historic recovery plan on which we have agreed must be put in place as soon as possible and we must be prepared to do more if necessary. The recovery must be green, digital, fair and forward-looking. It will therefore be our common responsibility to ensure that each government implements the strategic reforms and investments necessary for European money to contribute to the development of a new post-COVID world. Governments should not use European money to infuse without ensuring long-term and structural positive effects.  We must therefore rebuild, innovate and transform, building on the Green Pact and its variations such as the circular economy or the mechanism of carbon inclusion at borders. But also by relying on the digital agenda. As you know, there is an urgent need to take back control of our destiny in this area, it is an economic and social issue and the European Commission has put an ambitious project on the table.  But this rebirth will only really see the light of day if the rule of law is respected from day one. What is the point of investing if we are not even able to guarantee that these funds will not be misappropriated. This is an existential question for the Union. It is about preserving our values, but it is also a question of efficiency.  Beyond that, our Union should build a common asylum and migration policy: a major issue for the coming months, as well as that of our relations with our eastern and Mediterranean neighbourhood and the Western Balkans. I know that our neighbourhood expects a clear vision of the European Union on these projects. Prime Minister, nothing is pre-defined or pre-written. Even though we are still in the middle of a storm, I am convinced that Europe must raise its sails ever higher and maintain its course or risk drifting away. The contours of the post-COVID world depend entirely on our commitment, perseverance and the demands of our ambition. More than ever we are today the authors of our own destiny and this fate will be even better defined if we can unlock this conference on the future of Europe and I am convinced that with the Portuguese Presidency, in collaboration with Parliament, this will be possible.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I should like to welcome Mr Costa to the European Parliament. We have just finished six months of the German Presidency, which have been painted as the success of a European vision on the multiannual financial framework, the Recovery Fund and the rule of law, with Angela Merkel appearing to have pursued brussels' interests, rather than her own interests.  But then we found that the reality in practice was quite different, and while we were committed in words to having a European dimension to crisis management, above all, some states were doing their own thing and negotiating bilaterally to have additional doses of vaccines. Let me make it quite clear that I do not want to attack these states for this legitimate choice, but simply to point out that, in practice, the national interest ultimately comes before the European interest. With you, Mr Costa, I would also like to reflect on what has been the European Union's response to the crisis, now that we have more or less all the cards on the table. The first point I would like to make with you is the fact that the only non-political institution of the European Union is the one that has really acted quickly and effectively, the European Central Bank, and this clearly raises a subject of democratic accountability, which cannot be ignored. Then I would like to turn to the pillar of this answer, which is the Recovery Plan, the European response to the crisis, to make some reflections with you and ask you a few questions. The first point concerns clarity, now that we have the cards on the table, on what the Recovery Plan is: we have discovered that it is European debt, so it is a debt that the European Union will assume on its shoulders; we have discovered that the first money will probably come more than a year after the outbreak of the crisis; we have discovered that, in order to repay this debt, the citizens of Europe will have to bear European taxes and we have discovered that there are conditions, conditions that, in my opinion, run both with what is the Costa Presidency's programme and with what is the vision, for example on certain rules, which the European Parliament has expressed across the board – as my colleague from the Socialist Group said.  The Stability and Growth Pact needs to be reviewed, it is old, it is no longer relevant and I believe that you, Mr Costa, can agree with this, and so I would like to ask ourselves whether we, on the one hand, say that this pact needs to be changed and that the Commission has undertaken to review it and, on the other hand, in the Regulation on the Recovery Fund we write in stone that , in exchange for that money, we must respect the Stability and Growth Pact, binding ourselves to these rules that we must change for the next fifteen or twenty years. I would therefore also like to understand how these conditionalities are combined with the programme of the Portuguese Presidency and, above all, what you mean by social pillar. I would like to end by giving you a good luck, because the next six months will be very difficult and you will have to implement this, which is a response, albeit belatedly, to the current crisis. I believe that we need the courage to change, the courage to look back, the courage to understand that the approach we have used is completely wrong, the courage to deny even those wrong choices. I believe that without a revolution of common sense and common sense, Europe will not be able to emerge from this crisis.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome to the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, on the environmental, social and economic level, I would even say geopolitically, Portugal's priorities for its Presidency of the Council are part of the general dynamics of the von der Leyen Commission, which has placed a green pact for Europe at the heart of its programme.  So, on the face of it, we would like to follow you with our eyes closed, but, as the saying goes, the devil hides in the details. And there is one - and it is a great size, Prime Minister - that totally contradicts the beautiful ambitions displayed. I am talking about your stubborn desire to ratify at all costs this relic of the 20th century that is the draft free trade treaty between the European Union and Mercosur. An obstinacy that you share with your Spanish colleague Pedro Sanchez, a socialist just like you.  And now we're not following you, but then not there at all! This project, if ratified, would be a disaster for climate and biodiversity because it will increase deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions. It would be a disaster for our farmers, who are already burdened by an endless race for productivity and facing new unfair competition tomorrow, at a time when suicides are already decimating the agricultural world. It would be a disaster for the workers there, who would suffer massive job losses in the industrial sector, but also for the environmentalists, who today already pay with their lives to defend this common good that is the Amazon.  Finally, it would be a health disaster, firstly because our plates will be further invaded by pesticide-laden food products, most of which are banned in Europe, but also because massive deforestation coupled with intensive animal breeding promotes the transmission of diseases, such as COVID-19, to humans. All for what? Growth, you might say. Let's talk about it: 0.1 percentage points more GDP for the European Union and the same less for Mercosur. No, the real goal is to further increase the profit margins of multinationals by putting ever more pressure on the planet and the living, including humans. And this, at a time when our planet and our societies undermined by inequality are already on the verge of rupture. Prime Minister, this treaty is neither done nor done. And it is not by accosting him a little statement here or a protocol there that he would become virtuous. Mr Prime Minister, you may put lipstick on a pig, it remains a pig. For too long, the majority of European socialists, in the name of growth and employment, have swallowed up the myth that what is good for multinationals and for those they enrich is good for our societies. I'm telling you, wake up! Prime Minister, if you take seriously the principle that none of our policies can make the environmental and social situation of the planet worse, this famous 'do no harm principle', you must relegate the treaty with Mercosur, at least as now negotiated, to the dustbin of history. In contrast to the levelling down it has produced so far, it is time to make our trade policy the central instrument of a virtuous emulation in favour of ever-higher social, environmental, health, fiscal and even democratic standards.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: On the other: The ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Welcome here, Prime Minister Costa. Believe me, you have to do. There's work to get your teeth into.  I would like to highlight three points. EU recovery fund. What do you really mean by the Solidarity Fund? For example, Italy receives 9 billion for health care, 17 billion for gender equality and the vast majority, 75 billion, goes to climate change. What does this have to do with Corona? After the United States and Germany, Italy has the largest gold reserve. Maybe you could have used just a little bit of that reserve? Why should Swedish taxpayers be involved in funding this? To spend EUR 75 billion from the Corona Fund for climate change change in Italy – is it solidarity with the Swedish taxpayers? You can call it whatever you want: Coronafund, nextgeneration fund. I call it that Sweden is an ATM for Southern Europe.  Next thing I want to take up vaccination sessions and I hope you will make an effort there. Will free travel in the future only be possible for the holders of one? So we're going to divide people into categories now? This is a frightening example of how the corona crisis is being exploited to create a federal state.  Finally – freedom of speech. I see nothing in portugal's programme on this. Big Tech companies are the new powers. They are the ones who decide who can speak. It is the law that limits what is illegal or not to express on social media, not the political preferences or discretion of platform owners. And the right to have an account should be the guiding principle.  Good luck Portugal! I hope you can make an impact.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Mr President, Prime Minister Costa, welcome here to the European Parliament. 13,000 job cuts at Airbus, 10,000 at IBM, 2,300 at Michelin, 2,000 at Sodexho. I could continue to list this sordid list of social plans for hours, as the social crisis is raging all over Europe. Companies that lay off, self-employed people strangled by debts, unemployment exploding: this is the terrible situation in Europe at the beginning of the year. That must be the top priority of your presidency. The recession has a good back for crisis profiteers who receive public aid without any social consideration. So yes, to distribute dividends to their shareholders, some of the multinationals did not hesitate for a moment, but when it comes to saving jobs, there is no one left. Take, for example, Sanofi, four billion euros in dividends and 1,700 jobs cut. Behind these figures that give the whirlwind, these are so many lives turned upside down, worried faces, disoriented families who sink into poverty, sink even deeper into precariousness. In Italy, 3.7 million people have used food aid, in France it is an increase 30%, in Barcelona the meals distributed have increased 20-fold. Colleagues, in one of the richest areas in the world, people are hungry. Misery affects all segments of our society and it is even more powerfully affecting young people. Already ignored, they find themselves completely abandoned with this crisis. In France, 50% of students have difficulty eating properly, a quarter have had suicidal thoughts, when they do not already act, like these two students in Lyon. An entire generation is sacrificed and calling for help, but our governments refuse to listen to it.  So the Portuguese Presidency said it would make the social crisis its priority. On behalf of our Group of the Left in the European Parliament, I would like to make you a simple but meaningful proposal, which is fraught with meaning. Let us declare a social state of emergency. Our Parliament recently proclaimed a climate emergency in the face of the destruction of our planet. Let us react with the same intensity in the face of the tsunami of poverty which risks taking everything in its path. Let us declare a social state of emergency for young people in the galley, for people in poverty, let us declare a state of social emergency.

name: Márton GYÖNGYÖSI
text: – Mr President, tasks and challenges facing the Portuguese EU Presidency are clear. But from a long list let me just highlight two which require special attention and without which our European Union cannot last – and thank you, Mr Costa, for elaborating on both.  First, solidarity and granting of benefits of economic cooperation to all Member States i.e. strengthening the social pillar, closing the wage gap across our continent and between the periphery and the core countries, we just cannot afford to have winners and losers of European cooperation. Second, strengthening the rule of law and democratic institutions by implementing the rule-of-law mechanism adopted here recently.  But first and foremost, the Portuguese Presidency should depart from its predecessors’ bad habit of making decisions behind closed doors just in the interests of a few Member States and particular interests. There is nothing more damaging and disengaging than this practice. The EU must be transparent and work for the benefit of its Member States, all 27 of them.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Mr President, Prime Minister António Costa, Madam President of the Commission, the Portuguese Presidency begins today on the sign of deep regret and a window of hope. Window of hope for the vaccination campaign, deep regret for the number of deaths in Europe, now tragic also in Portugal. In the person of the Prime Minister I pay tribute to all of them and their families, I thank the health professionals with an emotional thank you. Speaking of health. Do you have any plans to coordinate government responses to restriction measures? If at Christmas one had opted for coordination and if he had followed the French, German and Italian examples, the numbers in Portugal would not be so tragic. Now you're willing to bet on that coordination? Speaking of economics, with the terrible effects of this vacancy, will you propose an emergency program that supports the sectors most affected in the short term, youth employment, tourism, catering?  As for the Recovery Fund, what will you do to ensure that the money is well spent? This is, moreover, one of the functions of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, to combat fraud and corruption of European funds. I will not ask you questions about this because there is an urgent debate which, at the request of the government, was postponed from yesterday to today.  So since you're here, I'm going to challenge you. Represent the Council in person in this debate. It is the place to explain itself and I am pleased that, after all, it has converted to the Conference on the Future of Europe after devaluing it in December 2019 and throughout the first half of 2020. Finally, a personal note. We who have known and lived together for so many years, with respect, affability and democratic sense. It is in the House of European democracy of which you have been a member. Here, eye to eye, do you really think that Members of all parties and all Member States have aligned themselves in an international conspiracy against Portugal, the State and the Portuguese? Do you really have the courage to repeat here that this was set up in front of everyone? Believe me, PSD Members will always be on the side of Portugal and Europe. I will work for Portugal and the Portuguese government to succeed, but I will work as usual, without fear of threats, without fear of intimidation.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, it is in difficult times that the character and capacity of peoples, peoples and institutions is revealed. As Portuguese and as a European I am proud of the lucidity and courage with which the Portuguese Presidency has defined and is putting its priorities into practice. A pragmatic definition, because when people are suffering, as so many are suffering from the health, economic and social impacts of the pandemic, pragmatism is the first of the principles.   The answer to the needs of citizens is a humanistic duty and the antidote to populism. And we know, even from experience in Portugal's internal politics, that there are those who do not hesitate to propagate false narratives to weaken the ability to comply. And that is what Mr Rangel did in his speech.    In this afternoon's debate everything will be clarified again about the appointment of the European Prosecutor by Portugal and I hope that you will then have the humility to apologise. But we will. We will be able to take full advantage of the union's new cycle of solidarity cooperation, implementing the common vaccination strategy, advancing the progressive rooting of a health union, deepening the social dimension of the energy tradition and digital achievement and, at the Porto Social Summit, making room for new concrete measures on inequalities, new precariousness and dignity. We'll go further.  Today, a new cycle in global geopolitics begins with the inauguration of the new American Administration. It is the time for a new multilateralism with more strategic autonomy. The Summit with India, the digital tie-up to South America, the special attention to relations with Africa, the new cycle of transatlantic relations mark the first steps of the European Union in this new cycle. Prime Minister, the connection of the EllaLink submarine cable to Sines, from South America to Sines, is, moreover, a sign of the clear perception that no strategy to combat climate change or inclusive digitisation will be successful if it is only European. The strategies will be all the more European the more they can be global at the same time.

name: Malik AZMANI
text: – Madam President, I would like to welcome Prime Minister Costa to this House. Leaving the turmoil of 2020 behind us, we look forward into 2021. With the start of vaccination programmes throughout the European Union, there’s finally some light at the end of the tunnel, and that gives us hope. But at the same time, we are not there yet. But together, as President von der Leyen mentioned, we can get through this. I believe that only together can we get through this. With the start of 2021, we also welcome the new Presidency. Although the COVID—19 health crisis will keep dominating the agenda, we also have to look beyond this crisis. Renew Europe shares the ambitions of the Portuguese Presidency to deliver on key issues, such as the green and digital transition, a strong recovery of the European economy, strengthening the role of the EU in a turbulent world, and making headway with the Conference on the Future of Europe. We also underline the priority to make progress on the new agreement on migration and asylum. Europe needs a comprehensive migration policy that looks internally at the challenges we face, but crucially, also with an external focus. We need to have good solid partnerships with countries of origin and transit to address and tackle our illegal and, above all, dangerous routes of migration to the European Union. How is this Presidency going to keep pressure on this process? With the digital transition moving forward, we must not forget to respect and defend the fundamental rights of users, the protection of our democracy and ensure a level playing field for our businesses. The Digital Services Act is a matter of priority for Renew, and my message to the Portuguese Presidency is that we now need to deliver and create a safer digital space.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, some of the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency of the Union are interesting, others much more worrying, raising fears, in particular, of the risk of internet censorship and restriction of digital freedoms. On the contrary, recent events in the United States should encourage us to fight against the grip of the GAFA and their desire to privatize civil liberties outright. On the implementation of the European recovery plan: while support for our devastated economies is obviously vital, I remain dubious about the recovery plan itself, which is ignored, including funding, and whose expenditure by the Member States will once again be subject to the close control of the European Commission. All pretexts are good for more Brussels centralisation, even though bureaucratic rigidity, lack of anticipation and lack of agility have characterized the European institutions throughout the health crisis.  With this recovery plan, my country, France will receive a total of 35 billion euros less than what it will pay even though we are one of the countries most affected. No doubt this is again a great victory for Emmanuel Macron on the European stage. The Portuguese Presidency also wants to deepen the single market. But what this market needs, before it deepens, is its protection! We must fight against unfair competition, we must re-industrialize in order to gain independence on the world stage. We need better food security for our nations and health for our peoples. We must increase controls and impose compliance on our standards on those who want to sell on European soil. The Mercosur agreement would be a real betrayal for our farmers, it would also be dangerous for our fellow citizens, it would finally be, and you know, disastrous for the environment. Portugal, a great country of European conquerors and explorers, should lead the way to the independence, power and influence of our civilization and nations rather than being mired in the old globalist dogmas whose application leads to our decommissioning today and threatens us with extinction tomorrow.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, I’m happy to see on the Portuguese Presidency programme several references on the need to improve democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in the European Union. However, to be honest it leaves me a little puzzled seeing these commitments, but at the same time not seeing any real progress to overcome serious situations that we are currently having over these matters. I’m sure you would agree that it is untenable that a Member State has been keeping politicians and civil society activists in jail or exile for more than three years now for supporting a demographic vote in Catalonia. This is a situation that simply cannot hold any longer and which indeed contradicts EU values. Therefore, I’m asking you, Prime Minister, as holder of the Presidency of the Council, to encourage the Spanish Government to take, during this semester, clear steps towards dialogue with Catalonia, to engage in political negotiations with the Catalan Government and to find a solution for our pro-independence leaders, which should be based on an amnesty law.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, I noticed a certain irony. Italy has received so much money from its multi-year budget with over EUR 200 billion that its coalition partners in the Italian government have been so fighting that it has been in crisis. I thought the relief fund would provide stability. But perhaps Italy has received too much money.
