The President of the Italian Central Bank, Mr Visco, said in Elsevier last year that Italy – and I quote – 'does not need money, but reforms'. Italian fishermen lose around EUR 100 billion a year because of a lack of VAT collection. Italy receives EUR 85 billion from the €750 billion Corona aid fund. The Netherlands receives very little, but it does guarantee 43 billion in case countries are unable to repay the money borrowed by the Commission. The Netherlands is therefore an ATM.  Perhaps the best way to solve the Italian government crisis is to forf out a large part of that EUR 200 billion. Less money means less fighting. The Netherlands is also in crisis and can therefore use its money perfectly itself.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, we will not bring to this plenary national debates which only reveal the absolute absence of a national and European agenda of a right that only clings to cases and does not debate the country's priorities or Europe's priorities.  But we regret that there is no clear intention in the Portuguese Presidency document to discuss what the future of economic governance in Europe will be, particularly in the face of the increasingly clear intentions of the European right, and, after a brief interlude to support economic recovery, initiate adjustment programmes, pressure on national governments to withdraw support for the economy , a policy that our country knows very well, which has had catastrophic consequences and which the Portuguese Government should contribute to combating through the Presidency of the European Union. I regret that this debate will not be opened during the next semester and that our Presidency does not help to change economic governance rules that do not serve the European Union at all. I also think that a Presidency that gives so much prominence to the social issue, even announcing the proposal for the Social Summit, should also give a very important emphasis to labour issues in the context of social issues and this unfortunately does not happen and is unfortunately consistent with what has been the Portuguese Government's policy of not reversing the changes to the troika's time labour legislation. Finally, a presidency that wants to have the climate at the centre cannot have as one of its priorities to persist in the ecological attack which is the free trade agreement with Mercosur, which is a sword that hangs over the Amazon and on the ecological balance on a global scale. This agreement must be abandoned and the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union would be an excellent time to do so.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, a year and a half ago, the 5-Star Movement was decisive in saving Europe from the abyss of nationalism by voting for you, Mr von der Leyen, for an ambitious and forward-looking political project. With the same conviction today, as the 5-Star Movement, we welcome the programme of the Portuguese Presidency, which sets out a series of priorities for European citizens that coincide with those that the Italian Government has set itself for the Presidency of the G20, as evidence of political continuity and common actions that we can carry out together to address the current pandemic crisis at European and international level. From ethical and anthropocentric digitalization, to the acceleration of the green transition, to the completion of the social pillar, what were the themes of a movement born among the people for the people today are heritage and destination of our continent. Mr Costa, we call on your Presidency to promote real change and to propose a revision of the Stability Pact, so that the resources made available by next generation EU can really generate an economic recovery that is as expansive as possible in the long term. We consistently say that we support the European project according to the founding values, because there will be no real progress unless it is for all citizens.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister Costa, welcome to the European Parliament. Portugal is holding the Presidency of the Council of the European Union for the fourth time, and whenever Portugal held the Presidency in the past, it was linked to important moments for the further development of the European Union. It was the Portuguese Presidency in 1992 when the Maastricht Treaty was signed, negotiated during the Dutch Presidency, signed during the Portuguese Presidency. The 2007 Treaty of Lisbon: negotiated, agreed, and signed under the Portuguese Presidency. It became fundamental law for all of us, for the European Union. And the Portuguese Presidency in the year 2000 marked decisive steps towards the accession to the European Union for some Member States in the south and in the east of the continent – Malta, Slovakia, Latvia, Lithuania, Bulgaria, and my home country, Romania. So Europe owes a lot to previous Portuguese Presidencies of the European Union, and the moment in time now is equally important. The Portuguese Presidency needs to lay the ground for the European Union of the future – more innovative, based on research, digital, based on a process of greening which works for the economy, works for people and works for enterprise. In December we managed to make important decisions: we agreed on the budget of the European Union for the next seven years, and we agreed on the biggest economy rescue package that the European Union has ever done. Now, Prime Minister Costa, it’s time that we make this work. Money needs to arrive to people in need, to enterprises in need, to regions, very soon. In two weeks’ time will take here in the plenary of Parliament the final vote for the Recovery and Resilience Facility, and I’m calling upon you, Prime Minister, to work with the Member States to also do the last steps at national level, specifically ratifying the own-resources decision so that we give the European Commission the permission to go to the market, to borrow the money so that it can reach the people in need very soon. Thank you very much, Prime Minister Costa, good luck for the next six months.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new Portuguese Presidency starts while we are still facing the coronavirus emergency, but we must begin to rethink the future of Europe. There are many things to do, but first of all we need to secure Europeans health with the coordinated vaccination plan and restart the economy with Next Generation EU, a historical tool, made possible by those who believed in Europe and in the strength of its unity in spite of those who, even today on these benches, are taking up precisely those measures that allow European resources to reach citizens and businesses as soon as possible. Our attention must now be focused on the approval of the national recovery plans: we do not need any national recovery plans, but recovery plans that make this dramatic crisis an opportunity to radically change the development model, make it more person-friendly, environmentally and socially sustainable, with a particular eye to those who have lost their jobs and to the new generations. , which risk carrying the burden of the next debts on their shoulders if we are not able to invest today in tomorrow's growth projects. These are the only conditionalities we will accept. Good job, Mr President.

name: Katalin CSEH
text: – Madam President, I wish the Portuguese Presidency good work. Last year, the EU showed courage, vision and solidarity in its pandemic response and climate policy, as well as in the rule of law crisis. But sadly, the Council was more often part of the problem than the solution. There are too many leaders on the conservative side who still believe that silence, autocrats and their corruption is what holds Europe together. But they are wrong. Further appeasement of and concessions to autocrats will only embolden them and make Europe weaker. The Portuguese Presidency now has the chance to be wiser.  The other thing that makes Europe weaker are the Trojan horses within the Union who misuse the unanimity rule. Just look at the outrageous arrest of Alexei Navalny and at Mr Szijjártó, an EU foreign minister who will pay a friendly visit to Moscow this Friday. We will be never be a global player if we play like this.  I hope the Portuguese Presidency will be a partner in fixing this broken system and thus making Europe a truly global player.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The EU migration pact is at the heart of your Presidency and is intended to replace the Dublin system. But Dublin is not the problem. Because what has happened since 2015 is wrong, according to Dublin. This migration pact, however, is wrong by mixing asylum law and immigration law, thereby eroding national sovereign rights. This requires a new EU treaty under Article 48(2) TEU, not a simple majority, all the more so because the Pact speeds up receptions and does not facilitate deportations, opens up new access routes together with NGOs and increases reception capacities. This pro-migration pact normalizes migration. Come to your senses. Another three million migrants that the EU accepts are disrupting our welfare state, and Africa produces three million people every three weeks.

name: Francisco GUERREIRO
text: – Madam President, dear President Ursula von der Leyen, dear Prime Minister António Costa, let me begin with a word of support for all professionals, especially those in health, who work at the forefront of combating COVID-19.  But this pandemic did not arise by chance. According to scientific data, it is a symptom of a failed and ruptured system. I speak of the way we produce and consume food in this globalised world and, considering the risks to public health, the impacts on biodiversity and climate change mitigation, such as the welfare of millions of animals in Europe, I question the Commission and the Council Presidency on whether they will actively seek the decisions resulting from the negotiations on the common agricultural policy , now in the trilogue phase, are based on the European strategy of Prato ao Prato and on the strategy for the preservation of biodiversity. It is that the common agricultural policy is not only 34% of the Multiannual Financial Framework. It is a key policy to comply with the European Ecological Pact and the best tool for implementing resilient and regenerative production processes.

name: Anna ZALEWSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab It is a difficult six months, many difficult issues that will determine the future of Europe: the pandemic, vaccination, rebuilding trust after pfeizer has done, limiting the supply of vaccines, or Germany, which negotiated its contracts outside the European agreement, and climate law, which is still unfinished – work on it must be accelerated (the votes of Parliament, the Commission and the European Council are divergent), alignment with climate law regulations , including regulations on sinks, as well as a very important ETS Regulation. As you can see well, the ETS, the European carbon pricing system, has slipped out of control. In the last few months, you have to pay twice as much for carbon dioxide emissions. This is an alarm – it is necessary to amend and revise this regulation in the coming weeks.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, the scale of the problems faced by several countries in the European Union, including Portugal, requires the implementation of measures opposed to those which, over decades, have led to the regression of labour and social rights, growing social inequality and concentration of wealth, the weakening and privatisation of public services, increased dependency and indebtedness , of disrespect for sovereignty. The seriousness of the situation requires another direction to ensure employment with rights, the strengthening of public services and social functions of the State, support for micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, investment in strategic and productive sectors, ensuring the sovereign development of each country and convergence in economic and social progress. The so-called "Recovery Fund" and the Multiannual Financial Framework should promote the achievement of these objectives by ensuring rapid mobilisation of resources, taking into account the economic and social reality and specific needs of each country and without the imposition of conditionalities that interfere with sovereign decisions. The announced Social Summit should not be limited to a proclamation of intentions and policies based on levelling, social rollback or measures to mitigate the impact of a planned destruction of employment. What is required is a pact for employment and social progress that is towards full employment, employment with rights, the eradication of precariousness, wage appreciation. A pact promoting the defense and strengthening of public services in each country, ensuring the universality of rights, such as the right to health, education, social security or housing.

name: Dorien ROOKMAKER
text: – Madam President, dear Prime Minister, dear colleagues, Portugal declared a state of emergency and every effort should be made to getting people vaccinated as quickly as possible. As we have seen, the EU is able to cooperate in such an emergency; there is no need for further integration or a superstate. We can work together if we have to. We need more of these good practices. Integration is not an objective in itself; it is simply necessary to achieve common goals. Abstract ideals do not inspire people; we need tangible results for everybody to see and for everybody to enjoy. If we really want people to make a connection to Europe, we have to make it possible for them to connect within Europe. Transport and tourism need improved cross-border connections, especially high-speed rail connections. TEN-T projects need cross-border commitment from EU leaders and Member States. Let’s make it possible; let’s get to work!

name: Kinga GÁL
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. What citizens are really interested in today, live in any corner of the Union, is to get their pre-pandemic lives back. If this is a condition of vaccination, you are entitled to ask when you will be vaccinated. It cannot be explained that as long as millions are vaccinated outside the Eu, we lack the vaccine. This shakes confidence in the EU institutions. Trust is the key question, Prime Minister, whether the Union can restore citizens' sense of security in the face of pandemic, economic crisis and migration challenges. We therefore expect the Portuguese Presidency to help to have enough vaccines to implement the historic budget agreement as effectively as possible. Restore citizens' confidence that the Union can and wants to protect its external borders, that illegal migration can be stopped and that unauthorised migrants can be reversed, and that a mandatory immigration quota is in no way a solution. The Visegrad countries cannot accept this. We expect a guarantee from the Portuguese Presidency that the rule of law in investigation will not become an extortionate tool, that there are no ideological expectations for EU payments. It is unacceptable, Madam President, that Vice-President Jourová threatened to withdraw funds from the Hungarian Government in his statement yesterday. We expect the Portuguese Presidency, Prime Minister, to conclude the Article 7 procedure in the Council.  Finally, restore confidence with the European Citizens' Initiative tool, because what is the purpose of more than one million signatures collected if the Committee does not take a legislative initiative to protect traditional national and linguistic minorities? The protection of national minorities is part of the rule of law. If he does not wish to address this, all jourová's arguments against the rule of law will be discredited. There will be something for the Portuguese Presidency to do in terms of strengthening trust. I wish you every success in this.

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister António Costa, Madam President of the European Commission, in a debate scheduled for Parliament to discuss the priorities of the Presidency of the Council for the next six months, where we must focus on saving lives, on saving jobs, an EPP Member has so far chosen to de-step forward the House, nationalise the debate and attack the Prime Minister of Portugal. I register, with regret, this choice of the Ppe, of the PSD. But on, this is not the time for small politics, because the Portuguese Presidency begins with great challenges. Ensuring European unity while continuing to fight the pandemic, saving lives, vaccinating Europeans, rejecting national selfishness in this process. Saving jobs, still saving jobs, now that the third wave of the pandemic has forced us to confine again, contrary to the wishes of some hawks who want the hasty return of the macroeconomic rules that would at this time generate unemployment and hopelessness. If ten years ago there was money for the banks, all that was needed, now we are not going to cut off the legs of the workers, who are not at fault of this crisis. And also prepare the future, with an ambitious green and digital recovery, but that leaves no one behind. We welcome Portugal and António Costa for their priority to The Social Pillar.  And, I ask, what progress does the Portuguese Presidency think about doing in this regard? Can we approve the timetable for the Action Plan of the European Pillar of Social Rights at the Porto Social Summit?

name: Luis GARICANO
text: – Madam President, welcome to the European Parliament, Prime Minister Costa. National recovery plans are beginning to arrive in Brussels, but some Member States do not want to make the reforms that Europe demands. For example, in Spain, in my country, the government's populist ministers insist that no reforms need to be made, they even want to undo those that have already been done. They think European money will come the same way. The temptation of each country will be to turn a blind eye to the plans of others: today for you, tomorrow for me. But we cannot allow countries to skip European conditions, Mr Costa. If we now turn a blind eye, if we do not make reforms, if we do not invest this money well, European money will have been a great waste with serious consequences for Europe. That is why Europe must be firm. You, Mr Costa, and you, Mrs von der Leyen, must demand that European money be spent on European priorities. It is your duty not to approve any plan that does not include the reforms and investments that this Parliament, the Commission and the Council have agreed. As you said, Mr Costa, it's time to comply.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: Mr President, allow me to draw the Portuguese President's attention to the issue of the so-called comprehensive EU-China investment agreement. The citizens of Europe received the news of this agreement somewhere between the Christmas tree and New Year's Eve served by Mrs Merkel and Mr Macron, who – as we all know – run this European Union de facto. We, the other Member States, are allowed to join us.  From here, I call on Portugal, also a small Member State, to put this scandalous agreement on hold and to keep it on hold for the time being. After all, just hours after the protsy announcement of this agreement, in Hong Kong, at the behest of the Chinese regime, parliamentarians and political leaders were detained in pure Tiananmen style. Democracy in Hong Kong has been completely decapitated, and what is Europe doing? Europe is going to make sweet rolls with an investment agreement. This is totally unacceptable to us. Our relations with China need to be completely re-completed. A thorough evaluation is needed, not only in hong kong but also on 5G, the coronavirus and the unsubsensed military threat in the South China Sea and elsewhere. All this should inspire us here in Europe to end all naivety, here and now right now.  It is time to replace the immediate gain and political marketing of the European Union with a sensible long-term strategy.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, you have made climate the heart of your speech and the European agenda and, unsurprisingly, you did not mention Mercosur, because the free trade agreement on Mercosur, because of soybeans, beef, bioethanol, is more than 25% deforestation and therefore it contributes massively to climate change.  However, Prime Minister, since 2,000, when negotiations with Mercosur opened, this is 5.5 times the area of Portugal in deforestation on the Amazon. 5.5 times the size of your country and you know, you were prime minister at the time of the terrible fires that ravaged your country. So, Prime Minister, since you want to ratify this agreement, how will you justify to your fellow Portuguese the next forest fires, resulting from climate change? Madam President, when there is a new pandemic resulting from deforestation, industrial livestock, what will you say to The citizens of Europe? When there is a health scandal of pesticides or animal abuse in Brazil, when there is a corruption scandal, how will you justify to the Europeans that you have signed? So reopen this agreement, you cannot say that today we cannot reopen the agreement with Mercosur, at a time when everything changes.

name: Geert BOURGEOIS
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, Lisbon is one of my favourite cities and I note that you are putting some good emphasis on it. You are resolutely opting for multilateralism, and you will find a supporter of Joe Biden, who has the good idea of organising a summit of democratic countries. I ask you: put on your agenda also a summit of the EU and the United States.  Good luck with your plans for new trade treaties, especially in Central and South America. I hope you will find support for Mercosur, with additional commitments to sustainability and forest management.  I also ask you to do everything possible to finally achieve a breakthrough with India. Make that summit a success. I think you can count on the European Parliament.  I'm much more reticent about your social summit. I ask you to keep the redistributive powers with the Member States. Respect subsidiarity in order to maintain confidence in the Union.

name: Carles PUIGDEMONT I CASAMAJÓ
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, the cloud of key words that will identify the Portuguese semester will be very similar to that which identified the German Presidency: Next Generation EU, digital transition, climate emergency, but also pandemic, confinement, vaccines, economic crisis and unemployment. It is true that the Portuguese Presidency will open a new stage in the relationship with the United States and will have the opportunity to restore, with President Biden, everything that President Trump has broken. In this sense, we have full confidence in the ability and the Atlantic vision of Portugal. But what worries me most is everything that is clouded by the pandemic cloud. I am referring above all to rights and freedoms, certainly in EU countries like Spain that have political prisoners and use repression against political dissidents. Please Mr Prime Minister, fight to ensure that the pandemic does not make human rights and fundamental rights invisible. Can we beat the virus without freedom? COVID—19 maybe yes, but the crypto-fascism virus, no.

name: Dolors MONTSERRAT
text: – Madam President; Mr. Puigdemont, don't come tell lies! You are an escapee of justice, an enemy of democracy and the rule of law. I am very convinced that the Portuguese Presidency will vehemently defend the rule of law and democracy.  President Costa, the next six months must lead us inexorably to the exit from the health crisis. We have the tools, the vaccine and the firm will to end this terrible pandemic. The Europeans are exhausted. If the German Presidency has left us the vaccine and its access, the Presidency of Portugal must now put in all the necessary resources to ensure that, in six months' time, Europeans are mostly immunized and vaccinated against the virus. There's no alternative. Only from health security can our economies, industries and jobs, affected by the pandemic, be boosted. And, alongside this, there are many challenges for the next Semester that cannot be forgotten, such as reorienting the fisheries agreements after Brexit to defend our fishermen, the migration crisis, or the tourist and hotel crisis after COVID. Today there are millions of Europeans concerned not only about when they will be vaccinated, but also about their employment, about their business. They wake up every morning not knowing if they will charge at the end of the month, how long they will be in ERTE or unemployed. These six months ahead have to be the momentum of recovery and hope, with ambitious national reforms to create jobs.  We all want the success of the Portuguese Presidency, because it will be the success of the European Union. But, President Costa, I must tell you that this can hardly be the case if the shadow of any doubt about the portuguese prosecutor's election to the European Public Prosecutor's Office is not dispelled. There's no time to waste: clear it up. You have a chance today. The Europeans are waiting for you.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, I should like to say to Prime Minister Costa that you are taking the lead at a time when the world needs exactly that: leadership. Not only within the EU borders, but also in the global arena, and this requires the moral leadership to say that a world in which two thirds of the population will have no access to COVID-19 vaccines by 2022 is unacceptable.  It also requires the executive leadership to enact the EU’s first sanctions against the world’s worst perpetrators of human-rights violations under the new global human-rights sanctions regime, and it requires the global leadership to stand up to China, to hold Russia to account and to rebuild our transatlantic and multilateral ties while strengthening Europe’s ability to take responsibility. The S&D Group looks forward to working with you on a truly progressive global agenda. Good luck.

name: Stéphane SÉJOURNÉ
text: Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, Prime Minister Antonio Costa, I have listened attentively to the priorities of the Portuguese Presidency and we share the broad guidelines and priorities of this Presidency.  Economic recovery to ensure the implementation of our European budget and our European recovery plan, climate action to approve the European climate law and guarantee at least 55% reduction in CO2 emissions by 2030, digital to guarantee European sovereignty, social Europe with the preparation of this summit in Porto, which must give a boost to the European base of social rights , as well as Europe open to the geopolitical world with an Africa summit, relations with the Mediterranean, is strategic autonomy.  However, we will have to guarantee an additional point, Prime Minister, on the institutional issue which must restore confidence in our institutions. The conference on the future of Europe must be an important moment and should come out of the ground fairly quickly in July. We will have to overcome our divisions and blockages, we will be complete if we decide and we debate how to decide together.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Costa, for the sake of the peoples of Europe, I hope that your presidency will be a humble Presidency, because humility means being able to reflect on how inadequate the dogmas are on the budget in order to emerge from this crisis. The suspension of the Stability Pact and the freezing of state aid legislation are just the tip of an iceberg of unsustainability. Working people and businesses have spent months looking to Brussels with confidence, but if there is no common sense to understand that conditionality is a trap in an historic phase like this, then the Recovery Plan risks becoming a noose around the neck. According to the International Monetary Fund, the fiscal stimulus adopted by eurozone governments is significantly less than that of governments in advanced third-country economies. This means that governments in Europe are afraid to spend public money, so I hope that this Presidency will take this into account because a leash, however loose, always remains a leash.

name: Tineke STRIK
text: – Madam President, a Presidency comes with celebrations and joy but also with responsibilities and opportunities, especially where Member States are divided and are not willing to achieve progress.  On two topics, I urge you to take decisive action. One is to fight discrimination. The Black Lives Matter Movement shows that in Europe too many people still feel excluded from society and are discriminated against. Twelve years ago, the Commission proposed a horizontal equal-treatment directive to make sure that equal treatment applies to everyone in all situations. The Parliament swiftly adopted the proposal but it has been blocked in the Council up until now, so I urge you to take the lead to try to unblock this important file. Another blocked file is the start of the negotiations with North Macedonia. For years now we have imposed requirements for this moment on them and the country did a tremendous job to meet all of them, and now one Member State misuses its EU membership to solve a bilateral dispute. I urge you to put pressure on Bulgaria to lift its blockade, and to restore the credibility of the EU regarding the Western Balkans. Their citizens deserve it.

name: Eugen JURZYCA
text: – Madam President. I consider it a top priority to use the resources from the rescue package as effectively as possible. We only have one chance to use them wisely. It's not free money. These are resources that we will be paying back from new European taxes for decades. I would therefore like to call on the representatives of the Portuguese Presidency to support the idea of 'value for money' of the resources used. Green and digital investments, which are given priority, must also be subject to an efficiency test. Will they bring more productivity than other investments? We don't quite know. Will they boost long-term economic growth? We don't know, too. Public investment must not be an alternative to the necessary structural reforms, but only an addition to them. Otherwise, only higher taxes and new debt will remain after the rescue package.

name: Tomas TOBÉ
text: – Madam President, for the European Union, for our citizens and for the migrants, the moment of truth is here. We need a common European approach to migration. It is time to break the political deadlock in the Council. Last September, the Commission presented its proposal for a new pact on migration and asylum. It is now crucial that the Portuguese Presidency move the work forward. As Rapporteur on the Regulation on Asylum and Migration Management, I believe we now have an opportunity to find an efficient, pragmatic and practical political compromise. We need a meaningful solidarity for the front-line Member States and flexible options for the contributing Member States, and let me be clear: all Member States need to contribute in some way. Therefore, the Council needs to unite on a position, by consensus would be ideal, but if it’s not feasible it should be by qualified majority. We need to start the reforms and I believe that this needs to be on the top of the agenda of the Portuguese Presidency. My questions to the Portuguese Presidency and Prime Minister Costas are therefore: what actions will the Portuguese Presidency take during its term to unite the Council on a position; what is the timeline? And good luck of course with your Presidency.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: – Madam President, Mr President and Prime Minister, I would like to begin by congratulating the Rapporteur on his excellent For a long time, we Social Democrats have been pushing for a strong Europe, a strong social Europe, with security, justice and equality. As a Swede, I am very proud that our government was able to organise the summit in Gothenburg where all the Member States supported the social pillar. But now, now the fight must go ahead, not least in the shadow of the ongoing pandemic.  I therefore welcome the portuguese Presidency's clear willingness to give priority to social issues. I would particularly like to stress the importance of keeping the social dimension together with the green deal and the digital agenda. We shall have a more socially, ecologically and economically sustainable Europe. Therefore, Mr Costa, I look forward to the Porto Summit. Thanks for that invitation.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: – Madam President, I say to the Prime Minister: thank you for your clear commitment on the conference on the future of the European Union. I know that there are still some problems in the Council, but I know your strengths. I think you are maybe the only one who can overcome that in the Council, and there is also good reason to do so, that conference, because it’s not because now that Trump is out and Biden is in that we can do business as usual. We have reacted better to the COVID-19 crisis in comparison to the financial crisis – which was a disaster, because it took us 10 years to have the Banking Union and it’s still not there. There are still weaknesses in the European Union. Migration is not solved. The problem of our geopolitical weakness in our relationship, for example, to Russia: not solved. The rule of law: a number of countries not biding by the rules. I think we need this conference urgently and I count on you, Prime Minister, to achieve that in the Council in the coming weeks if possible.

name: Philippe OLIVIER
text: Madam President, on the threshold of this Portuguese Presidency, Prime Minister, you were expressing your desire to bring about the pact for immigration, this pact with the devil. This supposedly balanced pact is irresponsible and totalitarian.  It is irresponsible because it organises the submersion of Europe, with the stated objective of its repopulation. It is totalitarian because it implements coercive legislation for States by stretching treaties, in particular Articles 79 and 80 of the Union's Operating Treaty, by twisting the principle of subsidiarity, by making migration a common eu law jurisdiction, when it was only an exceptional jurisdiction. However, one treaty can only be changed by another treaty.  This demographic globalisation of Europe, you want to decide it among yourself, without any real democratic debate taking place. Because it is about the existence of Europe and its civilization, for the immigration pact, we ask you, Prime Minister, to give the voice to the people by applying the principle of a multi-millennial Europe to which your beautiful country belongs: Vox populi, Vox dei.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, I would like to thank the President of the Commission for her work on You have rightly defended the European vaccination strategy. But for the current phase of the pandemic, we need much more than a common vaccination strategy. Acutely, we are dealing with highly contagious mutations that spread across borders. Many people could also die if the protection measures and shutdowns continue to be decided simultaneously and nationally. Now we need a binding synchronisation of the Corona policy in Europe, that is, a common step-by-step plan with the most uniform measures possible and the same incidence values. Top scientists in the "Contain COVID" initiative have long since put forward proposals to this effect. Mrs von der Leyen, Prime Minister Costa, be courageous tomorrow at the EU summit! Present a European plan for a European Corona policy! Anything else, with border closures, would cause massive damage. A strong EU plan against Corona is the order of the day in view of the new threat situation! That is the EU summit task tomorrow!

name: Mazaly AGUILAR
text: – Madam President, the German Presidency of the Council has been to forget. Under his mandate, a multiannual financial framework has been negotiated for the next seven years, enshrining an unacceptable reduction in the CAP to please the green lobby and which is not intended at all to help European businesses and workers, who, after our elders, are the worst off with this pandemic. A financial framework that will blindly allocate billions to the green agenda without addressing the reality of our economies, as unemployment and despair rise for the self-employed and small and medium-sized enterprises. A German presidency that has ended with the announcement of a regrettable investment agreement with communist China, a country responsible for action or omission of this crisis of death and desolation. We Spaniards have high hopes that the Presidency of a sister nation, such as Portugal, will make common sense in this drift, strengthen the protection of the Mediterranean axis and help explain that the great diversity of our agricultural and livestock sector is not a threat to the environment, but remains its greatest and best ally. All the luck in the world, President Costas.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, thank you for putting the social aspect at the heart of European politics. The COVID crisis has had and continues to have important consequences for seniors in our society, but it also has very important social consequences, particularly for young people. Young people are desperate today, the short-term reality is quite bleak, in the medium term it is not much better and in the long run it is quite black, anxious, in any case, linked in particular to the fight against global warming. So thank you for telling us, to tell us if youth will really be at the heart of this social summit in Porto which will be very important for everyone. Thank you also for also involving the social partners in this process. On the other hand, I am really surprised that you put on the front page and that you have this desire to ratify the Mercosur absolutely and quickly. We can no longer look at free trade treaties, and I am in for free trade, without taking into account the impact on the climate. We cannot say both that we are in force with the Paris Agreements and ignore in the various agreements that we pass from a precise, objective analysis of CO2 impact.  It is a first element and the second for our farmers, our producers, we would rather wait to have a signal, especially in relation to imports that have to stop, if we have this production force in Europe, especially for the feeding of livestock. Finally, we are of course pleased that a populist in North America has left the White House, we must not be able to support tomorrow a populist in South America, namely Brazil.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: Madam President, Madam President of the European Commission, Prime Minister Antonio Costa, thank you for your words and thank you for stating all the European challenges that your Presidency will have to meet.  And among these challenges, which I share, is the negotiation of the common agricultural policy. First of all, I hope that we can come to fruition together under your presidency. More than ever, this text should enable farmers to live with dignity. However, as you know, the CAP has long been market-driven, exclusively by the market, creating considerable damage to the farming community.  And while I am not adverse to market orientation, I believe we have gone too far in deregulation. Agricultural markets are structurally unstable. We need to get out of the myth that the agricultural market is self-regulating. This is not true: too many farmers have lost their jobs, sometimes even their lives. We urgently need to regulate agricultural markets, and I have no doubt that you will do so.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, I am pleased to see that your presidency will be given the sign of recovery. At the same time, however, the implementation of the repayment agreement requires marking the ground now. Because tomorrow, Janez Jana, the little Orban of the Alps, will take over. Will he have the heart of Europe enough to move this project forward? So Mr Costa, I have a question: why does the Portuguese programme not mention anywhere the own resources, acted and planned to avoid the repayment of the debt by European citizens? Prime Minister, your presidency is meant to be social and that is very good. But it will only be social if you manage to set the road to fiscal justice seriously. It will only be social if the digital giants go to the cash register, it will only be social if Chinese industrialists pay the same rights to pollute as European companies, it will only be social if financial speculators are put before their responsibilities. Madam President, Prime Minister, social Europe will go through fiscal justice or will not be.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, do you think that the Italians are stupid? Do you think the Italians did not understand that Europe is treating them like fish in the face? Take the problem of illegal immigration: according to Frontex, in 2020, immigrant landings in Europe fell by 13 %. It is a pity that they have tripled in Italy: more than 34 000 illegal immigrants have landed in Italy in the midst of a pandemic, or 95 % of all illegal immigrants arriving from the Central Mediterranean. You have turned Italy into the refugee camp of Europe, with the complicity of the PD-5 Stelle government. Let's move on to the coronavirus emergency. Eleven months have passed since the start of the pandemic and the Italians have not seen a euro, neither of the Recovery Fund nor of the billions so promised. And now you have included the last rip-off in the Recovery Regulation: put the money in place, but in return, the Stability Pact, austerity and all the absurd European constraints will return. We will not allow this Europe, a slave to banks and multinationals, to starve so many Italian families and businesses. Together with our citizens, we will fight to stop this madness and to give hope and a future to our people and our land.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Madam President, Madam Commission President and most of all, dear Prime Minister Costa. Forty-six years ago, the people in Portugal took to the streets for democracy and freedom. They took to the streets to peacefully overthrow an authoritarian and oppressive regime. Their struggle for democracy and freedom will never be forgotten in Europe’s history. Many years have passed since then, but today again authoritarians are grabbing power in Europe, threatening democracy and the rule of law. Again, we need a strong Portuguese voice in the struggle for freedom and democracy. So, Prime Minister use the next six months to stand strong for our shared European values. This Parliament has for years now fought for a more determined European reaction to breaches of rule of law and EU citizens’ fundamental rights. Very often, unfortunately, without the Council Presidency at our side. Let us make the next six months a spring for freedom and democracy inside the European Union, for the rights of minorities, of women, for equality and diversity. We count on you Mr Prime Minister.

name: Nicola PROCACCINI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Costa, the political phase is certainly momentous. We will see if your ability to offer balanced and efficient guidance will be just as memorable: unfortunately, no one has escaped how the June European agreements on the purchase of vaccines have been betrayed by those who believe themselves to be above all the other Member States. With regard to covid-19 recovery plans, we also see the risk that some national plans will become an opportunity to issue election tips, rather than for long-term strategic investments. Finally, I would like to mention two decisive dossiers. The first is the Digital Services Act: it cannot be the corporate policy of an American or Chinese digital platform that establishes the rules of our economic, democratic and social coexistence. The second is the new pact on migration and asylum: do not dump the burden of irregular immigration on border states, such as yours and mine. Good job, Mr President!

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Madam President, the Portuguese Presidency starts in a crisis and pandemic without precedent and, although everyone is affected, some feel the negative impact more than others. Older generations are under higher health risk, but younger generations face tremendous challenges in education, finding a proper job and starting their own family. The joint European vaccination efforts offer an opportunity to normalise our lives and our economy, but it is also crucial to defend the free movement of persons in Europe, both through maintaining Schengen as an area without internal border controls, and through further Schengen enlargement after fulfilment of all the criteria. I also welcome your commitment in the area of the future of work, and in reconciling work and family life. The imperative of fair recovery has been recognised by the Portuguese Presidency. It’s time that innovative and digital recovery comes to all: to all generations, to all economic sectors and to all the regions. I wish you success.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: Qabel ma nagħti l-kelma flower-kelliema li jmiss, se niftaħ issa l-ewwel sessjoni ta' votazzjoni tal-lum. Se nivvotaw dwar il-fajls hedge kif inhuma indikati fl-aġenda.
