name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Issa nkomplu d-dibattitu tagťna dwar id-dikjarazzjonijiet tal-Kunsill u tal-Kummissjoni dwar il-preżentazzjoni tal-programm ta' attivitajiet tal-Presidency Portugiża (2020/2928(RSP)).

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Mrs Von der Leyen, Prime Minister Costa, you can feel it, there is a different wind blowing in Europe. Taking care of everyone and making sure that everyone can come along, that is our job now. So no longer with higher minimum wages, care for affordable housing, and put an end to zero-hours contracts. Then we'll get through this crisis together honestly.  Portugal has shown how to get out of a crisis by investing in people. We must start to apply this lesson throughout Europe. I welcome Prime Minister Costa's priorities for a new social agenda for Europe. To do this, we need binding social goals. At the Social Summit in Porto, the Heads of Government and the European Commission have to sign off on this. I would say the new Dutch government.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Madam President, I say to the Prime Minister: Portugal must be a strong leader to bring us out of the crisis. We need an efficient rollout of the vaccine. Our citizens want to know: when will we have enough vaccines, and how should these be delivered efficiently? Our health systems are still under a lot of pressure. Lockdowns help reduce new cases but are costly, not only economically but also for public trust. Public trust which is vital to successful vaccine programmes. Mr Prime Minister, the vaccine is just one part of restoring our economy. Beyond the recovery package, we need to plan how to remove the barriers introduced since the crisis and ways to encourage our citizens’ businesses to work and travel cross-border again. I wish you good luck.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: – Madam President, I have been a Member of this Parliament for 18 month and I already sound like a broken record. Every start of a semester I request for my Group one minute of speaking time to address the new Presidency and to inquire what will you do about the situation in Poland? What will you do about the situation in Hungary? What will you do about these two Article 7 procedures that the Council seems to be shying away from, reeling away from, even.  Meanwhile, democratic life in these two countries is getting worse and worse, and some freedoms just do not exist anymore for those citizens that the Council does not seem to find equal to the other European people.  We need you to act. Will you be in the courageous camp? I remember the Finnish Presidency. These quite young women – very strange already for a government, young and women – were the only ones that had enough courage, cleverness and political skills to tackle this grave problem. Will you lead on this?

name: Izabela-Helena KLOC
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Prime Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Instead of enjoying the charms of winter, many Europeans are wondering today how to survive this time of year. Their concerns are justified. We have recently seen an incredible wave of power supply disruptions and spikes in electricity prices. Winter has exposed the unavailability of renewable energy sources and restored concerns about energy security. The Portuguese Presidency has not taken up this issue. Recent months have shown that too rapid an energy transition entails the risk of major turbulence in energy production and distribution. For this we have cosmic electricity bills. This is already the case in France, Austria, Ireland. And by the end of winter it's still a long way off. I therefore urge you not to overlook the problem of energy security and access to energy. However, we must guarantee a reasonable pace of transformation using indigenous fossil fuels as stabilisers of the energy system. Our continent cannot be plunged into cold and darkness simply because windmills and solar panels are in fashion and bring profits to their chosen ones. I think it's time to apologize now with coal.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Madam President, we very much hope that the Portuguese Presidency will succeed, because with it the European Union will succeed and European citizens will have enormous benefits. Undoubtedly, our great challenge is to tackle the pandemic and socio-economic crisis. We were clearly in favour of voting for this very positive and historic step, which is the creation of the 'New Generation EU' Recovery Fund, worth seven hundred and fifty billion. But right now, business is groaning. The workers and citizens of European Union society are in a difficult position and expect this money as a 'manna from heaven' so that they can truly recover from this difficult period of time.  Mr President-in-Office of the Council of the European Union, Prime Minister of Portugal, António Costa, I fully endorse your priorities, but I would like you to add one more to these priorities: safeguarding the principles, values and European law. A country collectively and over time violates and flattens the principles and values of the European Union and violates European law by continuing to be financed by the European Union;  To date, the European Union has shown unacceptable and abusive tolerance. I expect you, Mr Costa, to answer me clearly, without the triviality, as far as Turkey is concerned, what your reaction will be to this provocative behaviour by Turkey;

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Protection of fundamental rights, democracy, the rule of law – these are the priorities that the Presidency mentions in the same paragraph as protection against terrorism, hate speech, misinformation. Strengthening security and fundamental rights is a challenge, also for us in the LIBE Committee, for example in the area of e-evidence, the safeguarding and publication of electronic evidence. Yes to faster publication, if fundamental rights remain secure. With terrorist content online, the Council could not go fast enough. But with the e-evidence regulation to better protect privacy online, we have been ready to negotiate since 2017, and member states are blocking it. So, while the Council is pressing ahead with some measures, it is on the brakes on the protection of fundamental rights. That is why, dear Portuguese Presidency, you show that the Council, too, always wants to protect fundamental rights effectively. Thank you and good luck!

name: Charles GOERENS
text: Madam President, Prime Minister of Portugal, Madam President of the Commission, I hope that, under your leadership, the conference on the future of Europe can start shortly. This conference, which is not a goal in itself, will, I hope, reconcile the citizen with the European political sphere. The citizen will therefore be at the centre of this conference, but let us not be naïve, let us not pretend that the citizen will reveal only new things to us.  We know from the polls done by Eurostat in particular that the citizen is in love with security, that he wants a security and defence policy, that he wants to fight climate change, that he wants to relaunch multilateralism with the Biden administration, that he wants to defend public goods.  So I would like to introduce a little nuance in relation to your speech, which I really appreciated. We also have to talk about institutions. If we agree on the aims, we will also have to agree on the means to implement them. I am also counting on you, knowing that you are a convinced European, so that this subject does not remain taboo, it would be a missed opportunity.

name: Riho TERRAS
text: – Respectable Sitting President, Madam President, respected Mr Prime Minister. First of all, I would like to thank you, of course, for introducing the objectives of the Portuguese Presidency. In today's health and economic crisis, real forward-looking decisions must be made, as the global race for a more successful recovery from the crisis has been going on for some time. A speedy recovery for Europe is a vital objective and our competitiveness depends very much on the decisions that must be made here and now. I am convinced that it is these actions that will increase Europe's beggars, support a wider digital and technological turn, and that it will give us the opportunity to stand at the forefront of global competition.  But, Mr Prime Minister, competitiveness also means the ability to provide our people with healthy and reasonably priced food produced in Europe. This is the main objective of the common agricultural policy. I very much hope that, in the trilogy of the common agricultural policy, Portugal will not be charged with the motivation to continue to operate in its field under the auspices of the green revolution. The role of the European Commission, and in particular Vice-President Timmermans, in the trilogy, has been not balancing and solution-oriented, but ideological and agriculturally worrying. I hope that Portugal will stand up for the interests of European farmers during its Presidency and that the outcome of the talks will be favourable to farmers. Thank you.

name: Javier MORENO SÁNCHEZ
text: – Madam President, Madam President of the Commission, Mr Prime Minister, dear António, may they be my first words to wish you welcome in what has been and will forever be your home, the house of European democracy.  Crises are often said to create opportunities for the European Union, and last year, unfortunately, they have not been lacking. Now it is time to act on challenges and opportunities, as set out in your Presidency's motto.  Firstly, overcoming the pandemic with a vaccination campaign based on European transparency and cooperation, eliminating health nationalisms. Secondly, facing economic and social recovery with the advent of European funds for fair and inclusive ecological and digital transitions that leave no one behind.  Therefore, the concrete development of the social pillar with a real action plan and concrete measures is clearly an urgency. And no one better than the Portuguese Presidency to achieve this, paying special attention to gender equality and the fight against poverty. Good luck and go!

name: Svenja HAHN
text: Madam President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the President-in-The-European Commissioner for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you for the exchange. The potential of artificial intelligence is so great, we can hardly imagine that today. For the prospects of tomorrow, however, we must now create a framework for how we live, how we operate and what place the EU will have in a digitised world. Prime Minister Costa, I expect your Presidency to make three main points: to promote the Digital Single Market. We only raise opportunities together, we only put global standards together, civil rights are non-negotiable. The protection of fundamental rights must be safeguarded at European level. No mass monitoring through automatic facial recognition and no overblocking by upload filters! Promote innovation instead of slowing down! Any kind of regulation must be unbureaucratic and open to technology, and I expect you to prevent national solo actions from going ahead, to create a European framework for artificial intelligence and digital services, for progress and innovation 'made in Europe'. Good luck!

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, first of all, Prime Minister Costa, the Presidency of the Council under your leadership has begun during unprecedented times. As we heard this morning, important priorities are on your agenda, such as tackling the COVID-19 pandemic and ensuring Europe’s economic recovery. Colleagues, I welcome in particular the fact that Portugal has decided to focus strongly on external affairs in the upcoming months. As we discussed yesterday with the High Representative during the debate on our common foreign and security policy, strengthening multilateralism and affirming the European Union as a global player is today more important than ever, and our Commission President Ursula von der Leyen is leading a geopolitical Commission, and this for good reasons.  Prime Minister, the proposals from the Portuguese Presidency to strengthen the EU’s relations with India, with the African continent, and indeed with Latin America, especially Mercosur, are a key step in promoting the role of the European Union on the global stage. The next months will also be decisive in establishing a fruitful cooperation with the United Kingdom and with the new administration in the United States. For all these priorities I wish her success. The Committee on Foreign Affairs is looking forward to working closely together with the Portuguese Government. (Applause)

name: Nuno MELO
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, resisting commenting on the appointment of a European Prosecutor on the basis of false information, which thus undermines the credibility of the Public Prosecutor's Office at the very moment he is born, I would like to stress that Dr António Costa is receiving the leadership of the European Union at a time when the COVID-19 pandemic shows signs of absolute uncontroland and Europeans need to look at themselves and trust that he will be up to the challenge. But unfortunately, they look at the disaster that happens in Portugal and doubt.  In a few months, Portugal went from a good student to one of the worst examples in the world. When Europe confined, Portugal relaxed. When in July the numbers were worse than in March, instead of tightening the requirement, i told people to go to baths and when in October, November and December the consequences appeared, there was no absolute reduction of contacts in Christmas and New Year. Now that everything is worse, it is ordered a confinement of make-believe that keeps all people in the street and elections are held that will provoke gatherings in all the villages of Portugal. It makes no sense that, in a European Union in which people move freely, that each one decides, differently, the mechanisms for controlling the pandemic, often by intuition, and so I ask and finish, what can you say here today to reassure Europeans and say that you will do much better ahead of 27 countries than you are achieving in Portugal?  Vaccination plans, pace, coordination, European solidarity, rather than national selfishness, are the issues I leave you, Mr. Prime Minister, and I wish you the best of luck in the job at the moment, which you need.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, the Portuguese Presidency has the right priorities: to overcome the pandemic, to recover the economy, to strengthen Europe in the world.  When we discuss our common future, it is regrettable that some, fortunately very few, want to use the European Parliament stage for their small national political "guerrinha", but no artificial case should divert the Portuguese Presidency from what is really important and the important thing is to make the Portuguese Presidency an opportunity to re-meet the European project with the expectations of citizens , coordinate the European vaccination strategy, get the money to the real economy, align investment with our strategic priorities.  In the next six months, Portugal has the Presidency of the Council and also has the Secretary-General of the United Nations, a great opportunity to bet on the multilateralism that the world needs and Europe too.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Madam President, Prime Minister, President, vaccination and recovery are the two most urgent tasks of the mission of the Portuguese Presidency. We have built a robust European response to the crisis, anchored in the MFF, the Recovery Fund, the Own Resources Decision, the Recovery and Resilience Mechanism and the Rule of Law Regulation.  Member States need to ratify the Own Resources Decision. Congratulations to Portugal for having already scheduled this decision in the national Parliament for the next day 29.  Of course, budget support for economies has to extend beyond 2021 and the general escape clause of the Stability and Growth Pact has to remain activated in 2022.  The Portuguese presidencies have a tradition of leaving inheritances, the Treaty of Lisbon, for example. I'm sure the same will happen this time. I end by quoting President Sassoli, a Presidency that will go down in history for driving the construction of the new Europe, a mission we all have. Count on us, count on the European Parliament.

name: Maroš Šefčovič
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, Madam President of the Commission, dear Prime Minister, dear António, I think that, as you heard from all honourable Members, your programme to deliver on a green, digital and social Europe resonates very well with this House, and this is exactly what Europe now needs and what our citizens expect from us. As Mr Azmani, Ms Bonafè, Ms Jongerius, but also our parliamentary leaders Mr Weber, Mr Cioloş and Ms García Pérez said, they all expressed in their interventions also the reference to hope – to hope that we will be able to come back to life as we knew it before COVID—19. I think it was also very clear from this debate what we need for that. We need to show the highest respect for EU solidarity and for EU unity. As you know very well, yesterday the Commission called upon the Member States to get more than 80% of the health workers and more than 80% of elderly over 80 years of age vaccinated by February. We would like to get 70% of the European population vaccinated by the summer. That’s the timeline, that’s the ambition, and that’s the hope, which we hope the European leaders will endorse tomorrow in a videoconference on this very issue. We believe that this is the best path to restore growth, prosperity and to bring us back to the normal joys of life we all miss so much. Honourable Members, in almost all interventions there was clear reference to the importance of tackling the social consequences and social problems aggravated by the COVID-19 crisis. Therefore, we in the Commission appreciate so much the support of this House for the Portuguese Presidency’s ambition to complete the work on national recovery plans, to get approval for their own-resources decision, so that we can start the disbursement of money to kick-start our economies also by this summer. The European social summit organised and proposed by the Portuguese Presidency will be an excellent opportunity to put in practice all the Commission’s measures we will prepare under the European pillar of social rights to make sure that nobody is left behind. Dear Prime Minister, honourable Members, the Presidency of Portugal is also opening a new chapter in pursuit of our European geopolitical ambition and the restoration of effective functioning multilateralism. It will be our efforts to help our neighbourhoods and to help the global effort in the vaccination. It will be closer cooperation with democracies, including the summit between the European Union and India, which happen to be the two largest democracies on this planet. And you heard also, Mr President-in-Office, the support of the Members of this House for open, strategic autonomy on which we will be working together. On top of it, it will be also under your Presidency when we will open a new chapter with the new incoming US Biden administration. We start to build a new relationship with the UK as a third country, and we will also push to rebalance the trade and investment relationship with China. Dear Prime Minister, you highlighted how important it is to listen to people and to respond to our citizens, and we all hope, as it was expressed by Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Weber and Mr Séjourné, that under your Presidency we will be able to launch a conference on the future of Europe and devote it to the debate and, I would underline, listening to our citizens – what they want us to improve and how they want us to shape our Europe in the future. And I agree with you that it should be the issues which are closest to their heart we should debate together. To conclude, I would like to assure you, Mr President-in-Office, that we will be working with you as closely as possible to make sure that, after your Presidency, Europe will indeed be healthier, greener, more digital and more socially fair. Lots of success and best of luck with your Presidency, Prime Minister.

name: António COSTA
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, Madam President of the European Commission, Mr Vice-President, Ladies and Gentlemen, I would first like to thank mr Weber for the warm words of encouragement and enthusiasm about the future of the Portuguese Presidency and I would like to begin by welcoming the broad consensus I have reached here on the priorities we have set, from the objective of jobs, jobs, jobs formulated by Mr Weber to the call for the social urgency of Mrs Aubry. In essence, it is the verification of a common objective of making Europe's economic and social recovery a priority. This recovery can't be just any recovery. It has to be a recovery focused on our future, on the strategic challenges that we face and, therefore, it must be based on what is the great ambition to make this decade a decade to achieve at least a 55% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions and also to make this decade a digital decade. Nor can it be any social recovery and then, as Mrs Iratxe said, the social issue is absolutely central. This recovery has to be fair, it has to reduce inequalities, it has to create better jobs, decent jobs, jobs with rights. That is why we have placed the Social Summit as the great event of our Presidency, which is precisely to broaden a spirit of comprehensive social dialogue, which is the commitment that social partners, civil society, European institutions, Member States, we all have to celebrate so that we can emerge from this crisis stronger than we were when it began.  But this recovery process must also be demanding in respect of the values of the European Union and certainly a country that has experienced the longest dictatorship of the 20th century is particularly sensitive to the importance of guaranteeing the values set out in Article 2 of the Treaty and of not letting open proceedings in article 7 stop.  Those who violate the rule of law cannot be part of the European Union. Anyone who violates Europe's core values cannot be part of the European Union. That is why it is absolutely essential not only to ensure respect for the cross-compliance mechanism that this Parliament has adopted, but also to enforce and advance the processes that are open under Article 7.  Portugal is proud of the journey it has made since 1974 to be an exemplary country in the protection of the rule of law. I can really be proud that 20 years ago, as Minister of Justice, I witnessed the implementation and start-up of Eurojust and now it was also my Government that brought Portugal together with this enhanced cooperation mechanism, which is the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which is essential to combat corruption and ensure the smooth management of European money, since even my Government , Portugal had refused to join this enhanced cooperation mechanism. That is why we are taking over this Presidency of ours and that we are well aware that this Europe in today's global world really needs to have a stronger external presence. It has to truly be a global agent and we will not be a global agent or building walls to prevent migration, nor closing the doors to the trade relations that we have to open with all the other economies in the world. I understand the debate on Mercosur, but the Mercosur debate is not, first of all, an economic debate. Of course we all know that it is the most important trade agreement that Europe can conclude, but firstly, an agreement for Europe's geopolitics because, in this new global world, the Atlantic cannot lose its importance by letting the new centralisation of the world focus on the Indo-Pacific. We do not ignore this region and we have therefore given the summit with India a priority for our Presidency, but the Atlantic remains our space and that is why, although the United Kingdom has left, we have to have close relations with the United Kingdom. That's why we have to look with hope at this new relationship with President Biden. That is why we have to celebrate Ellalink, physically linking Europe to Latin America as an element of the utmost importance, but that is also why we need an agreement with Mercosur. We are awaiting the conclusions of the Commission's studies on the environmental impact of this agreement and on the steps to be taken, but there is one thing I would also like to say quite frankly, because it is quite frankly that we have to say: that no one wants to hide the methane produced by European cattle in the Amazon forest. No, we cannot want to hide in the Amazon forest what is really protectionism from an agricultural policy that has to be adjusted to the priorities of climate transition and environmental values. The environmental objective has be present in all European policies. I wanted to end by talking about the future and the future of Europe. We must unlock this small institutional impasse that has already caused us to waste x time to reflect on what europe's ambition to do together and there is no shortage of themes for Europe to discuss in its future: the issue of migration is a crucial issue, the post-COVID economic management of our Stability and Growth Pact is a central issue , relations with the African continent are a central issue, the issues of fiscal justice are a central issue.  That is why this conference must move forward and there is nothing to justify small institutional issues blocking what is the future of 450 million citizens. No, this conference really has to be about citizenship, about citizens, their longings, their fears and not on institutional issues.  That is why the motto of our Presidency is even time to act to ensure a fair recovery, a green recovery and a digital recovery.  Many thanks to all and the Presidency is counting on the European Parliament to carry out our mission. (Applause)

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Thank you Prime Minister, thank you, Mr President. As you will have heard, there is great expectation, great confidence in the Portuguese Presidency and, of course, a great desire to cooperate. The debate is closed.  Our work will resume at 3.00 p.m. with statements by the Council and the Commission on the social and employment crisis during the COVID-19 pandemic and the EU response through the Recovery Plan and the MFF. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Carmen AVRAM
text: in writing. – I wish good luck to the Portuguese Presidency in these unprecedented challenges. First, European workers need adequate minimum wages and a coordinated social-security system across EU. This is why putting the European social model at the centre of the Portuguese Presidency is paramount and in accordance with our common values of solidarity, convergence and cohesion. Also I welcome the announcement of the Portuguese Government regarding the implementation of the Green Deal, the adoption of the climate law and the decision to promote innovation, digitisation and sustainable resource-management in the rural areas. Faced with the COVID crisis, European agriculture managed to ensure food security and is certainly something the EU needs to seriously support with regard to future potential challenges. In this context, since Portugal will oversee the implementation of the MFF and the recovery fund I hope it will do its utmost to guarantee funds for agriculture. By doing so it is respecting the promise that no one will be left behind. However, in order to achieve this, it is essential to understand that not all Member States find themselves in the same position, they do not all have the same resources to face this crisis.

name: Isabel CARVALHAIS
text: in writing. – 2021 will be the year of the start-up of the implementation of economic and social recovery plans. A recovery based on 3 principles that guide the Portuguese presidency: environmentally ambitious, based on innovation and digital development, but which does not forget the basic principles of the European pillar of social rights. These are also essential pillars for the negotiations on cap reform, a reform that must be concluded for the sake of the stability of the sector and a rapid advance on the path of greater environmental sustainability, change of behaviour, stimulating the development of research and technological innovation. In fisheries too, the presidency faces a number of challenges. The situation and Brexit pose many uncertainties that could hinder the economic recovery. Regardless of the difficulties, the Portuguese Presidency gives an important sign of hope, but also of realism with the priorities presented for fisheries and the Oceans. The fisheries sector can make a major contribution to the implementation of the different strategies for meeting the objectives of the European Ecological Pact. The full and fair climate and digital transition will bring environmental sustainability, but also economic and social to all sectors, including fisheries.

name: Sara CERDAS
text: in writing. – Portugal takes over the Presidency at an important time for the EU: on the one hand, we have the entry into force of MFF 21-27, on the other hand, the need to start working with a view to recovering from the crisis and, with this, new instruments for recovery, notably the Next Generation EU.  Portugal has the possibility to leave a mark in the EU and set the pace for the recovery of the crisis, but also in the implementation of the European Ecological Pact and commitments on reducing emissions and combating climate change.  In this regard, I draw the Presidency's attention to the cross-cutting issues of the outermost regions (ORs). It is essential that there is a balance between measures to compensate for the specific constraints and structural deficits of the ORs and those aimed at promoting their potential and development opportunities.  It is also essential that there is a balanced and coordinated plan in the recovery of the crisis and the implementation of the principles of the European Ecological Pact. The Presidency should endearing to ensure safeguarding and job creation, supporting SMEs in the sectors most affected by the crisis and ensuring genuine European cohesion.

name: András GYÜRK
text: Writing. – Following the sharp debates of the previous year and in the context of the economic crisis caused by the coronavirus epidemic, the Portuguese Presidency is facing a number of actions in the field of energy and climate policy. The principle framework of the European Green Agreement should be filled with concrete content in the coming period. This is a complex and large task, for which it is essential to restore citizens' trust in the institutions and instruments of the Union. The Presidency-in-Office can take important steps in this direction. Accordingly, in the European Climate Regulation to be finalised in the coming months, the legitimate wish of the people to get their pre-pandemic lives back must be respected. Climate protection and the green transition must go in the interests of citizens, not along the ideological lines of the European left. In the current economic situation, caution is also needed in the development of financial instruments for the energy transition. It is a risky idea to reduce member states' tax powers on the basis of green purposes. The taxonomy regulation on sustainable finance should not further deepen the situation of European industry in crisis. Finally, I was pleased to read the Portuguese Presidency's ambitious objectives in the fight against energy poverty and the circular economy. An appropriate regulatory framework for batteries is of paramount importance. The tasks are given, and I wish you every success in their implementation!

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: in writing. – I welcome the ambition of the Portuguese Presidency of the EU Council to put our EU citizens at the centre of the programme. 2021 needs to rime with hope and solidarity. The programme presented today reflects this objective to strengthen EU citizens’ resilience.  In this sense, I also welcome the Portuguese Presidency for underlining the situation of Roma people in Europe and their focus to fight poverty, social exclusion and discrimination. I call for the Portuguese Presidency to be bold and ambitious in the general conclusions and recommendations in the context of the new EU Roma Strategic Framework 2020-2030. We need strong and targeted policies that address the challenges Roma communities face on daily basis: lack of education, poor access to public basic services, lack of decent housing, general health problems, discrimination and violence. The European Parliament expects the Council to take over its recommendations from last year and work towards swift tangible results.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. – The Portuguese Presidency presented its three main priorities: to promote the recovery of Europe; implement the Social Pillar of the Union, strengthen Europe's strategic autonomy by keeping it open to the world. The Presidency will support the creation of an EU of Health, which strengthens the ability to respond to public health crises, to produce and distribute safe vaccines, to ensure a universal, simultaneous, public and free vaccination process. The Spanish delegation shared these priorities and asked the Presidency to accelerate the transition to a more sustainable model, taking advantage of new technologies and promoting a fair recovery: investment should contribute to reducing inequalities, the wage gap, unemployment and ensuring decent housing for all. Economic governance needs to be reformed so that the social pillar is just as important as economic growth, and fiscal rules suspended until 2023, taking advantage of this time to reform them, introducing, for example, the golden rule for social investment. We must put forward an action plan at the Porto Social Summit, with measures such as child guarantee, unemployment insurance, and the creation of a European health response mechanism to advance the Health Union.
