name: István UJHELYI
text: Writing. – Portugal takes over the Rotating Presidency of the European Union in a life-changing period. In addition to controlling the coronavirus epidemic, the EU's seven-year budget is now under way, but a conference on the future of the European community is also expected to begin. A top priority should be given to the broad implementation of the concept of the European Health Union, initiated by the S&D Group in the Portuguese Presidency's work programme and partly developed by me, including by creating quality criteria for health care systems and by carrying out stress tests in the Member States. In this context, it will also be necessary to table, in the framework of the conference on the future of the EU, a possible overhaul of dogmatic principles such as the exclusive competence of the Member States in the organisation of health care. The epidemic has demonstrated the need for more integrated coordination in health care, with full respect for national sovereignty. Similarly, it is of paramount importance that the tourism sector is reopened and recovered as soon as possible, which has suffered almost the most damage as a result of the epidemic situation. This requires a coordinated, targeted programme and targeted support at European level, raising awareness of the sector that provides jobs for millions of Europeans. There is no question that one of the top priorities of the Portuguese Presidency must also be the unfurled and implementation of the Social Pillar, which is a significant backlog of the European community, and the coronavirus epidemic in particular has shown the Union that it is time to invest in people, in social inclusion.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the Council and Commission statements on the social and employment crisis during the COVID-19 pandemic and the EU's response to the reconstruction plan and the MFF (2020/2934(RSP)).

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, the COVID—19 pandemic has caused a once—in—a—generation crisis and is having a deep social and economic impact, which is likely to leave its mark on our societies for many years to come. Thousands of businesses have temporarily or permanently closed, millions of Europeans have lost their jobs and livelihoods, and almost all of us, in our own lives, have experienced a change to and, in some cases, have had to reshape our professional and private lives. All across Europe we have witnessed job losses, often with devastating effects for the people concerned, for their families and for the local communities. At the end of last year, almost 16 million people in the EU were unemployed, two million more than the year before. It is an appalling statistic, behind which there are countless people, countless stories, countless issues and the lives of people who were working and have now been pushed into poverty and precarity.  The COVID—19 pandemic has disproportionately affected the most vulnerable members of our society. It has laid bare existing systemic vulnerabilities and increased social inequalities to the detriment of those most disadvantaged. The pandemic has had a particularly strong impact on women. Our response to the continuing crisis and the recovery measures must therefore be designed in a gender—sensitive way. To this end, the Portuguese Presidency intends to table a set of Council conclusions on the impact of COVID—19 on gender equality in the labour market. The conclusions will form the basis of a forthcoming research note by the European Institute for Gender Equality.  Young people will also continue to disproportionately suffer the effects of this crisis. The reinforced Youth Guarantee, adopted by the Council in October, will help Member States better respond to the needs of young people and hence better target efficiency and monitoring.  We are now in the midst of a third wave of the virus, with even more contagious variants that have prompted stricter lockdowns in many Member States. Yet, at the same time, we are on the brink of hope that a vaccination can bring about the start of a long road to recovery. So the European social model that provided a cushion of support during this terrible period needs to be reinforced.  Although this crisis is grave, it would certainly have been far worse without the decisive action of the European Union and its Member States. At a time of difficulty, the EU showed unity, solidarity and flexibility, first addressing immediate emergency needs and then planning an ambitious recovery to make Europe more resilient, more competitive, just and sustainable for all future generations.  In the spring of 2020, we adopted the ESM Pandemic Crisis Support, the EIB Pan—European Guarantee Fund and SURE. While Member States fortunately did not need to activate their safety nets, thanks to the extremely favourable market financing conditions in 2020, EU workers benefited substantially from the support of SURE. All these measures were fundamental to support public action, enterprises and workers. We see that SURE has already been almost entirely utilised to support SMEs. We are also starting to see the benefits of the EIB support.  As for the recovery phase, we have come a long way since our leaders reached an agreement on the biggest ever MFF and on the unprecedented recovery instrument, the Next Generation EU, in July. These two instruments, amounting to more than EUR 1.8 trillion over the next seven years, are endowed with ambitious climate and digital targets and a focus on addressing challenges to employment, sustainability, resilience and competitiveness through reforms and investment. As such, they will enable the EU to provide both a much—needed cyclical stimulus and the right incentives to address structural issues in an ambitious way. While sharing the same objectives, the Council and Parliament had different views on how to structure this recovery plan. After intense, yet very constructive discussions and trilogues, we found political agreement on an ambitious text, which now needs to be swiftly voted on by the co—legislators, paving the way to the plan’s implementation. The Portuguese Presidency is indeed committed to steering the EU through a swift and efficient implementation of the instruments agreed in the course of the last year, ensuring a high degree of interinstitutional cooperation, flexibility and determination.  Addressing the social concerns of COVID—19 will be a key priority for our Presidency. We will seek to strengthen trust in the European social model, the importance of which became starkly clear during these troubling times. In this context, as you heard our Prime Minister say in this Chamber this morning, the Porto Social Summit that will take place in May will give impetus to the European social dimension and the European Pillar of Social Rights and its implementation plan, emphasising its central role in the European recovery and in adapting to the climate, digital and demographic transitions. We would like this summit to address the issues of employment. This morning, we were talking about jobs, jobs, and jobs. Indeed, we need to tackle this issue, and also skills, reskilling, innovation and social welfare to ensure that no one is left behind.  Resilience is part of the European identity, so to implement the European Pillar of Social Rights is the best vaccine against inequalities and fear. We have to tackle, and act quickly on all these fronts to fulfil the Portuguese Presidency motto: it’s time to deliver a fair, green and digital recovery. Thank you very much for your attention. I will remain here to answer your questions. (Applause)

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, 2021 should be the year opening the road to recovery. But this means first that we have to attain the objectives which have been set on the level of vaccination, because to defeat the virus we have to win this battle first. The Commission has indicated that our objective should be 70% of people vaccinated at the beginning of, or at least within, the next six or seven months. The second road to recovery is to maintain our strong will to contain the economic and social effects of the crisis thanks to the unprecedented efforts of the EU and the Member States.  As already described by the President, it is true that economic activity has been strongly impacted over the past year. And the outlook for 2021 remains uncertain because we do not know exactly what the evolution of the pandemic will be; thus the importance of vaccination.  The unemployment rate has increased – though it has increased less than one could have feared – and this is because Member States reacted, reacted through the introduction of massive short-time work schemes, with the support of the European Union. But the statistics do not tell us the whole story, yet millions of people have lost already their jobs and they are mainly the low-skilled, the low-paid workers, the temporary workers, the young on precarious work, and the most vulnerable. Precisely the most vulnerable people have been disproportionately hit, and after a clear improvement, poverty and inequalities are again on the rise. Moreover, the recovery will likely be uneven across Member States, across regions, across economic sectors and categories of workers. Therefore, we need a strong solidarity at all levels – at national levels, at regional levels, and, obviously, also at European level.  The EU support is all the more important to ensure a sustainable and inclusive recovery and economic and social upward convergence. The EU has been reactive and played a leading role to mitigate the negative effects of the crisis. The EU launched an unprecedented plan for reform and investment worth almost EUR 1.8 trillion, made up of long-term investments, financed by the Multiannual Financial Framework, more than one trillion, and one other financial instrument, the Next Generation EU with EUR 750 billion. The Recovery and Resilience Facility will fund reforms, as the President has just mentioned, on the one hand, and investments in every Member States. We have to build back better, and here investments are extremely important. We have to support growth and employment while boosting the green and digital transitions. We are not talking about any growth: we want sustainable growth and we want an inclusive growth. Cohesion funds have been boosted through the REACT-EU initiative, increasing the resources of the current programmes to address the social and economic impact of the crisis. The European instrument for temporary support to mitigate unemployment risks in an emergency, better known as SURE, has helped and is still helping Member States fund their short-time work schemes and similar schemes for the self-employed to mitigate the immediate economic impacts of the pandemic and the necessary confinement measures. In addition, euro area Member States agreed to make available a combined volume of around EUR 240 billion to help finance health-care, cure and prevention costs due to COVID-19 through the European Stability Mechanism.  Yet a surge in unemployment may have only been delayed rather than averted. That’s what I meant when I said ‘statistics do not tell us the whole truth’. High risks affecting the labour market exist as many sectors are unlikely to fully recover for some time, and many companies are already experiencing financial distress. While short-time work schemes have been effective in cushioning the blow and continue to be an important element of support at this critical juncture of the pandemic, they cannot be a durable solution, although we have to maintain them where necessary and combined, if possible, also with training and with skilling people in order to offer them new jobs. We need to set the conditions for future sustainable economic growth and a quality job-rich recovery. Investments, reforms, active labour market policies and skills for jobs are key.  We need a coherent package of active labour-market measures to support structural change and quality job creation by easing business restructuring where needed and facilitating the redeployment of labour, notably towards the green and digital economy, and that’s what the President of the Commission, Ms von der Leyen, said this morning. Yes, jobs, jobs, jobs, is key, but we do not want precarious jobs, especially not for the young. We want quality jobs.  The modernisation of labour market institutions, promotion of upskilling and re-skilling and reinforcement of social protection and health systems will be crucial to strengthen economic and social resilience and secure growth and employment in Europe, also in the medium and long term. This is all the more important as we see that some groups are hit especially hard. We must avert at all costs the risk of a new ‘lost generation’. Years of progress in bringing down youth unemployment risk being compromised, in particular with a view to those furthest from the labour market. Therefore, it’s now important to implement the Youth Employment Support (YES) programme that the Commission launched in July already and to translate it in concrete actions and also to integrate it in the measures financed by the recovery and resilience plans. Workers in non-standard forms of employment, above all temporary employees, are particularly vulnerable. Women are over-represented in sectors that are at the forefront of fighting the pandemic. Women are also particularly affected by the increase in unpaid care and domestic work. Equality, therefore, remains high on our agenda, not just for pay, but also for all the opportunities in the economy and therefore will have also, especially in the care sector, where three quarters of workers are women. We have to value this work in terms of recognition but also financial recognition. Children in low-income families are also at risk, in particular as distance learning has become a norm for many pupils. It really matters whether you have access to a computer, a good internet connection, a quiet place to study, and parents who are able to support you. There is a new ground for inequality, for inequality of opportunities that we really have to tackle. In general, health, education and social-protection systems, in particular social services, have been put under unprecedented pressure, further exacerbating challenges for people in the most vulnerable situations. This will continue to stress test the capacity of social protection. And finally, this is part of the resilience we have to strengthen. We have to do that in relation to adequacy, coverage and sustainability. This has come to the fore in view of ensuring socially fair transitions. Our action plan to further implement the European pillar of social rights is imminent. It will turn the pillar’s principles into concrete action for recovery and renewed upwards convergence in the EU. This will include an update of the pillar’s social scoreboard in a long-term view up to 2030. Many measures, from boosting skills to reforms to strengthening social protection systems, to investments in social housing, for children in need can be supported through the new funding instruments established on the Next Generation EU and the MFF. The European Parliament and the Commission have been able to strengthen the social dimension of the Recovery and Resilience Facility even further, and I’m more than grateful for that work which has been done in Parliament. The Cohesion Policy, including the ESF+ and the Just Transition Fund, will also play a critical role in supporting economic recovery, and the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for displaced workers can support workers who have lost their job due to restructuring.  This shows that we have formidable firepower, financially but also the tools, to turn the present challenges into opportunities. While building back our economies and societies, by boosting the green and digital transition, we need to set the conditions for achieving social progress. This is imperative for successful, fair, sustainable and inclusive recovery, and we will all meet in Porto to make these objectives very concrete.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the pandemic and fear of job loss are, without doubt, the two biggest concerns of citizens throughout Europe right now. All of our political decisions have to keep this in mind. We should do all we can to reduce the risks of the pandemic and the negative effects upon the people, upon the companies of Europe and upon the regions, and we have to do all we can to support the process of job creation. Unemployment is still projected to rise this year; we do not know exactly how much it will increase, because we will only know the magnitude of the economic crisis after COVID-19, after the lockdowns and once the economy returns to its full potential of activity. We therefore have to do two things for the time being: firstly, implement the decisions that we have taken; and secondly, stand ready to do more if needed. In terms of decisions taken – and the Commissioner and Minister rightly outlined many of these – I would like to highlight the recovery and resilience facility. Here at the European Parliament, with myself, Dragoș Pîslaru and Eider Gardiazabal Rubial as co-rapporteurs, we worked hard to ensure it was better suited to supporting the process of job creation, SMEs and the people affected by the crisis.  So what have we done? Firstly, we have created a special pillar, a social pillar, to help those affected by the pandemic, particularly women, because, Commissioner, you’re right, very often the burden upon them was bigger. Then there is an economic pillar – support for SMEs – and we also make very clear that solvency instalments are allowed at national level, so countries can use the money to support companies facing the risk of insolvency. To conclude: to the Member States, please present your national programmes to the Commission as soon as possible. To the Commission, please adopt them as soon as possible so that money can start flowing, so that we can start helping those affected. We, the European Parliament, will make use of our prerogatives in order to make sure that the plans presented by the countries enhance employment.

name: Manuel PIZARRO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, Commissioner Schmit, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, as the economic and social recession worsens, the vast majority of European citizens look to the European Union as a lifeline.  Let us be fair, without the Union, several Member States would have the shipwreck ahead of them today. The best proof of this is, moreover, the silence to which the populists who, for years, elected the European project as a scapegoat have been temporarily referred to. We can't fail.  The recovery plan and the new Multiannual Financial Framework provide a robust response to the crisis, stimulate economic and social investment and job creation, but we have a problem. The slow and bureaucratic rhythms of the European Union are not commendable with emergencies like the one we face today. We must ensure that the funds we are investing to support workers, businesses, health systems will in fact be able to be included in the recovery plan and the MFF.  We must move towards translating into binding rights the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights. I trust that the European Presidency exercised by my country, Portugal, will contribute to this plan, to this social Europe that we aspire to.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, Commissioner, Minister, dear colleagues, Romanians have a saying: 'the friend in need is known'. Only when you really need help will you realize who you can trust.  The Union has demonstrated in 2020 that it is a true friend of European citizens, touched by the worst medical, social and economic crisis in recent history. Renew Europe believes that our response through the recovery and resilience mechanism, through our ambition for the Multiannual Financial Framework, the response has been adequate.  The European Parliament, the Commission, the Council have been working on key issues, such as FEAD, REACT-EU, SURE, the European Social Fund to start the long road to healing.  Our chance is to become stronger. This crisis must be used to cure, but then to overcome old structural social problems. Access to education, health, the fight against poverty, social exclusion, discrimination, barriers to work must be the subject of our efforts further. We can no longer accept millions of children living without food safety or a stable roof over their heads. My call to European politicians: be ambitious, think long-term and think about citizens, prioritise in national plans for recovery and resilience investing in Europe's children and young people, in jobs with social impact that will create access and opportunity.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, Madam Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, there can be no economic recovery without social recovery. The finding is damning: with the crisis, the old continent is expected to have more than 30 million working poor, according to the European Social Observatory. I am thinking in particular of young people and women, who are most exposed to the economic and social consequences of the pandemic. Unfortunately, Europe's inability to overcome social crises is not a new fact.  However, in the mid-2000s, European Europe gave the impression that it was going to modernise its social policy agenda. In March 2008, the importance of the social dimension of the European Union was even an integral part of the Lisbon Strategy. However, in the following years, major concerns were focused on controlling public spending and structural reforms. Austerity became a key word in the public policy of the European Union and the social dimension virtually disappeared from the European political agenda.  Moreover, despite this observation, it is interesting to note that Brussels wants to strengthen the social dimension of economic and monetary union, while social and employment policies are very much within the competence of the Member States. This new federalist integration will run up against the reality of the multiple indicators reflecting European disparities on social issues.  Of course, Brussels has learned from its mistakes in previous crises, by creating the SURE programme to help workers keep their jobs, however, how will it be possible to effectively combine economic ambition with social and environmental ambition? Europe will finally have to clarify its priorities. Arbitrations on the recovery plans and the social summit in Porto, to be held next May, will be markers in order to know the will, feigned or real, of Brussels, of a radically more social-oriented reconstruction.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: verts/ALE Group. Madam President! I was in Brussels during the first lockdown, and here I saw that we stood on our balconies and applauded by the health and care staff. It was a wild feeling, and those people deserved the applause because they've been at the forefront of the corona fight. But applause is not enough at all. Women employed as the country's nurses are subjecting themselves and their families to illness every day. At the same time, it is one of the many women's professions that are underpaid and lack recognition. Indeed, the statistics show that we are far from both economic and social equality, and the health crisis has only exacerbated that.  We must ensure equal pay and we must close the pay gap! It is therefore more important than ever that the Commission gets off to a start soon and has its proposal on wage transparency presented. We have waited, and it is a huge failure of the hard-working women in the health and care sector, for this proposal to be postponed again. I therefore look forward to seeing the Commission's proposal. The corona crisis has also shown us that it is children and single parents and women and people with disabilities who are affected first. We therefore need to strengthen our social safety net through a European guarantee of minimum incomes.

name: Johan VAN OVERTVELDT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, Secretary of State, we reached an agreement at the end of last year on the multiannual budget and the corona fund. However, that is not the end of the work. That's really just the beginning of the work. We must now ensure that these resources are injected into the economy as quickly as possible. This is therefore a call on all Member States to ensure ratification as soon as possible.  The use of these resources should support the recovery, provide job creation and allow us to strengthen our health systems, but also – and this is often overlooked today – to keep the debt mountains that are now emerging and which are swelling every day manageable. This can only be done with economic growth. If we do not achieve that growth, we will have inflation and/or bankruptcies of sovereign states. Neither is an enticing evolution and will certainly put further pressure on the European house. So hopefully these funds will be well spent, that economic growth will come and what we've seen happen a little too much with the vaccines.  Vaccines offer the way out of corona pandemic and – let's admit it as politicians – the scientists have done more than their job. We have those vaccines available today, something that deserves credit. Nevertheless, the EU and the Member States have again failed to offer the added value that Europe really should offer. Crucial opportunities were missed. I find the choice of purchasing a portfolio of vaccines to be very defensible and legitimate, but it must also be scientifically based. Stories are now circulating in the German press as if Europe had ordered too late and too few vaccines for the sake of French interests. This creates the perception of political haggling, which is, of course, totally unacceptable in the present circumstances.  Even if there are sufficient vaccines available, there are apparently other problems. In Belgium today there is a shortage of syringes and hypodermic needles, yet another stock saga. Is this problem also present in other Member States and what European solutions are possible? We really need to get some answers to that.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Madam President, the reason I am here today is to ask you to declare a state of social emergency in Europe. As you said, Commissioner, the pandemic has caused poverty and precariousness to explode.  Students throw themselves out the window of their university room, Deliveroo delivery drivers line up at the Heart Restaurants. I saw them with my own eyes. They deliver food, but they don't have to eat for themselves. We are on the edge of the precipice and at our feet, in the abyss, there is one of the worst social crises in the history of mankind. So I ask you to listen to the cries of alarm of the associations that see the parade of laid-off workers, whole families, tenants caught in the throat. Political choices must no longer be made in the light of competition, the market or budgetary rigour, the situation forces us to drop all these dogmas, but the only thing that must now irrigate the decisions of the European Union is the social emergency. So I repeat to you, I beg you, let us declare a state of social emergency in Europe!

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: – Madam President, the pandemic has altered the global economic scenario. It has been a profound, social and economic crisis: closed companies, almost sixteen million Europeans without jobs. It has also significantly affected vulnerable sectors. There is no doubt that crises always hit the disability sector, women and all minorities more than they least have. Europe has given a solidarity response, a united response, an unprecedented historical response, putting on the table very strong actions, which represents more than 1.8 billion euros in order to achieve a more digital Europe, a more inclusive Europe, a more sustainable Europe, a more competitive Europe. In order to achieve these results, Member States have to act, and for that they have to make reforms: labour reforms, of the pension system; you have to focus a lot on economic sectors like my land, tourism. It's time to act. It's time for the truth. It is necessary that the batteries be set up in order to give an answer above all to these most vulnerable groups, because without them, without attending to them, they do not get out of this crisis.

name: Klára DOBREV
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. We have taken a huge step forward towards a much stronger and more united European Union. Social affairs and health have been member states' competences for a very long time. Yet in this epidemic, in this crisis, the European Union has done much more to contain the epidemic, much more to alleviate the social consequences than the governments of several Member States. Unfortunately, among them is Hungary government. Unprecedented funds have been mobilised by the European Union, and these funds have been used with unprecedented ease and flexibility. We really opened up the possibility of helping people directly. I would therefore like to thank the countries and governments of Europe for showing solidarity in the Council. From there, I would like to thank the European party families for putting aside their ability to agree on natural competition in Parliament, and from there I would like to promise everyone that this money will not go to illiberal dictators or oligarchs, but to where we intended them: to the people.

name: Marie-Pierre VEDRENNE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, ladies and gentlemen, this health shock today has above all social consequences and represents a source of multiple anxiety. Prime Minister Costa this morning reiterated the commitment needed for a fair, green and digital recovery. The goal that must animate us and remain: leave no one behind. As we know, many jobs are at risk. I am thinking of all the workers, especially bretons with the announcements of social plans to come by large groups. Together with others, with you, Commissioner, we have been working on an ambitious agreement on the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund for laid-off workers. Supporting and accompanying in the conversion, requalification, reintegration, is the raison d'être of this Fund and COVID becomes a reason for mobilization. On all fronts, Europe is acting, it must go further. Solidarity and social Europe is being built every day, but tomorrow it must be even more responsive and even more visible.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her The EU has failed at Corona – medically and economically. We have record death rates and the worst economic data in the world with the UK. China, meanwhile, is growing and writing record exports. Now the Commission is not ordering enough vaccines, and so more citizens and businesses are dying here unnecessarily than in Russia, China or Albania. To cover up failure, von der Leyen plans record spending of 1.8 trillion. In return, it borrows 750 billion in breach of the Treaty, because Article 310 TFEU requires that "the EU budget be balanced in revenue and expenditure", and 311 adds: "The EU budget is financed entirely from own resources, without prejudice to other revenue." But the illegal debts are not accounted for anywhere. The money is certainly for the Green Deal and the EU migration pact, even though the EU generates only 9% of all CO2 emissions and millions of migrants destroy our welfare state without developing Africa. All this is madness, it is not a stimulus package, but a Morgenthau plan for the deindustrialisation of Europe and a vision for the fastest way to the Third World. Those who have such visions must go to the doctor.

name: Damian BOESELAGER
text: – Madam President, we fought hard as the European Parliament, but also as the EU as a whole, for a strong EU recovery fund to counter this unprecedented crisis. We decided to raise an unprecedented amount of EUR 750 billion to be able to invest in the green and also the digital recovery and to get out of this crisis better than we went in. Now it’s time to fight equally hard to make sure that this money is put to good use, and for this I demand three things. First of all, that we ensure that every cent that is spent is transparently spent, that we know where this money is going. Second, that this money is used as additional money, that we make sure that we have new projects in the green and digital spaces, so we don’t just refinance existing pet projects of national governments. And third, that citizens are involved, that stakeholders are involved, and that most importantly our national governments are involved when we draw up these plans to make sure that the money is put to good use.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Minister, i would like to thank you very much for Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. The coronavirus pandemic has caused a serious economic crisis and, consequently, a social crisis in the world and in Europe, as reflected in the deep fall in GDP, even double-digit in the countries of the southern European Union, as well as double-digit increases in unemployment. The EU's response is the financial framework for 2021-2027, the Reconstruction Fund, as well as the already trillions of euros of public aid provided by Member States to their companies. I would like to express my hope that this Reconstruction Fund will be swiftly ratified in the twenty-seven Member States. If this does not happen, it could turn out to be a paper fund in 2021, and this will not allow the southern countries of the European Union in particular to emerge from the recession. Finally, the issue of state aid. Indeed, as I said, it is already in trillions of euros, but it is very uneven. Richer countries can afford it, less prosperous countries can afford less public aid. This, of course, will create distortions in the EU's common market and companies from less affluent countries will have serious problems to cope with competition.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: – Madam President, honoured and respected. At the moment, the debate on the social and employment crisis is only the tip of the iceberg, as rough statistics obscure the huge differences between Member States, regions and economic sectors. Nor do they reflect people's personal hardships and social differences that have deepened.  It is therefore crucial that we have measures to help alleviate this. By demonstrating that the social union is a possible direction for European integration. Even if European Union law is not in favour of social union, it is possible if there is a political necessity or will for it. Focusing on the weakest, closing the gender pay gap, improving working conditions and protection at work, investing in people's knowledge and skills, and strengthening social dialogue and collective bargaining must become our lasting response.  I hope that this year the current Portuguese and future Slovenian Presidencies of the Council of the EU will be able to convey the spirit of their social and human rights-oriented constitutions to european parquet floors and, together with us and the Commission, to strengthen the pillar of social rights. For the EU as a safe home for people.

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: – Madam President, hundreds of reports and analyses have already been produced taking into account the huge economic consequences of the Covid-19 pandemic, and the data are very worrying. It is important to me that the same attention is paid to the social consequences of this crisis. The state of emergency and the measures imposed have seriously affected vulnerable groups. This has led to an increase in inequality, poverty, unemployment and social disparities and could jeopardise the social model as well as employment standards in Europe.  I very much welcome the response given by the European Union in the MFF and the recovery plan. It should be based on the principles of economic and territorial cohesion, solidarity, social dialogue and transformation in order to ensure a fair green transition. It is now fundamental to avoid delays in the funds envisaged. Citizens need to feel the results of these investments as early as this year. The responsibility of the Member States is immense and it is in their plans that they reflect the specific needs of the population, providing for a set of reforms and measures to ensure a social recovery from the crisis.

name: Paolo BORCHIA
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I could list Eurostat data on employment or business death, but instead, as a warning, I am going to talk to you today about Mario Monti. Why Mario Monti? As a former European Commissioner, as President of the Italian Council, he put into practice with strict compliance the same budgetary dogmas that have tiptoed into the Recovery and Resilience Facility regulation with the following results: collapse of GDP, increase in unemployment, explosion of youth unemployment, worsening of the public debt ratio. I would like to cite Mario Monti to say that the implementation of the recovery plan and the budget will necessarily have to take account of the Commission's recommendations on macroeconomic imbalances. These are recipes that have caused disasters in the past – I am not saying this, Eurostat says, so Mario Monti at the time, it was February 2012, was applauded by this very plenary meeting in Strasbourg. And so I say to you, think about it, because first come the people and then the budgetary rules.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The social crisis and the employment crisis during the COVID-19 pandemic are the effects of this pandemic that will stay with us for longer. Hence the questions: what action has already been taken, is the level of funding sufficient, what will be and is the effectiveness of the mitigation instruments used? We have to wait for some answers. The crisis continues. Protecting jobs, maintaining employment and fighting for every workplace has become a major challenge, reducing social impacts such as rising poverty, social inequalities, difficult access to health care, the deteriorating situation of the elderly, the sick and the disabled.  Poland, my country, is an example of a country that has effectively protected its labour market through its support instruments so far, using its own resources and EU support. Poland has benefited from the SURE programme and is preparing a national recovery plan to benefit from the Instrument for Reconstruction and Resilience. Vaccination is an opportunity for all of us, but if we want a healthy economy and a modern labour market, we must implement innovative solutions and not be afraid of reforms.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Mr President, Minister Zacarias, Commissioner Schmit, the impact of this pandemic on the economy and on employment on public finances is still incalculable. It is imperative to protect citizens in health, but also to do everything to prevent job destruction, accentuate inequalities and asymmetries, increase social exclusion.  The European Union has built a European response to recovery, this time with the political ambition and funding needed to achieve it. The social dimension must be an important pillar in economic and social recovery plans, funded by the Recovery Fund, promoting investment and creating jobs. The transition to digital and climate cannot generate new poor and new inequalities. On the contrary, they have all the conditions to generate sustainable and quality employment, employment with rights, decent employment.  Economic and social recovery will only be effective if people are at the heart of policies.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Madam President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, ladies and gentlemen, the health crisis has spared no one: employers, employees, associations, the most vulnerable. So, of course, we have not come out of the crisis but I am hopeful because we are all working on it relentlessly. I would like to pay tribute to European action here. The social Europe, the Europe that protects us, that protects the citizens, that protects you and me, was not a given before the crisis. Since then, its necessity has become clear, as we have seen with this European mechanism to support partial unemployment insurance systems. In practical terms, some people were able to receive aid from their state because Europe was in support. Those with the strongest kidneys gave pledges to ensure the most vulnerable have the ability to finance themselves. This is European solidarity! Commissioner, Secretary of State, we still have a long way to go to get out of the crisis, but what we have done with the unemployment insurance mechanism, with the recovery plan, with the European budget and its various negotiated instruments is laying the groundwork for a social and solidarity Europe. We should welcome that.

name: Robert ROOS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, every plenary week we debate in this House on matters that do not belong here at all. Also this week. Social policy and employment are not the eu's business. These are eminently national matters, and with good reason: this type of policy must be close to people, made within the Member States. In my case: for Dutch people, by Dutch people.  I appreciate the efforts of colleagues here, but the reality is that you are spending a lot of time on initiatives outside the EU's treaty law base. Agreements on powers between the EU and the Member States will be stretched until Brussels has a foot in the door on another policy area. That is, ladies and gentlemen, the way this institution works. And a crisis is always abused for that.  Brussels meddling undermines our national clout when, now more than ever, we need it to overcome the corona crisis.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we share a lot of elements in the analysis and I believe that there is a broad consensus on urgency and seriousness. What is important is to implement the measures now and I think we all need to be aware that this time it has to be different.  This morning, the president advocated what she called a new social rulebook. This underlines the importance of the social dimension in these policies. This is what the citizens are asking us, that Europe, that the European Union, like the Member States, like all the actors, be listening to them, or close to their problems, their difficulties.  And first and foremost, there is the stimulus, but the stimulus only works if it is implemented quickly. So I absolutely share what has been said, first of all about the presentation of the national plans and the rapid implementation of those plans. This also implies - and I agree with the calls that have been made by the President of Parliament and repeated here - that national parliaments and governments must do their job by ratifying the financial frameworks so that, in fact, the stimulus packages and in particular the related resources can be implemented. Yes, job creation is central. We are in a triple crisis. A health crisis that we hope to control thanks to vaccines, but also a fundamental transformation, which has been accelerated by this digital crisis. A revolution that affects many jobs, many companies, especially SMEs. And I agree that job creation must be at the heart of our concerns, especially through support for SMEs, new businesses, start-ups, those who invent the technologies of tomorrow.  But at the same time we must prepare all those who risk losing their jobs tomorrow to these new deadlines, to these new challenges and thus the investment in skills, in skills for both young people and also the less young is crucial. So I think what we have started with the various measures on training, of course we are not going to do it between now and Brussels, we are going to do it with the companies, with the social partners, with the regions, with the municipalities, wherever there is a transition to be made.  I have listened to what some colleagues have said about regions or rising unemployment. And then Europe must be present on the ground by helping, facilitating transitions and bringing people to employment, not towards a vague future that will be made up of unemployment and exclusion but towards solid jobs, quality jobs. That is the challenge, that is the challenge, together we have to take it on.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, I think I’ve heard a lot of consensus in that 2021 should be the year for recovery, with the rollout of the vaccination processes and with the support of the financial recovery instruments. We have the vision, we have the programmes and we have the budget. So we have the responsibility to succeed. And to succeed, we have to put the people at the centre of our policies. This is very clear. We need to work now to have an immediate impact on the lives of people with the national recovery plans and, at the same time, we need to push for reforms and economic and social investment that will have a long-term impact, addressing structural issues that became even more evident under the focus of the pandemic. Some of you said that the EU has already done a lot. This is true, and we should be happy about that, but we need to continue to do our utmost to help Member States protect Europeans from the social and economic consequences of this crisis. To this end, we need quickly to finalise the pending legislative work and move towards the implementation phase before the summer. We need to avoid delays. Recovery has to be anchored in sustainability, in innovation, in gender equality, and in upward social cohesion. We have to take care of the young and we also have to take care of the old, because we have seen the ravages that this crisis has taken on our older population too. Protecting Europeans from the adverse effects of the COVID—19 crisis will therefore remain high on our agenda. This trio of Presidencies – the current trio and the next trio of Presidencies – have already discussed this matter and will take this forward. So the Council is ready to continue working on these issues, together with the Parliament and the Commission. Thank you, Commissioner, for the proposals put forward. We look for the best solutions to meet this daunting challenge that we are all facing, and we need to face it together. (Applause)

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: in writing. – The current pandemic has led to a social and employment crisis, already generating an upward trend in rising unemployment, worsening working conditions, as well as an increase in inequalities and poverty in Europe. The main objective of the recovery plan and new MFF is to mitigate the negative effects of this crisis, in all its forms. However, from a social point of view, we need more. We need to emphasize to a greater extent the social dimension within these recovery mechanisms, so that we can actually achieve a socially sustainable Europe and leave no one behind. We also need the new financial framework to increase the esSE+ budget, the only instrument aimed at alleviating the dire social effects caused by this crisis, implementing the Pillar of Social Rights, and implementing measures that are a priority for Socialists, such as the Children's Guarantee. In short, a vast budget, ensuring the obligation to meet social objectives, as well as the establishment of concrete and tangible indicators of social investment included in the European Semester and national recovery plans.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "We have changed the word crisis in the last year by all cases. The COVID-19 pandemic has led to increased unemployment, increased social inequalities, deepening poverty among Europeans, collapse of health and education systems. Despite its limited competences in many of these areas, the European Union has already done a great deal to help Member States in their fight against the crisis. There has been a great deal of flexibility in the disburse of EU funds, the Commission has adopted a temporary State aid framework to support firms at risk, the SURE instrument to reduce the risks associated with unemployment has been implemented, and the FEAD instrument has been put in place to enable food or material assistance to those most in need. Finally, a new budget was adopted and EUR 750 billion was allocated to the Reconstruction Plan for Europe. However, this is only the beginning of our efforts. The true extent of the crisis will probably only come to an end once the pandemic has subsided. At this point, we must first of all focus on a rapid and thoughtful vaccination strategy that would give us a chance to return to normality. That is why I am pleased that we have used the mechanism of joint purchase of vaccines. Member States should also present recovery plans as soon as possible. Social dialogue with regions, social partners and entrepreneurs is important in this context. We must listen to the voice of the citizens. The proper use of resources must also be ensured. Every euro must be used to bring the greatest possible benefit to our economies and citizens.

name: Dan-Ştefan MOTREANU
text: in writing. – The current health crisis, unprecedented in recent history, has caused a considerable loss of income and jobs, with the unemployment rate reaching 7.6% in October 2020, with already disadvantaged workers, such as young people and those on temporary contracts, being disproportionately affected. At the same time, the difficulties faced by young people in accessing the labour market were accentuated, including as a result of the increasing lysiled processes of transition from education to work. I would like to welcome the adoption of the Council's recommendation on strengthening the Youth Guarantee, an important tool in many Member States, which has in recent years helped to improve the lives of millions of young people through offers of good quality jobs, continued education or participation in apprenticeship or traineeship programmes. I would like to stress in this way the importance of increasing complementarity between the European Social Fund+ and the Recovery mechanism and resilience in order to establish at national level enhanced programmes for young people to provide them with new opportunities and skills in emerging areas such as digitalisation and the green transition.

name: Guido REIL
text: Writing. – Chairman, officially it is said that the funds of the created Reconstruction Fund, 750 billion euros, serve to reduce the economic and social consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic. In reality, however, they serve to achieve the objectives of the inviolable Green Deal and represent an important step towards the completion of a debt and transfer union. This is a label hoax. After the bad British leave, of course, there is much less money to spend, but you don't want to cut back. Spending more and more money is the message. That is why new funds are being made available through a new budget. The German Chancellor has always assured the Germans that there will never be joint debt. Now there is indeed common debt and there is no way back. The fact that the EU is taking on debt, even though it does not have its own statehood and financial sovereignty, that the money is distributed past parliaments and its right to house, is a violation of democracy and law. The end result is that in this transfer union, 40 percent of the EU population co-finances the remaining 60 percent.

name: Domènec RUIZ DEVESA
text: in writing. – The current pandemic has led to a social and employment crisis, leading to worsening working conditions and increasing inequalities and poverty in Europe. The recovery plan and the new MFF are primarily aimed at mitigating the negative effects of the health and economic crisis. However, from a social point of view, we need more. We need to further promote the social dimension within these recovery mechanisms, in order to truly achieve a socially sustainable Europe. We also need the new financial framework to increase the esSE+ budget, the only instrument aimed at alleviating the dire social effects caused by this crisis, implementing the European Pillar of Social Rights, and implementing measures that are a priority for Socialists, such as the Children's Guarantee. In short, a strengthened European budget which together with the Next Generation EU recovery plan financed by the issuance of European federal debt, together with new own resources, must ensure the obligation to meet social objectives, as well as the establishment of concrete and tangible indicators of social investment included in the European Semester and national recovery plans

name: Ernő SCHALLER-BAROSS
text: Writing. – While Portugal, which is the Rotating Presidency of the Council of the European Union, is announcing a social turnaround, effective management of the economic crisis is the only way to prevent the social crisis. This calls for economic solutions, not the withdrawal of member states' social policy powers. The Hungarian left has once again betrayed itself: Klára Dobrev is sithing for a European superstate and wants to regulate social policy centrally. Instead of building a United States of Europe, we need measures at EU level that effectively support job creation, wage growth and support for families. The European Union must develop a solution so that its Member States emerge stronger from the crisis and not just get through it. The Hungarian Government has announced an economic protection action plan in view of the crisis caused by the epidemic, which includes, in addition to business financing, the retention of jobs, job creation and the protection of families. With the help of the Economic Protection Action Plan, 1500 billion HUF extra capacity expansion will be implemented in the Hungarian economy. Businesses forced to close temporarily due to epidemiological measures will be supported by the Hungarian Government by taking over two thirds of wage costs in December 2020 and January 2021. The results of the stabilisation and economic recovery package are already being felt in the strengthening of employment and the economy. Small and medium-sized enterprises are considered to be the most vulnerable economic operators during the pandemic. A roadmap with specific objectives is needed to substantially reduce the administrative burden on SMEs.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. – After the time of political consultation, solidarity coordination and the design of pandemic response tools, this is a time to focus all efforts on action, promoting ratifications and completing the legal framework so that resources can reach people and businesses quickly and are useful, in emergency responses and also on the structural transformations that the European Union needs. Discussions and institutional decisions have allowed for decisive alignment between the priorities of national governments, the Portuguese Presidency of the European Union, the European Council, the Commission and Parliament. With strong legitimacy, we share a vision, programs and funding. The next step is, through national programmes and European programmes, to involve the whole of society in its implementation, putting people at the centre, focusing on requalification and preserving employment and ensuring that the energy and digital transition takes on a social dimension, ensuring that it will not be the poorest or the most vulnerable to bear its costs.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the report by Lucia Ďuriš Nicholsonova, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) No 223/2014 with regard to the introduction of specific crisis response measures with COVID-19 (COM(2020)0223 - C9-0151/2020 - 2020/0105(COD)) (A9-0174/2020).

name: Lucia ĎURIŠ NICHOLSONOVÁ
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President. The current pandemic crisis has serious economic and social consequences for almost everyone. However, it has been paid the most, in all Member States, by people at risk of poverty. These people don't care if and when they go on an exotic vacation. These people are working out whether they can even afford to pay for hot food for themselves and their children or to warm up in the house. As a result of the pandemic, the rise in unemployment will be huge and the reduction in people's living standards will be extreme for millions of Europeans. But if living standards are falling for people who have already started from the poverty line, we need to act quickly to save them and we need to act effectively. And that's how I see FEAD, the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived. Help from it must be quick, it must be targeted, flexible and material. In my own country, Slovakia, after the first wave of the pandemic, the number of households freezing in winter has increased significantly, literally because they cannot pay for the heat. After the first wave of the pandemic, almost eight percent of households in Slovakia were in a situation where they could not pay their electricity bills. This is a huge increase compared to 2016, when it was 5 per cent of such households. Currently, 16 percent of families live in Slovakia, including families with young children who are trapped in poverty. Since the covid-19 outbreak, the situation has worsened for more than twenty per cent of European Union citizens at risk of poverty and social exclusion. The European Aid Fund for the Most Deprived is precisely the instrument that helps people in need on the way out of poverty and from social exclusion. Through the Fund, states can provide food and basic material assistance, but also immaterial aid to cover basic needs for those most in need. Since its inception in 2014, FEAD has assisted 13 million people a year, including four million children living in poverty in the European Union. The crisis has exacerbated social disparities and inequalities. Member States need to draw money from the European Aid Fund to help the most vulnerable. Of course, the crisis also has a negative impact on the ability of partner organisations to deliver aid to those who are dependent on it. Today, the staff of partner organisations must be protected themselves in order to be able to deliver material assistance where it is needed. That is why, as part of the revisions to the FEAD Regulation, we are taking exceptional measures that are a direct response to the deteriorating situation not only of those who are dependent on aid, but also of those who ensure that they receive aid. I would also like to thank the Commission very much; The revised regulation will allow Member States to also benefit from additional FEAD resources of up to 100 percent. It will be up to the Member States to decide how much additional resources are being made from REACT-EU to FEAD, and this will only be done according to how much resources one or another country will need to help the most vulnerable populations affected by the crisis, be they families affected by job losses, single mothers with dependent children, or elderly and sick citizens, or people living in separate and segregated communities. , such as Roma settlements. In doing so, they will have to stick to the principles of integration and non-discrimination and equality from a gender perspective, all in accordance with the Charter of Rights of the European Union. The good news for the Member States is that they can apply for 100% of European money, which means that aid from the Fund can be paid without restrictions, without delays and without burdening national budgets. I am really pleased that we have agreed on all these important elements, and I firmly believe that, thanks to this review, the aid that is so important now and in the current crisis will reach all vulnerable citizens who need it.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, we just had a debate on the social and employment consequences of the crisis, and now we are discussing one of the most dramatic impacts of this crisis on real lives, which are under pressure, under threat – the lives of people who are suddenly in deep poverty. The social impact of this pandemic is primarily affecting precisely the most deprived, and demands for additional material and social support are rising, because some people – who never imagined they would find themselves in such a situation – from one day to the next have lost their jobs, they have lost their businesses, they have lost their income, and they are facing deep social problems, deep poverty. In many Member States, we see the queues at food banks and soup kitchens becoming longer and longer, and joining them are people who never thought their lives would go this way.  Thank you for the presentation and the introduction, and also for setting out the dramatic consequences. We have a duty to protect the most vulnerable during this crisis. That is why I thank you, Madam rapporteur and the Parliament, for having quickly concluded on the regulation amending the existing Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived, or FEAD. I particularly thank Madam Nicholsonová, Chair of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, who has led the work on this file, and also the shadow rapporteurs.  As has already been said, with this amendment we are ensuring that we can mobilise fresh money for 2021 and 2022 for the most deprived people through the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived, as part of our overall EU crisis response. Our contacts in the Member States signal that these possible top—ups will be well used, and we estimate that they will inject substantial amounts of fresh money into the FEAD. It is our joint mission for the additional funding to swiftly reach the most deprived. So we will already pay 11% of the 2021 allocation as initial pre—financing.  The support for the most deprived is also part of the European Social Fund Plus proposal, which is still waiting for an interinstitutional agreement by the co-legislators. Progress was made under the German Presidency and I’m very hopeful that under the rapporteur and the Portuguese Presidency, we can come to a rapid conclusion. I also want to thank all those in the NGOs who, day after day, are committed to helping the people who are close to despair. I think we have to recognise their work, their commitment, their help, their solidarity. They are perhaps one of the best aspects of Europe.

name: David CASA
text: f'isem group PPE. - Sinjura President, il-flus li qed nitkellmu fuqhom huma kru大jali fil-ħajja ta' dawk l-aktar vulnerabbli fis-so大jetajiet tagħna. name: Brando BENIFEI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EAFD programme, the Fund to support the most deprived people, is an irreplaceable and indispensable instrument for the European Union because it provides direct aid to those most in need for billions of euros through material assistance, such as the provision of food and basic necessities, or through programmes to promote their social inclusion. For the European Parliament, the defence of the EAFD is an absolute red line, including in the ongoing negotiations on the new European Social Fund Plus, which will include it internally. I would like to say this to my colleagues present from the new Portuguese Presidency: the EAFF today allows thousands of organisations across Europe to finance projects to combat poverty on the front line, which are essential to give dignity to people in need, thanks to accompanying measures, psychological support, training, administrative and legal assistance. It allows the financing of food stamps and vouchers for families and individuals in need. It allows the canteens of the poor to operate in continuity in their service. Today in all European countries, also due to COVID-19, the rows at these canteens are stretching frighteningly. That is why, thanks to REACT-EU, Europe is making an additional EUR 55 billion available for inclusion and social cohesion policies. The national administrations, with these amendments to the regulation, can and must today strengthen their EAFD programme, pending the new regulation. Let us not lose our sense of reality: here we really talk about the survival and dignity of so many people.

name: Dragoș PÎSLARU
text: on behalf of the Renew group. – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to thank rapporteur Lucia Nicholsonová, with whom I have worked very well on this new review of the fund.  Renew Europe supported the Commission's proposal and contributed substantially to the debates. We are pleased with this increase in the amounts that will go to people who need so much help in these dark pandemic days.  In Romania, FEAD is implemented through POAD, the Operational Programme for Helping Disadvantaged Persons. For these people in vulnerability the 3% percentage with which we increase funding can make the difference between life and death.  It is important for the Member States to do two things now: to make the most of this opportunity, but also to ensure that the source of this funding is communicated appropriately. Money must be transformed into food and materials vital to those who cannot afford it, distributed efficiently, widely, using all the necessary means in all regions, especially in the most difficult or remote. The use of this increase is voluntary indeed, but I believe that the Member States should take advantage of it. Last but not least, this programme needs to be communicated better, it is a direct, European, united response to the suffering of the vulnerable, it is an argument for a stronger Europe with increased prerogatives.

name: France JAMET
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this pandemic is the catalyst for what is already an unprecedented economic and social crisis, compounded by the dramatic inadequacy of The Europeanist policies that have eliminated one by one the basic tools of sovereignty. This report therefore proposes to adapt the regulation of the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived in response to the explosion of poverty. Yes, we must help our businesses, we must help our compatriots plunged into poverty and for this we must make good use of what could pass here for the largesse of the European Union, but which is in fact concerning the money taken from the taxpayers' pockets.  However, the explanatory statement of this text is confusing, indicating that the data that will be used to establish the distribution of funds will be collected and established by so-called specialized NGOs. Beyond the fact that these NGOs would arrogate the prerogatives of the States, many of them are highly politicized and serve their own ideological purpose above all. Nor should this pandemic be an excuse to give free rein to the political glories of technocracy. Let her not forget that the poor she claims to help today have been plunged into distress and destitution by their own policies: no borders, free trade agreements, relocations, deindustrialization. This is in fact the assessment of European globalist policy.

name: Katrin LANGENSIEPEN
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the coronavirus let the poorest suffer the hardest : the homeless, Roma, children living in low-economic-resource households, more often women than men, persons at risk. The list is long. I’m worried that if help for the poorest is not immediately provided the consequences will be severe.  As Greens/EFA shadow of the FEAD proposal I’m therefore happy to see that this afternoon we will vote on a file that includes the need of a social sustainable and resilient recovery and stresses the feminisation of poverty. But not only that. We Greens also welcome that the proposal boosts funding by pre-financing and by inviting the Member States to boost the fund. FEAD is an instrument that reaches out to the most deprived with very direct support that makes a real difference on the ground.  So for this afternoon I urge you all to vote for funds, for basic food, basic material, and special social inclusion measures. Let’s vote in favour of FEAD.

name: Elżbieta RAFALSKA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. In a prosperous Europe, we still have enclaves of poverty and a deep diversity of poverty. Before the pandemic crisis, 13 million people, including as many as 4 million children, benefited from the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived. This shows the scale of the problem. In the crisis and after the crisis, the number of people in need of food support will increase rapidly. Today we see it. Particular attention should be paid to the elderly, people with disabilities, chronically ill people, single people, homeless people. Quick and well-organised assistance is needed.  A partial response to these growing needs is the revision of the FEAD Regulation, including the key to increasing additional resources. However, setting a mandatory 3% share for all these measures may limit the freedom of action of governments. Time is pressing for us. The priority is to enter into force of the Regulation as soon as possible with a view to mobilising additional resources without delay, a revision of operational programmes, as well as the purchase of food and the rapid referral of food to the most deprived persons.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Madam President, during this debate the EGf was discussed as a consensual instrument, a last-line instrument that gathers the support of all political groups.  Unfortunately, in another process, the European Social Fund process, we are having a very difficult negotiation with the Council which, at a time when this instrument is much more necessary, wants less funding for this instrument.  It is therefore very important that we take this consensus that we have in the European Parliament to put pressure on the Council to take measures to finance this instrument that is up to the needs, but we also need, because this is a last-line instrument, to change the way we think, the economic response to crises, in particular the rules of economic governance because the objective of the European Union and our collective objective cannot be to have instruments to distribute food goods. It has to be a prosperity society in which these instruments are not needed.

name: Ioannis LAGOS
text: Madam President, the crisis created by the corovirus has brought great problems all over the world, let alone to European citizens. We have therefore seen that there is a major problem with regard to the human status of citizens. We are talking about money, we are talking about numbers, and we are doing well, because money and aid must be given to ordinary citizens; What kind of life are we going to have? How will a man live when he does not live with his family, when he cannot hug his relative, he cannot hug his child, he cannot go out with two friends to go somewhere and live as he should.  There are big issues here and there is a complete terrorism that has taken place on the issue of corovirus. I personally see some things that I cannot understand; say, we can get on the subway, on the bus, on public transport, that we are stuffed with too many other people, but we cannot get in our car, be with two other people, our family. How is that possible? I can buy a coffee or a sandwich and rely on the stairs to eat, but I'm not allowed to sit on chairs. So we have to look at this, see why we got there, and I want to say — one last point — that the money should not be given to NGOs;

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to Lucia as rapporteur and to the shadow rapporteurs for the good work. However, it has to be said that we are grateful for a work that must be said: sad that it must be done at all, that there is a need for it at all. The European Union is a place of longing for millions of people in the world. But it is precisely the work on this dossier that shows us that, even in a place that is a place of longing for many millions of people around the world, there are en masse problems, there is mass poverty. I believe that the path we are releasing today for additional funding, including an extension of the programme, is not only an important aid for those affected, but is also an extremely important pointer. Because I always notice this in conversations with groups of visitors who say: yes, with you in the European Union, with you in Parliament, there is always the interests of corporations, of entrepreneurs, of big bosses, of important people, for the little people there is nothing in it anyway. With you in Brussels, everything always lasts so long. I can only say that what we have now got here at FEAD – even within a very short period of time – actually proves exactly the opposite: this Europe has a big heart and has in mind those who have really been hit massively by this crisis. So thank you for your work at this point.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, try to stay in the class when you have to go to school without breakfast. For many children, this is the daily reality. In a rich country like the Netherlands, more than 270 000 children are growing up in poverty. Even when the parents both work hard, there are children who have to go to school without a lunch box. I find that heartbreaking and unacceptable. Poverty inhibits people and stops development. We really need to get rid of that.  I am therefore very pleased with these additional resources in this corona crisis for the Fund for European Aid to the most deprived. From here on, I call on my colleagues in The Hague to make direct use of the funds from this fund, especially now that there is no government. We must now combat poverty by investing more in children.

name: Sylvie BRUNET
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I welcome this second revision of the European Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived (FEAD) regulation since the beginning of the COVID-19 crisis in order to adapt it to the health, economic and social crisis affecting the most vulnerable in all the countries of the European Union. Indeed, this revision will make it possible to fight poverty more effectively by increasing the appropriations from the REACT-EU initiative and the pre-financing in support of actions on the ground. In France, one third of food aid is financed by European funds and the demand has unfortunately increased by about 30% with young people, the elderly, women who for the first time use this aid. This is to say how much Europe's action was expected by the major associations and actors in charge of the distribution of food aid and I would like to take this opportunity to thank them for their unwavering commitment. I regret, however, that the obligation to devote a minimum share of REACT-EU's available resources to the abounding OF the FEAD has been waived in the negotiations with the Council: the allocation of resources will remain voluntary and without a minimum percentage, whereas all Member States should be able to move in the same direction. I keep saying that we will not be able to succeed in Europe in the environmental and digital transition by leaving more and more people on the side of the road.

name: Maxette PIRBAKAS
text: Mr President, dear Commissioner, I would like to speak today for my fellow Guadeloupeans, Martinique, Reunion, Guyanese and Mahorais, who are also affected by the health crisis that is hitting us. It should be noted that ultramarine companies, such as Guadeloupe, have lost 83% of their exports, which will result in direct and indirect job losses throughout the island. In this period of health, social and economic crisis, for me, it is urgent to act without delay for the poorest and most deprived of our ultramarine compatriots in order to guarantee a minimum to survive. Today, our insularity and remoteness are creating more pronounced factors of poverty, which will have to lead to stronger aid in order to support families in French overseas departments. I say to you, ladies and gentlemen, the ambition of the recovery driven by the Member States and our Parliament must include strongly the outermost regions, including the five French overseas departments. Colleagues, believe me, it is important for us to fight poverty in overseas departments. We must react together, together for our territories so far from Europe.

name: Radan KANEV
text: – Mr President, today we are discussing further European assistance to our fellow citizens most affected by the corona crisis – those living in extreme poverty. I support this initiative because I am a representative of a country where poverty is a major problem where hundreds of thousands rely on temporary work, often abroad, to feed their families, and many have been deprived of the crisis even by this minimum income. But I also want to draw your attention to another person of the problem. The danger is that tens of thousands of families as a result of the crisis will fall into a state of extreme poverty. The pandemic literally took away the bread of free artists, thousands of self-employed persons, owners of small and family companies. Until yesterday, representatives of the middle class, they are now income-free, with overdue mortgages and accumulated debts, and in some European countries, among which unfortunately bulgaria is, they are abandoned outside the protection of economic measures. This Parliament, together with the Commission, has a duty to address the problem, to ensure that the European budget is indeed spent on the most affected, to prevent millions of European citizens and families from becoming innocent victims of poverty.

name: Anne SANDER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the poorest are bearing the brunt of the health, economic and social crisis linked to COVID-19. In this very particular period, more and more people are falling into great precariousness. Logistical and human resource constraints, particularly as a result of containment measures and social distancing, are increasingly hampering the distribution of basic food and material aid, as well as support for social inclusion.  Many volunteers, and I would like to salute them, who are pillars of the front can no longer mobilize as easily because some also, it must be said, belong to groups at higher risk of serious diseases. There are also older people among them.  It is therefore the whole chain of solidarity and assistance to the most vulnerable that is weakened by this pandemic.
