To deal with this very worrying situation, it is Europe, it is the European Union that is at the rendezvous, and I am therefore very pleased that the measures we have already taken, which we will take, will help to combat this great precariousness. This report complements the previously adopted FEAD regulation and will unlock additional resources. It is essential, it is a beautiful testimony of Europe in solidarity, close to the needy, Europe which has heart.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank all those who have spoken and expressed this support and solidarity with the poorest, with those who are most affected by this crisis and who are indeed sometimes pushed to the very brink of despair. I believe that what has just been said by many of you, the message that starts from here, brussels or Strasbourg, is a message not only from the heart, but it is a message of solidarity and it is also a side of Europe that is often underestimated and misunderstood. This is the message that Europe does care about all its citizens. As indeed, it must be concerned about all its territories, including the outermost regions. The Commission thanks you once again for your work, including the rapporteur, and she pledges to implement this regulation very quickly and to work with determination with all those on the ground who are implementing this aid to the poorest so that they can get by.  So there is a clear link to the stimulus package, because we do not want to leave people in poverty. And I agree, it's a job that we have to do but ultimately it would be better not to have to do it. And so the recovery and by the same toy the exit of this precariousness, this is our objective, hence the importance of the recovery plan.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place today, Wednesday, 20 January 2021. Written declarations (Rule 171)

name: Atidzhe ALIEVA-VELI
text: in writing. – The Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived is an expression of European solidarity with the most deprived in our societies. Now, in the face of the Kovid-19 pandemic and the uncertainty that is in store for millions of people, this solidarity is more necessary than ever. It is important that Member States increase support to food delivery organisations, basic material assistance and support for social inclusion for those in need most, and this is now possible with almost EUR 48 billion available under REACT-EU. I call on the Member States to make the most of these additional resources and to make use of this additional funding available to ensure that those hardest hit by the crisis receive the support they need quickly in these precarious times of health crisis. Combating poverty and social exclusion is common and our goal is to ensure a rapid, sustainable recovery. I am extremely pleased that a special focus has also been placed on the fact that the crisis has affected many more women who work mainly in the field of services and are on the frontline in the fight against the pandemic and that this must be reflected in the allocation of funds.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Kim Van Sparrentak, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on access to decent and affordable housing for all (2019/2187(INI)) (A9-0247/2020). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  Remote intervention is also planned from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Kim VAN SPARRENTAK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, dear Commissioner Schmit, thank you for being here today, dear colleagues, today we are discussing the report on access to decent and affordable housing for all, because we are facing a housing crisis in Europe. From Paris to Warsaw, Dublin to Athens, an increasing number of people in the EU are struggling to afford the rising cost of housing. Even before the start of the pandemic, one in ten Europeans were spending more than 40% of their income on housing. And not only the price, but also the quality of housing is a problem. Far too many people in Europe are living in overcrowded, damp, poorly-insulated, or otherwise unhealthy homes, with unaffordable utility bills. We can’t just be bystanders; this housing crisis is affecting people from all demographics: young people who are forced to stay with their families longer than they want because they can’t afford a place of their own; people who are thinking of starting a family but are postponing this since they still live in a studio, for which they can only just make the rent; elderly people who would like to move out of their family home but can’t afford to get an adjusted apartment, whilst young families are desperately waiting for a family home to move into. And this is the housing crisis for those that actually have a home, because the sad reality still is that more than 700 000 people sleep rough every night in Europe, and this number keeps on rising year after year in the last decade. This report recognises that access to decent and affordable housing is a fundamental right, a right that is guaranteed at EU level. This can’t just remain nice words, colleagues. And as a rapporteur on this topic in the European Parliament, it has become clear to me that the European rules today are often better at protecting the making of profit on the housing market than at protecting people who need a roof over their head. This has to change. We need the EU to step up its game and do its part with all the tools it has at its disposal to tackle the housing crisis, side by side with the Member States and local level that of are, of course, crucial. The report offers concrete solutions for the Commission, the Member States, and the local level to take action. And for this, I also want to thank the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I had a very pleasant collaboration. Because we can solve the housing crisis if we want to. We can end homelessness by 2030. Homelessness is an extreme form of poverty and a violation of human rights. In the coming six months, the Commission will propose its action plan on the European Pillar of Social Rights that addresses homelessness in its Principle 19. And the topic is high on the agenda of the Portuguese Presidency. The Commission should be bold and dare to propose a social moonshot strategy: an EU level goal together with all the Member States to end homelessness by 2030. Commissioner Schmit, I’m very happy that you’ve already shown your willingness to work on this, and the European Parliament with this report makes also a strong call to tackle homelessness once and for all. Let’s be partners and put the collaboration platform on homelessness that has been announced to work with a clear and ambitious target. We can also increase investments in affordable housing. Since the financial crisis, we have an average annual investment gap in affordable and social housing of EUR 57 billion per year. We need to urgently close this gap. We can, on the one hand, ensure that EU prioritise this investment for each budget and that Member States prioritise it in their recovery plans. On the other hand, the new fiscal rule book of the EU should allow for more public investment in housing. We can fight climate change, create jobs and tackle energy poverty through housing renovation. We are living through a health crisis; we have an economic and social crisis unfolding; there is a climate emergency. We can tackle all these issues by investing in quality housing through the renovation wave. We know that housing renovation can create two million jobs. This investment in renovation can help kickstart the economy. Bad indoor quality, damp housing, mouldiness – all have an important influence on respiratory diseases like Covid, so we can improve people’s health through renovation, and on top of that we can get millions of people out of energy poverty. We can stop illegal holiday rentals. In more and more cities, residents are pushed out of their neighbourhoods because it’s more profitable to rent apartments to tourists. Many cities feel powerless against these platforms when trying to get rid of illegal hotels. We can give cities more control over short-term holiday rentals through platforms like Airbnb. Through the Digital Services Act, we have to make sure that these platforms share the necessary data on rentals with cities so that rules on illegal holiday rentals can be enforced. We can make sure houses are to live in. Rather than a fundamental right to be guaranteed for all, housing has increasingly been considered only as a market to make profits through speculative acquisitions and through hedge funds and foreign institutional investors such as Blackstone, treating housing as a tradable asset. This has a dramatic effect on prices. We can do something about this by checking if the EU rules on real estate transactions and ownership, and put forward proposals to better protect mortgage borrowers from evictions. Citizens across Europe are struggling and count on us to stand by their side. With an economic and social crisis unfolding, the European Parliament will send a strong signal that we are serious about a strong, social Europe. That is why this report receives very broad support in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and that is why, dear colleagues, I count on your support for this report in plenary as well.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur for the report and also for the presentation of the report, which really highlighted the issue and the challenges, and the real dimension of the housing problem, which affects all Member States in the European Union. So it’s not just a national issue; it has become a real European issue. I also want to thank the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs for its timely and very relevant work on this report on access to housing.  Importantly, the report calls for an integrated approach to social, public and affordable housing at EU level. I very much share the objective of tackling homelessness and of supporting access to decent and affordable housing as a key factor in fighting poverty and social exclusion. We talk a lot about better wages, about minimum wages; this is extremely important. But even if I increase the minimum wage, if housing rents are increasing much more, people have not gained – they are not more prosperous; they have become even poorer. So I think the housing issue is a central issue in terms of social policy and improving the social context in all our Member States. Last year’s employment and social developments in Europe highlighted the strain that the increase in house prices over the last decade is putting on the middle class in the EU. There is a poverty trap looming because of this housing crisis for a lot of people who can no longer afford to find decent housing, and I would say housing close to their job, which, incidentally, creates other issues of transportation and CO2 emissions. Housing costs are higher in cities than in rural areas and represent a burden for more than one third of households living below the poverty threshold. In 2018, one person out of seven in the EU was living in a dwelling of poor quality. Thirty-Four million Europeans are struggling to keep their homes adequately warm in winter. And, more worryingly, homelessness trends have been on the rise over the last decade in most Member States. And I agree that we need better and more data to really understand what is happening here.  The COVID-19 crisis has worsened inequalities and people’s ability to cover housing-related expenses. The health crisis has underlined how essential a decent home is to health and well-being. It has demonstrated the vulnerability of persons, families, children, who experience homelessness and the pressing need to address this extreme form of social exclusion. As the honourable Members know, housing policies are obviously a national prerogative. But the EU has a key role to play in supporting its Member States, in helping Member States to exchange experiences – and indeed there are good and positive experiences all over Europe – on developing affordable housing, and also, in financially supporting the development of affordable housing. In the context of the COVID-19 recovery strategy, building renovation constitutes an opportunity to boost the green transition and, at the same time, employment. In particular, the renovation of social and affordable housing districts has the potential to reduce energy poverty, create local jobs and bring long—lasting benefits for communities. In this regard, local social economy enterprises can also play a key role by improving the accessibility and affordability of housing. The Commission encourages Member States to include building renovation in their recovery and resilience plans, with particular emphasis on social and affordable housing, and, in accordance with the principles introduced in the renovation wave, to establish long—term local public-private partnerships, supporting skills, digitalisation and smart technologies. Energy poverty is a strong focus of the renovation wave. The Commission has issued a recommendation to support national, regional and local efforts in tackling this issue. In addition, it will continue to support the EU Energy Poverty Observatory, which collects data, develops indicators and disseminates best practices for tackling energy poverty. The Commission will also support eradicating homelessness through Next Generation EU and the next long—term EU budget, namely under the European Social Fund Plus (ESF+) and the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF). In particular, the integrated housing——led approach will be supported by the ERDF in combination with ESF+. This approach follows the principles of Housing First, which combines immediate housing with enabling services to help previously homeless people pay their rent, promotes stable living conditions and prevents repeat homelessness. To tackle all these issues, and to help Member States – but also local authorities, municipalities and regions – address this problem of homelessness, together with the Portuguese Presidency we will organise a conference in June. It will be a broad conference bringing together all stakeholders – not only Member States, the Commission, Parliament and national parliaments, but also local authorities and NGOs – precisely to create a common platform to address the problem of housing and mainly the problem of homelessness.  There are good approaches in certain Member States and municipalities in our Union. We really have to help everybody to address this problem efficiently, with the aim of reducing drastically – if not absolutely – the question of homelessness. The future Invest-EU programme and its social and skills window will support investment in social housing and accompanying services for vulnerable groups. Homelessness and housing affordability and their social and macroeconomic implications are considered in the context of the European semester and included in the country—specific recommendations addressed to Member States. I’m looking ahead to the upcoming action plan implementing the European pillar of social rights, which will clearly emphasis this problem and we will discuss how to concretely translate principle 19 to the benefit of all those who suffer from bad housing or even the absence of housing.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has First of all, iammy and thanks to the rapporteur and to the shadow rapporteurs for the work that has been presented here – an extremely important piece of work, but also, in some details, a somewhat difficult report.  So what we do not have to argue about with the PPE-DE is the fundamental question and also the fundamental passion and willingness to fight against homelessness and affordable housing, which is not something we need to argue about. But we need to talk about some details. That is why we have marked two key votes for us in this report. On the one hand, this is the question: a binding renovation rate. Yes, when it comes to energy-efficient building renovation, the greatest potential sit-downs when it comes to the issue of CO2 savings. But the objectives must also be realistic and also financially viable. The same is true of a ban on investment in real estate. Yes, there is a real conflict of objectives here too. But if you look at the structure of private pensions, you will find that real estate investments play a major role here. So that's why let's argue about these details, that has to be. That is what we are going to do now in the vote. However, in the fundamental direction that we need to put more horsepower on the road here, there is no need to argue with the PPE-DE. With this in mind, i would like to thank you very much for your work.

name: Estrella DURÁ FERRANDIS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, first of all, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur, Kim Van Sparrentak, on the excellent report she has presented and the collaboration with the other groups.  The housing crisis affects all Member States and affects all of us. People who have difficulty accessing decent housing are counted not by thousands, but by millions in the European Union. More and more people live in slums and informal settlements, in unsanitary living conditions.  The pandemic has only exacerbated this situation. Housing is a fundamental right and one of the basic pillars of the welfare state. It should be excluded from competition rules, just as social investment should be excluded from fiscal consolidation policies. We need to be brave and make important changes; bet once and for all on a universalist approach to housing.  The Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats has introduced in the report real ambitious proposals: the inclusion of housing in economic services of general interest, for the objective group to be expanded and that access to social housing also extends to the middle classes and not only to the most vulnerable; that the housing cost overload indicator reflects the reality of what families live and looks at no more than 25% of their disposable income; ensuring the provision of adequate and affordable housing for the three lower quintiles of society; and that 30% of new housing is affordable for middle- and low-income people.  Evictions and homelessness are a violation of human rights. The Housing First program must be strongly supported. Regulation of the rental market and the real estate sector is also necessary, addressing housing speculation, increasing taxes on largeholders of housing and the supply of rental housing, especially publicly owned, and regulating holiday platforms.  Finally, the wave of energy renewal has to start by rehabilitating the homes of the most disadvantaged groups, and it is up to regulators to ensure that electricity suppliers adopt protection schemes to ensure the supply of energy to the most... (the president withdrew the floor to the speaker).

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, I’m happy to take part in this discussion which is one more sign of the big social shift which we have witnessed in the European Union in the last years. It is also sad that also in this part of the world in the 21st century we’re still trying to solve the problem of homeless people. It was a big challenge even before the pandemic, but now things, as we know, are getting even worse. Economists predict that the current crisis will deepen the inequality, which means that the problem of housing will become even more serious. The Renew Group shares the call on the Commission to take appropriate measures to help Member States to solve the problem. We very much welcome the idea of broadening the scope of those who are entitled to receive social housing, and I believe we have to keep in mind that the European Charter of Fundamental rights and the pillar of social rights will promise Europeans assistance in housing, so we must act. But it doesn’t mean that we have to overreact. Renew Europe does not believe that in order to solve a problem we have to intervene into the free market and try to use measures tailored for one particular Member State all over Europe.  We are diverse not only culturally but also economically,  and touristification in Venice is not the same as, let’s say, on Saaremaa island. But despite the fact that in some things the report goes too far, we welcome the initiative and hope that together with the Commission we can make a big step in the European Union where the right to housing will finally become not just a right, but the reality for everybody.

name: Stefania ZAMBELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the right to a home is sacrosanct. Unfortunately, in times of social crisis such as the one we are experiencing, it is not a certainty for everyone. The number of people reduced to hunger and poverty is constantly increasing. Just listen to the news and see the queues of people waiting for a hot meal at the various charities to understand that something is not working. I believe that Europe has more to think about in this time of crisis than to deal with social housing, by putting the stakes and conditions for the allocation of housing, favouring, among other things, Roma and non-Eu ropeans. Europe must not interfere in the competences of individual states. We need national plans that meet the real needs of individual territories and a much stricter immigration policy to stem the arrival of thousands of illegal immigrants, because only in this way, and I repeat, because only in this way would the number of homeless people in our cities be drastically reduced and the number of illegal jobs destined for those who have been on the list for years decrease.

name: Ciarán CUFFE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, housing is in the news often for all the wrong reasons. In Europe, 700 000 people will sleep rough tonight. In my own country of Ireland, 8 000 people are without a home today. Rents and costs are high. Many live in homes that are cold, damp and unaffordable.  My colleague Kim Van Sparrentak’s report says this does not have to be. Everyone deserves decent and affordable housing. Her report says we must recognise housing as a fundamental right under European Union law. We must seek to end homelessness over the next decade. We must bring together our national strategies.  That won’t help those who are homeless tonight, in Brussels or in Dublin, but it sends a message that Member States must do more. We must provide housing first to those who are homeless. We must make the renovation wave a reality by retrofitting existing homes and bringing public housing up to an A energy rating. We must build public homes in the numbers needed and we must learn from cities like Vienna and Helsinki that give housing the priority it deserves.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Dear! Universal access to housing is undoubtedly a priority. There is no decent life if a person does not have a chance to have an apartment. This applies both to young people who are planning their future, wanting to start a family, and to the elderly, who are very often in financial difficulties: they cannot afford rent, they cannot afford to buy an apartment. But very often for these people, as well as for people with disabilities, architectural barriers are an additional obstacle. Finally, homelessness, which affects so many Europeans. All this requires our care and support. In this respect, I agree as fully as possible with the report. I also agree that housing is a flywheel of the economy. But I do not agree with this report in this section when it tries to impose further standards, further regulations and fall within the competence of the Member States. We should support Member States in financing good projects, but not impose further regulations.

name: Leila CHAIBI
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Mr President, a big thank you first to Kim Van Sparrentak for the excellent report and for the excellent cooperation we have had during the preparation of this report, which I hope will be voted on by a large majority. I would like to go back to one point, given that time is running out. Colleagues, I hope that as soon as this damn pandemic is over, you will be able to come back and visit Paris and when you walk between the Haussmann buildings, I invite you to spot the dirty windows, the full mailboxes, each time it will be a sign that the building is empty and you will see, there are plenty. In Paris, almost one in five homes is empty: this is called real estate speculation. The less housing on the market, the more expensive the buildings are, the higher the rent prices and the worse the housing crisis.  To get out of this crisis, we have to put these homes back on the market and for that, there is a solution, it is the requisition. So, to all those who yell at expropriation and infringement of property rights, I assure you: to commandeer is to force a landlord to receive rent every month. It's fine, it's far from the gulag, you'll agree. In addition, it will allow millions of people to have a roof over their heads. So if there's a real reason to scream, let's yell instead that the right to housing is really fundamental.

name: Chiara GEMMA
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two figures: 700 000 people sleep on the streets every night, as the rapporteur has mentioned, whom I thank for her timely report; 80 million can't pay for their housing. It is clear that we are facing an emergency: housing discomfort. Yet the European Pillar of Social Rights recognises the right to housing assistance for the needy, for the homeless and for vulnerable people. The house is not a commercial good, it is a human right. It is not a means for the accumulation of wealth, it is a social good. It is therefore time to combat multiple discrimination and ensure decent and affordable housing for all, and I say for everyone. And here goes the thought of those who are denied the right to their own home: children, the elderly, victims of domestic violence, women, refugees, people with disabilities, for whom the protection of the right to live independently is a moral duty. It is clear that the various housing policies, a guarantee for a real boost to social cohesion, require a single approach, one that places respect for the dignity of every person, none excluded, at the centre of every political choice.

name: Eugen TOMAC
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the housing crisis is an extremely important and topical subject today, in times of pandemic.  I believe that it is our duty to respond to this problem with extremely practical and applied solutions. Clearly, for us it is a great challenge, especially since there are tens of millions of citizens who are heavily burdened by the costs of housing, living in old, unsanitary, crowded, energy-efficient and, worst of all, many of them unsafe. The coronavirus pandemic accentuated their suffering, as many of them had to remain closed for long periods of time in unsanitary homes.  The fundamental right to live in a good quality housing should be guaranteed to all citizens of the European Union, and bold measures are required in this regard. Moreover, the devastating earthquakes that have recently affected Croatia at the end of last year only confirm the danger of millions of European citizens every day. That is why I believe that, including the city where I live, Bucharest, where we have more than 2,000 buildings at high seismic risk, which endanger the lives of tens of thousands of citizens, obliges the European Union to a highly active policy in this dimension.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: Mr President, if house prices skyrocket despite an economic crisis, if the waiting lists for social rented housing sometimes last up to a quarter of a lifetime and if bricks are seen primarily as an interesting investment for cottage milkers, then it is time to intervene. For many people, a good and affordable home has become a far-from-my-bedshow, an unattainable dream. That is unacceptable. That is why we must invest more in more social rented housing. It should become the standard that sufficient social housing is also built in all new construction projects. In Europe, in the Netherlands, young people, families and the elderly deserve a good home that they can call home.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: Mr President, some 20 undocumented immigrants living in 37 square metres in the Val d'Oise, 200 migrants in a squat in Marseille, a growing shortage of social housing in the Ile-de-France, migrant and Roma camps on the outskirts of our cities, these are some examples that demonstrate the sad state of our country France today. We keep repeating what you refuse to see: the incessant migration flows aggravate the housing problems, but the lesson-givers who voluntarily live far away from those they claim to defend. To put an end to the fatalism and hypocrisy of the self-righteous, let us stop immigration, which produces catastrophic effects for the working classes who are suffering the full effects. Let us affirm the national preference for the allocation of social housing, let us wage war on sleep merchants, who, like smugglers, take advantage of the laxity of our States, as well as social misery. Stop the third-globalization of our nations.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Fair access to decent and affordable housing is a human right that should be universally guaranteed. The absence of this possibility can have disastrous economic consequences for the european Community as a whole, having a negative impact on already unwavering public sentiment.  Unfortunately, the COVID-19 pandemic did not spare this branch of the economy. The problem affects tens of millions of people in Europe who, as a result of the consequences, have serious difficulties in paying rent and housing bills. The form in which our economy will be after the coronavirus will largely depend on whether we act together and whether we will involve eu institutions in order to increase the availability of housing among people with different housing needs.  Often, the number of apartments donated does not translate significantly into an improvement in their availability. This problem affects young people entering the labour market, as well as large families whose incomes are too low to buy housing at market prices, and at the same time too high to be able to apply for the rental of municipal housing. Today, we must make it clear and assure citizens that the European Union will not leave anyone without a roof over their heads.

name: Cindy FRANSSEN
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, decent and affordable housing is not obvious to many Europeans, let alone for the more than 700 000 homeless people in the EU. However, the right to housing is mentioned in the social pillar and is enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights. In Belgium, decent housing is even a fundamental social right. In addition, housing is the key to accessing other rights and other social services.  Do I agree with every paragraph in this dossier? Most certainly not. But as co-chairman of the Anti-Poverty Group intergroup, I support this issue because decent housing is one of the most important levers in the fight against poverty. And I want to talk about homelessness here. In the last decade, the number of homeless people has increased by 70%. That is why it is so important to have a European cooperation platform for homelessness, to realise this section of the social pillar and to further roll out the "Housing First" approach. Because frankly, homelessness has no place in a prosperous Europe. And to put it in your words, Commissioner, it belongs in museums.

name: Heléne FRITZON
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr Even before the pandemic, it was clear that there is a shortage of suitable affordable housing. Many Europeans today live in unhealthy and cramped housing. Far too many are also forced to experience being evicted from their homes and homelessness has spread.  There are a number of challenges to the housing situation in Europe, where the report makes concrete proposals that are welcome. At the same time, it is of course important that we have a good balance between the European level and the national level, since housing policy is basically the responsibility of the Member States.  The housing shortage must be eliminated. Segregation in housing must be counteracted and the climate impact in both construction and housing must be reduced. Where the EU can act towards a forward-looking housing policy, where the EU should do so. I welcome Mr Schmit's announcement on the future of housing policy.

name: Guido REIL
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which We are talking today about access to decent and affordable housing for all. This is a very important issue, because rents have exploded in recent years and, unfortunately, 700 000 people are now living on the streets in the EU, they are homeless. But what solutions are now being made to us here in the report? First and foremost, it is important to us to implement the Green Deal. Many apartments are to be renovated energetically. But homes that are being renovated energetically are not necessarily affordable. As an example, I would like to give the example from Germany: The city of Kiel has extensively renovated the district of Gaarden energetically. Until a few years ago, this district was home to low-income people, welfare recipients and migrants. After this chic refurbishment, these very people were displaced into residential barracks, or even forced into homelessness, and new residents came. First and foremost, Green voters who can afford this chic environment. Green policy is a policy of social coldness, of the freezing cold, and we must not allow that to happen. We need real social policy for real people!

name: Loucas FOURLAS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, in my country, Cyprus, housing is a sacred institution. In 1974, hundreds of thousands of Cypriots lost their homes as a result of the Turkish invasion. In 2013, Cypriot citizens "put their backs" to support the banks, losing some or all of their deposits. Today, these very banks are threatening to take the homes of those who cannot repay their debt. Today, and while the pandemic continues, no man is understood to have lost his home. Member States should adopt legal provisions on credit facilities and on the protection of tenants against eviction. I repeat: no man should lose his home.  We support the Commission's policy, Commissioner, on residential renovations. This policy will create jobs, help protect the environment and allow millions of European citizens access to affordable housing. More than four million homeless people are currently living in the European Union, and that does not honour any of us.

name: Elisabetta GUALMINI
text: – Mr President, housing is the first and most important among social rights, from which all the others derive. If you have a roof over your head you can develop social relationships, create a family and raise children, cut down your feelings of insecurity and distress. In Europe, 80 million citizens are unable to pay the costs of their houses and the ranks of the homeless have grown by 70% in the last a decade. We now have to build up a real European plan on housing, based on sustainability. Fortunately a wind of change is blowing through Europe, since Europe is now able to show what solidarity means in front of the big suffering of the people because of the pandemic. So a good society is the one in which the minimum expectations of each of us are fulfilled. We can’t be indifferent to those who sleep in the streets. We can’t be indifferent to those who simply need to build up a future. I hope that this House, our House, will strongly support this dossier.

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in fact, these three debates that you have organised today have one thing in common. What we have in common is how can we guarantee more social justice, how can we guarantee all European citizens, wherever they live, a number of fundamental rights without which we cannot organise our lives? This applies to the COVID crisis and its impact on employment, the same applies to those who have already been hit by this crisis, those who are in poverty and the same goes for those who are the victims of the housing crisis. There is a broad consensus on this right to housing. Housing is not just an economic sector, an object of speculation, it is a right. And since it is a right, then it must be implemented, it must be guaranteed to be implemented by everyone and I believe that this is what everywhere, in all Member States, we must make efforts. We do have to make sure that housing is accessible, affordable, that there is social housing.  It is also true that, in the context of renovation, which is central and can be a major asset, both social and economic, especially to get out of this crisis, there are also dangers, this has been noted in particular by some, and the danger is that you renovate and expel. In fact, you make these renovated dwellings unaffordable and that is what you should avoid because it is called gentrification. Neighbourhoods that offered housing to people at a certain level of rent suddenly become inaccessible once the housing is renovated. And there it is a danger, because it is increasing, it is exacerbating the housing crisis and it is also exacerbating social injustice.  When you look at the evolution of rents, particularly in many urban centres, and the evolution of wages, the range has completely opened. Therefore, we must act in a coordinated way, of course, every time in a national and local context on the issue of platforms that ultimately immobilize thousands, hundreds of thousands of dwellings.  The problem of unoccupied housing for reasons of land speculation must be brought under control, as investment in affordable housing must be controlled. Moreover, I have just seen the arrival of my colleague from the economy, housing is a social problem, but it is also an economic problem. A big economic problem. We know that sometimes the housing crisis takes a different form. It takes the form of bubbles with financial crises at the key, so I believe that there is a European dimension here that should not be ignored, that should not be ignored. Thank you for this debate, thank you for this report. Let us act and the Commission will be there.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, Wednesday 20 January 2021, while the final vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 21 January 2021.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Alex Agius Saliba, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, containing recommendations to the Commission on the right to disconnect (2019/2181(INL)) (A9-0246/2020)). I would remind honourable Members that for all the debates during this part-session there is no catch-the-eye procedure, nor will 'blue card' questions be accepted.  Remote intervention is also planned from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Alex AGIUS SALIBA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, today we live in an always-connected world. Digitalisation and digital tools have brought many new opportunities, both in our personal and also in our working lives. It has created benefits, it has created advantages for employees such as greater flexibility and less commuting times. But it has also its pitfalls, such as the constant pressure on workers to always be reachable, to always be available at all times. Digital tools used to work have created the phenomenon of always being connected: an always-on culture, creating digital obesity that can intensify work and extend working hours with a detrimental effect. A detrimental effect on workers’ fundamental rights. A detrimental effect on fair working conditions. A detrimental effect on fair remuneration, on working time and on work-life balance, on health and safety at work, on the equality between men and women. Digital tools make it particularly difficult to switch off in our free time. We all know the feeling of always being under constant pressure to check: to check for work-related emails, work-related messages, worried that our immediate attention is required. We all have been in situations where we receive work-related calls, emails, and we feel obligated to reply. More than ever, in the aftermath of the COVID-19 pandemic, the increase of telework and working from home, we have been victims: victims of our phones, of our emails, of our computers. The COVID-19 pandemic has fundamentally changed the way we work, and we must therefore update our rules. During lockdown, one in three workers started working from home. This has saved countless lives, but many workers suffer and are suffering from harmful side-effects, such as isolation, fatigue, depression, burnout, muscular or eye illnesses. People who regularly work from home are twice as likely to work more than the maximum 48 hours. The boundaries between work and private life have become blurred. The human cost is high, from unpaid overtime to exhaustion, to burnout. It is fundamental that we protect workers from the invasion of their rest time and to ensure that their right to rest and leisure and a maximum limit of the workday are safeguarded. And for this, we need the right to disconnect to become a fundamental right, a fundamental right to each and every worker throughout our Union. Therefore colleagues, I strongly urge you to support this own-initiative report.   We are calling on the Commission to propose a European directive on the right to disconnect. The report is putting forward a fully-fledged, developed legislative proposal with the minimum requirements for using digital tools for professional purposes outside our working time. It provides for the right to disconnect for all workers in the EU, and it ensures that digital tools are used as an asset benefiting employers and workers while their adverse effects are mitigated. It provides workers with the right to disconnect, switch off and refrain from engaging in work-related tasks, activities or communication outside the working time. The report is also introducing safeguards to workers against any victimisation or negative repercussion if they use this right. Employers should enforce this right and not require workers to be directly or indirectly available or reachable outside their working time and provide them with sufficient information and methods to support the right to disconnect. The report also recognises the social partners’ pivotal role and tailors its implementation to the specific needs, depending on the different national and regional levels, sectors, and industries. Those are the main elements of the report, providing the right balance. The right balance equally positive for both workers and also employers, and I am counting on your support to show solidarity with European workers, especially during these difficult times of the pandemic. Please let us stay focused on the right to disconnect. The report will help millions of workers in these challenging situations. Nothing in it or in the amendment tabled by me intends to undermine the social partners, neither limit the Commission’s legislative power to propose legislation on the right to disconnect in early course. The report or the amendment in no way can change the Treaties or limit the Commission’s legislative power or veto the European legislation. Social partners in Europe are fully autonomous in what they negotiate. For me it is clear that we, as European Parliament, cannot interfere in this process, and the amendment should not be interpreted as making any legislative proposal contingent on the framework agreement, which, as stated in paragraph 13, addresses some arrangements for connecting and disconnecting and no other aspects of the right to disconnect. (Applause) I call therefore on the Commission, on the Commissioner for Jobs and Social Rights, Schmit, if the European report is adopted, to act immediately, through consultation with social partners, and put forward a proposal for legislation on the right to disconnect, because only through European legislation we can ensure the real impact on the very-much needed workers’ rights in the digital world. Colleagues, we have a fundamental choice to make tomorrow. We either provide workers with the right to disconnect or turn our backs on them. My choice is clear. I hope you can all support the right to disconnect for all European workers. (Applause)

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, and particularly the rapporteur, for the work on this legislative own-initiative report on a very important and sensitive issue: the right to disconnect. Indeed, the report addresses this important issue, which is related to the profound changes in the world of work – profound changes dominated by the digitalisation of many jobs and by the way people work and are connected. In the last few years we have witnessed a sustained growth in telework and an accelerated adoption of ICTs for work purposes. With the lockdowns due to the COVID-19 crisis, this gained much more prominence, and it will likely remain a permanent feature in the work organisation. Digitalisation has created, indeed, new businesses, new opportunities, new ways of working, living and consuming. It has led to productivity increases, to more flexibility for workers and businesses, and in the context of the pandemic, allowed many workers and many companies just to continue their activities. So if there is, on one hand, an important advance by the digitalisation of the European economy, we have also to have a very, very keen look at the upholding of working conditions and labour law. The new economy cannot develop outside the normal framework of labour law, including also working time. This is not just a social dimension; it’s also an economic one, so we have really to maintain a balance between the development of digitalisation on the one hand, with the extremely important tools we all have in our hands, and on the other hand, the rules, the framework, the laws which protect people, because we want a people-centred development of digitalisation. This report identifies some of the key challenges that new technologies pose, indeed, to the world of work. Addressing these challenges is all the more important in view of the effects of the COVID-19 crisis, because this has accelerated a lot of these processes. In Europe we can pride ourselves on a strong set of social and labour laws which already touch upon some of the challenges raised by this report. We have the Working Time Directive, the Occupational Safety and Health Framework Directive, the Work-life Balance Directive and the Transparent and Predictable Working Conditions Directive, to mention the ones which are relevant for remote working and have a direct impact on the ability of the worker to disconnect from work obligations. These laws protect the well-being of European workers and put forward safeguards, amongst other things, against excessive working hours and unpredictable work schedules, including for the ICT-based work. We need to explore how best to seize the opportunities and address the challenges posed by digitalisation of the world of work, taking into account national industry and sectoral specificities, as the rapporteur has also mentioned. In this regard, the high-level conference on the future of work, remote work, challenges, risks and opportunities, planned by the Portuguese Presidency, comes very timely. Implementing a right to disconnect is often a matter of finding the right balance between the nature of the tasks, management style, personal choices and company-level rules. Certainly a one-size-fits-all approach is therefore not ideal, but this doesn’t diminish the importance of a right. Then you have to implement the right according to the different situations, and certainly this can be best done through social dialogue. As rightly set out in your report, social partners have a central role in dealing with issues linked to this right to disconnect. Social partners should take a leading role in this regard, and the Commission stands ready to assist, ready to encourage. But this means that we have to be all de bonne foi. In the last few years, some Member States have taken action by directly or indirectly mandating social partners to negotiate provisions on the right to disconnect. Italy, Spain, France, Belgium are among those countries. And in the past, social partners have already agreed on a cross-industry framework agreement on telework, in 2002 – so quite a long time ago, when telework was starting. Now telework is extending, and close to 30% and sometimes even more people are on telework. It would perhaps be important to have a look at this agreement and to adapt it to the present context and circumstances. Social partners have also come together to agree on a more recent agreement on digitalisation, concluded in 2020. This framework agreement specifically tackles telework and modalities of connecting and disconnecting from work, and it is currently being implemented at national, regional and local level. In this specific field it is equally important to duly take into account the concerns on proportionality, subsidiarity and better law-making principles. All proposals for Union action – and this is absolutely fundamental and applies also to the right to disconnect and eventually action in this field – must be subject, under Article 154 of the Treaty, to consultation with the EU’s social partners, who may decide to act by means of agreements, to act by negotiation between themselves. So anyway, this door is open – wide open. Before deciding on any action on the right to disconnect, the Commission certainly has to apply this Article and will also discuss with social partners on these aspects. As a certain number of Member States, as I recalled already, have already introduced a right to disconnect, many companies also establish this important right through agreements with their social partners, because they have understood what the rapporteur has described: people are not robots, people have limits. So, if you want to have better productivity, you cannot just occupy people 24 hours a day and seven days a week. So I think this is an important contribution, economic and social again, and this shows the importance of this right to disconnect for the good functioning of companies. And very often, by the way, it’s IT companies who have introduced this right to disconnect. It underlines also the crucial role of social partners in this field. Therefore, the Commission is inviting social partners to proactively work together in order to come to an adequate solution for the benefit of workers and companies. Certainly the Commission is ready to accompany and support them in this endeavour, and then the right of the Treaty – also of Article 225 – is absolutely there and can be used by the Commission if needed. (Applause)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the Commissioner is absolutely right: people are not robots. It's a very clear message to everyone, and I will now switch to my mother tongue. I will continue in Czech because it's very important to send messages to people back home.  – Mr President, the coronavirus crisis has shown that people can work from home, but that we have often not set the conditions under which they will work. In fact, many people couldn't live with the environment of having to prepare their children for school, make phone calls, and then catch up on the mail that was pouring in from all sides. I have small children, too, and I know what it's like to be at home with the kids. I know what it's like to turn on a malfunctioning school connection several times to get in touch with the teacher. And here I see it as very important that not only I, but many of you have been through this. And you know it's important that you have time that you can spend not only on your job, but also on what you do. That is why I am happy for the balance and for the absolutely clear message from the European Parliament, alexi and you others who have been involved in this report. The European Parliament is on the side of the people and on the side of having a personal life.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. Mr President, I think everyone knows that feeling. You come home after a long day at work, you just cook, and that phone just keeps vibrating. The boss, or you still have a moment ...  For more and more people, work and private life are becoming more and more intertwined. Stress, depressive feelings and burnouts increase whenever you have to stand. It could make you sick. Even if you are not so sure about your contract, for example because you have a temporary contract or because a reorganization has been announced on your company, you should have the right to say "nothing now".  For all workers in Europe, I advocate the right to inaccessibility. Commissioner, come up with a directive as soon as possible, rather than tomorrow. I think that our rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs have put forward a wonderful proposal, which absolutely deserves parliament's support.

name: Yana TOOM
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, frankly speaking, all the smart things have already been said, and that’s why I thought that I have to share a piece of personal experience.  Like, I believe, many of us, I was raised in a working environment where you had to work 24/7 just to build up your career. In the very beginning, after my country gained independence, I was a single mother of three. It was non—stop. And that was exactly what I wanted to see from my own people whom I was working with.  I have to say that, working on this report I felt ashamed sometimes. I believe that my accredited parliamentary assistants are particularly grateful to the rapporteur and for the fact that we raised this topic. Due to these technical means, we are now used to calling and writing to people at any time and then waiting for them to react. This is not normal. We all know, theoretically, that we have a Working Time Directive. We know how many hours we are supposed to work and how many hours we are supposed to rest, but do we really act accordingly? Sometimes not, let’s be honest. I believe that we have to deal with this problem, not only at legislative and European level, but also here in this House and everywhere. I’m very glad that we are on the same page as the Commission and the House. I believe that we are able to solve this problem and to give people the opportunity to work, especially during a pandemic, and to have a proper work-life balance.

name: Guido REIL
text: On behalf of the ID Group, I would like to make a i-see of the Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which No employee must be available to his employer 24 hours a day. That is perfectly normal. The world of work has changed completely in recent years. The assembly line worker, who is standing on the assembly line for eight hours, is in fact no longer available. We are talking about flexitime today, we are talking about working time of confidence, we are now talking a lot about home office. And all these things bring flexibility, flexibility that also brings freedom – and that's a good thing. Of course, we also need regulations. Finding them will be difficult. And i do not understand why this Parliament, of all people, feels called upon to find these regulations. Because it is not the job of this Parliament at all. This problem must be resolved at national level, because the labour markets in the EU are completely different and the rules of the game under which the game is played are completely different. That is why this problem must be resolved nationally by the social partners and, of course, by the social partners.

name: Sara MATTHIEU
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, on weekends with your boss whatsapes or answer an e-mail quickly in the evening, does it sound familiar to the ears? The line between work and private life is becoming more blurred, but more autonomy and flexibility should not equate to being continuously accessible. Humans are not machines. We need to be able to charge our batteries by distancing ourselves from our work, because being permanently accessible leads to stress and burnout.  I call on the Commission to come up with a legislative initiative as soon as possible, because all European workers deserve the right to be unreachable. Especially in times of COVID-19 and homework this is particularly relevant. But this is also important for employers. After all, without healthy workers, things cannot continue to run. A special mention for women: they often take on more caring responsibilities but also have to remain accessible to their employer and therefore they are more at risk of health and their well-being is put under extra pressure. Colleagues, if your living room becomes your office, where do you draw the line? Let's do this together.

name: Beata SZYDŁO
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Working online on the one hand is a boons, because it protects against coronavirus, it gives you the opportunity to work at this difficult time, but on the other hand it is a curse, because the line between private and professional life is blurred.  There absolutely cannot be an agreement that people should not have the right to privacy, to private life – after all, there are laws that should guard against it. There is the 2003 Directive, which clearly defines the right to rest, shows how working time standards apply, there is national law on working time, so it seems that the solutions that are being proposed at the moment are another overregulation. Perhaps it is worth looking at these existing rules and considering why this does not work, why workers do not have a chance to protect them in this 2003 directive and not to create another law.

name: Daniela RONDINELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in one year distance workers have risen from 5 % to 30 %, and this has happened in a situation of complete legislative vacuum at European and national level. It is necessary to regulate this transformation of the way we work through a European directive, which avoids the spread of new forms of exploitation, and to prevent states from proceeding in a scattered order precisely because 'ubiquitous' work is a common phenomenon of the internal market. That is why the emergence of new forms of dumping between countries must be avoided by means of European legislation that prevents companies from violating the new fundamental rights of workers resulting precisely from digitalisation. That is why the right to disconnect is a necessity for everyone, to which the European Commission must respond as a matter of urgency and start the legislative process immediately, because the social partners will not be able to implement the agreement on digitalisation in the next three years. The 5-Star Movement supports this report in its content, which has also been strengthened thanks to our amendments, but we cannot accept parliament blocking the social dialogue, when every worker must be given the dignity he deserves.

name: Dennis RADTKE
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has This report has been fought very hard, and I would therefore like to begin by thanking the rapporteur and the shadow rapporteurs for their work, but above all for their willingness to compromise. I believe that it is simply a very, very important signal, also from this Parliament. This is an issue that has affected millions of Europeans even before Corona. That we, as a Parliament, are issuing a report that is not decided by huge, contentious majorities, but where a large majority in this House can rally behind it. I believe that this is absolutely fair to the importance of this issue. It is also important to me – and I say this as someone who has worked for a large trade union for many years – that we as a policy do not make the claim: we can regulate and control everything here centrally immediately, we have a realistic answer to these complex questions, but that we are now saying: now, according to our understanding, it is the turn of those who are in the right place. , who are closest, and these are the social partners. You now have three years to come up with things and present them to us, and if you don't get it, we'll do it. But now it has been her turn, which I think is a very, very important signal, and it is also a sign of confidence in a much-needed strengthening of social partnership. I would therefore like to express my sincere thanks and I ask you to vote in favour of this report.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is important to remember that the right to disconnect concerns all workers, not just those who are teleworking. And while digitization has many benefits in an employee's life, studies show that hyperconnection can have unwanted effects on work-life balance or well-being at work.  It is unacceptable to us that more and more employees are seeing their working hours increase and this without additional income or compensatory rest time. As a socialist, I welcome this report, which calls for the inclusion of social partners in the forthness of the forthness of the legislative process, but above all sets out the necessary guidelines for the creation of such a right in Europe, through a clear definition of the right to disconnection, information for workers about their right to disconnect, the setting of new working conditions for online employment and the protection of workers in terms of the risk of reprisals. out of work.  Yes, European workers need the right to disconnect. Let's make it happen!

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: Mr President, telework is a new way of working that is of interest to many employees, but it can be seen as an unbearable constraint when it is imposed by a company, whether in normal times or in exceptional circumstances, such as the coronavirus pandemic. This is why it is useful to recognize employees a right to disconnect, that is, the right to fully benefit from their time off and leave, without being bothered by their company. This is what the French law of August 8, 2016, this law recognizes this right to disconnect and wisely refers to social dialogue to clarify its modalities. This French example deserves to inspire all the Member States of the European Union because the Union must not only be the Europe of business, it must also have a social dimension. However, there must be no unreasonable administrative straitjacket on businesses. Furthermore, I consider that the creation of this new right of the right to disconnect is a matter for states and not for the Union. For these two reasons, I am opposed to the adoption of a directive on the issue. Let's trust the states.

name: Lefteris NIKOLAOU-ALAVANOS
text: Mr President, the new capitalist crisis, accelerated by the pandemic, has given governments and the European Union the opportunity to legislate fixed requirements for employers to reduce labour costs and intensify it, drastically increasing teleworking. Violations of employers are continuous through the "connection" with the latest technology and exploitation: cameras, recording applications, sensors, work without hours, with painful consequences for the mental and physical health of workers. Violations based on existing anti-labour Directives of the European Union and laws of governments providing for the dissolution of the eight-hour period, an increase in working time of up to 72 hours per week, its six-monthly regulation.  Workers are called upon to strengthen their fight for collective agreements, to reduce daily working time and to abolish all forms of flexible working, against the permanence of teleworking, to ensure their leisure time. To fight against the laws that dissolve the eight-hour, labour insurance rights, such as the ten-hour work promoted by the Government of New Democracy, to ensure the return to the workplace with all necessary protection measures under the responsibility of employers and government.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: Mr President, Commissioner, according to a study by Eurofound, 27% of respondents working at home say they have worked in their spare time to meet labour requirements. In this light, the right to decoupling must be an important instrument of our social policy and must be protected immediately; , young people and people with caring responsibilities, such as families with children and single-parent families, and of course will take into account the specific needs of the various sectors, in terms of the right to decoupling, while respecting the autonomy of the social partners.

name: Gabriele BISCHOFF
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the In fact, we are not robots. That is why this report, the right to shut down, is such an important political initiative, especially in these pandemic times. Millions of people have been sent to the home office, and many are experiencing what it is like to see work and the private that blur, that burn-out, stress and also feelings of guilt are the result. Although most employees will return to their offices afterwards, it is clear that the way we work has changed. All the more incomprehensible is the lobbying tsunami, which has also been sparked here by some employers' associations. This is reminiscent of the dispute over the Working Time Directive. It is really important that employees are made legally empowered to be able to pull the plug and to be able to switch off their official telephones and computers outside working hours. That is why the Commission should not be impressed by this lobbying. I appeal to everyone in this House to support the report. Europe's workers rightly expect their health to be protected – time to act!

name: Marianne VIND
text: Mr President! During the coronapandemia, many experience pressure to be available in their spare time. That is why we propose to protect the right to take time off when you have time off for all those who do not have a fixed working time. It is crucial to me that it is the social partners who draw up the agreement, and it does not have to be difficult. It is primarily a question of anticipation. An appointment at a workplace for when and how to use email and phone. But not one that's so inflexible that you're not allowed to help if it's all on fire.  This is a little bit of the road. There is still a long way to go if we are to help the many millions affected by stress. It will therefore be crucial that we have an ambitious strategy with a main focus on health and safety at work. We must focus on this preventive action so that Europe's employees experience that the tasks match working time and their competences and that managers are better trained. There's no time to waste. Let's get started.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the other shadow rapporteurs for the work we have done in this report. The proposal is not, of course, as I would like, or as any other rapporteur would like, but we have reached a good consensus to introduce this right to switch up into Community law. Regrettably, last week an amendment was tabled by the EPP, which opposes this right to switch up, basically introducing a three-year postponement for the European Commission to submit a proposal. A three-year postponement, let us understand, aims at this European Parliament not to approve this legislative initiative in this mandate, because in three years' time we will be four months away from the elections.  The EPP has therefore found a way to kill this report, without explicitly saying it, and has succeeded in getting the Socialist rapporteur to make this proposal and at the same time call on the Commissioner not to comply with it!  We will vote against Amendment No 2 and we think this is a bad message to send to the tens of millions of workers who are currently... (The President withdraws his word to the speaker)

name: Nicolas SCHMIT
text: Member of the Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have listened to your speeches and I have not heard anyone who is against this right to disconnect. What for? Because it's just common sense.  As I have said and as some have also said, you cannot require a person, no matter how good, to be available at all times. We can demand it for a while but if we go beyond that time, well there will be a return. Return is occupational diseases, stress, burn-out. Diseases often of our time and diseases that have terrible impacts on people, but also have considerable financial consequences on all our social protection systems. Let me just make a brief reminder. 102 years ago, in a member country, not to mention France, an eight-hour law on working time was passed. It was a huge achievement, claimed all over Europe, and not just in Europe for that time. Some thought it was the end of the economy, the crisis, the end of productivity. Well technology already at the time taught that this was not the case. Moreover, the ILO's Convention Number 1, which was created at the same time in 1919, dealt exactly with 8 hours of daily work. I believe that today we are in a different situation, but we are also in a technological revolution, we are in an upheaval of the world of work. And so we must take the measure of this upheaval and its impact on humans, on human work.  This Parliament, together with the previous Commission, has adopted an important directive on work-life balance. One cannot advocate this balance on the one hand and on the other hand, absolutely open the door to all excesses. Moreover, which, logically, reasonably, could defend such excesses. Yes it is true, there can not be in this area a solution that applies to all types of companies. That is why social partners have a fundamental role to play.  But at the same time I say that, while I should be pleased that a number of Member States have already enshrined, as has been pointed out, in their legislation this right to disconnection, which must be declined according to companies by the social partners, well, as a European I have some difficulty in accepting that this right is accessible to certain nationals. , some workers in some countries but not all Europeans. This is not the European social model! And so the framework for pushing towards recognition of this right must be created. I hope that the social partners will succeed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, Wednesday 20 January 2021. The final vote will take place on Thursday, 21 January 2021. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Tanja FAJON
text: Writing. – At a time of epidemic, as many as a third of all workers in the European Union work from home. This has its advantages, but also its weaknesses. The advantage is certainly less likely to spread coronal virus infection, and nausea is a feeling that a worker should always be available. Working from home blurs the line between work and leisure. That is why, in the European Parliament (at the initiative of S&D MEP Alex Agius Salibe), we are in favour of the so-called right to disconnect, which means the right or the possibility for a worker to turn off his phone and e-mail after working hours without fear of negative consequences. In the report, we call on the Commission to regulate this right for all workers in the EU. This will greatly reduce the pressure and increased concern for the mental health of employees, who have been facing an unpredictable situation for almost a year and adapting to a new way of working. This measure will also be a relief to many Slovenes who work remotely during the epidemic.

name: Elena KOUNTOURA
text: Writing. – Since the onset of the pandemic, more than a third of EU workers have now been working from home. Teleworking, in addition to the positives it brings – flexibility, saving time, reducing air pollution due to reduced travel, protecting the health of vulnerable groups – is a major challenge for industrial relations by introducing new data and putting new obligations between employers and workers, often at the expense of the latter. Ever-increasing teleworking has led to an enforced culture of constant connection and uninterrupted operation and can deepen horizontally the negative impact on workers' fundamental rights, fair working conditions and work-life balance, physical and mental health and safety and well-being at work, but also, given its disproportionate impact on workers with caring responsibilities who are normally women , equality between men and women. Phenomena such as undermining labour rights, circumventing legal hours and violating respect for privacy must be regulated to eliminate them. In the absence of a European legislative framework defining and regulating the right to decoupling, we call on the Commission to propose legislation immediately. Disconnection from work must be a fundamental right and workers must be able to turn off digital devices without facing consequences.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – Work-life balance is very important in times of social distarence and curfews, so the right to check out must be a right that is an integral part of work organisation in the new digital age. The measures taken in response to the Covid19 crisis have changed the way people work and demonstrated the importance of digital solutions. While working from home meant preserving a lot of jobs, 27% of those working from home reported working from home in their spare time. The spread of teleworking has placed an even greater burden on young people and persons with care responsibilities, such as single parents, families with children or families caring for relatives. Continuous online contact, combined with the large number of work tasks and the increasing expectation that workers will be available at any time, can negatively affect the balance between private life and work, as well as their physical and mental health and wellbeing, can increase stress and lead to burnout. The right to check out allows workers to refrain from working-related electronic communications, phone calls or emails during rest periods or during their leave, without facing any adverse consequences. Respect for working time and its predictable nature are essential to ensure the health and safety of workers and their families in the Union.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. – In order to adapt workers' rights to changes in work at home, the European left requested and initiated a European Parliament report on the right to disconnect. The report is based on the impact of ICT on working conditions faced by the majority of Europeans forced by the COVID-19 crisis to switch to a telework system. In addition to the positive aspects generated by this new system, such as the protection of jobs during the pandemic or greater flexibility in the management of time, location and the way in which work is carried out, new challenges have also arisen which pose greater risks to workers and which involve supranational coordination of the Member States. According to Eurofound, 27% of Europeans who worked from home say they have also had to work in their spare time to perform their professional tasks. Thus, our proposal concerns the right of this category of workers to disconnect and is based on recent studies showing the importance of work-life balance on the physical and mental health of workers, while protecting the much-needed flexibility of many workers today.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the revision of Irene Tinagli's EU list of tax havens on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and by Paul Tang, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (O-000081/2020 – B9-0001/21) (2020/2863(RSP)) and – the oral question to the Commission on the revision of Irene Tinagli's EU list of tax havens on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, and by Paul Tang on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (O-000082/2020 – B9-0002/21) (2020/2863(RSP)).

name: Paul TANG
text: author. – Mr President, let me mark this moment because it’s the first time — and I say this with pleasure and even pride —that the Subcommittee on Tax Matters (FISC) is participating in the plenary debate of the European Parliament.  I am convinced that FISC will manage to build broad majorities inside and outside this House, because what I have seen from discussions with the different political groups is that we have at least one notion of fairness in common — that is that everyone has to pay taxes.  That is the rule, and there are no exceptions to the rule. Not for billionaires, not for big polluters and not for big corporates. This brings me to the blacklist of tax havens: the list of non—cooperative jurisdictions. It was long a deep wish of the European Parliament to have this list. Indeed, in 2017 we got our way when it was established for the first time. It was and is a good idea to name, to shame and, above all, to change. Change because being on the list should have, and must have, real consequences — both for the countries on the list and for the businesses that operate from those countries. But the Member States that ultimately decide on the list have forgotten just one thing: to include actual tax havens.  The Tax Justice Network has shown that the countries included on the list are responsible for only 2% of global tax avoidance. By comparison, the Netherlands alone — the country where I come from — is responsible for 8.5%, and the number one offender is the Cayman Islands, responsible for 16.5%. The list does not work yet.  And the nasty truth is that it’s not getting better; it’s getting worse. The Virgin Islands, Bermuda, Jersey. These are some of the world’s most renowned tax havens and they have been removed from the list.  Commissioner and Minister, imagine the shock I and others in the House felt when we learned that the Cayman Islands, the number one tax haven in the world, had been removed as well.
