With the Member States failing to live up to their duty, it is for the Parliament to step up and tell it like it is. This list is confusing and ineffective. You have got to fix this. Give the list teeth with strict criteria and make it bite with defensive measures. No countries without a corporate tax system or with low effective corporate tax rates should go free. Europe is suffering from Member States’ failure to live up to their duty. Our citizens are losing EUR 140 billion each year from corporate income tax losses. This is money that could have been spent on housing, on health, on care or, if you wish, on income taxes.  Our citizens want something different. They expect something different. 86% of them say that they want the EU to fight tax avoidance and tax evasion. Go fix it! There is a democratic deficit. The citizen expects, yet the politicians do not deliver. A democratic deficit is not just that, but also the lack of transparency, because the discussions on taxation take place in the back rooms, although scrutiny and accountability are part and parcel of our democracy. Taxation seems to be a debate for technocrats alone at this stage, and this should be changed. What you see in the resolution is that it calls for democratic standards to be obeyed. More specifically, it calls on the Council to disclose the participating members, the topics of discussion, the technical assessments, the summaries, the minutes and the conclusions of these meetings.  It also calls on the Chair of the Code of Conduct Group to visit the FISC committee regularly. It is part and parcel of our democratic process; scrutiny and accountability are part of that.  The resolution also calls for us to look in the mirror, because to fight tax avoidance through non-EU tax havens adds up to hypocrisy if we don’t look in the mirror. When we do, we will find that it’s not a pretty sight. The Netherlands, which I already mentioned, together with Luxembourg, Ireland, Hungary and other EU States are responsible for one third of global tax avoidance. This is why in the resolution Parliament commits itself to examine each and every policy [...] (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I’ve listened carefully to the honourable Mr Tang. Thank you for bringing this question to the plenary, as it is an important issue. The EU and its Member States are committed to strengthening good tax governance, fair taxation, global tax transparency and the fight against tax fraud and evasion, both at EU level and globally. The Ecofin Council produced a set of conclusions on 27 November 2020 on fair and effective taxation. This provided political guidance on further work on a modern EU tax environment. These conclusions also express the Council’s views on the Commission tax action plan, issued in July 2020, on good tax governance in the EU and beyond. The Council reiterated the importance of supporting the principles of good tax governance through the continuation of the successful work undertaken so far in the context of the Code of Conduct Group, including the EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes, which should be further pursued and enhanced where necessary.  The Council therefore requested that the Code of Conduct Group continue its work. It also stressed the importance of fair treatment within the EU with respect to third countries and jurisdictions, while maintaining a continuous dialogue with third countries as well as with the OECD. The Code of Conduct Group will also pursue its discussions on ways and means to further improve the work on the code. This should take into account the successful lessons from other experience gained so far.  The EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes was revised most recently in October 2020 following an in-depth review of the implementation of the commitments made by third countries’ jurisdictions that are part of the process. The next revision of the EU list, which is scheduled for February at the Ecofin Council, is prepared by the Code of Conduct Group.  As regards defensive measures towards non-cooperative jurisdictions for tax purposes, Member States and the Council adhere to a number of guiding principles. The defensive measures can have considerable consequences for the listed jurisdictions. The following aspects can be mentioned in this context. First, the key objective of the list is to ensure change, as Mr Tang said, and not punish the listed jurisdiction. Being listed entails reputational damage and we see that this aspect tangibly contributes to the efficiency of the EU list. More and more jurisdictions change their practice and adopt tax good governance; standards that are also applicable between the EU Member States.  So, on the second aspect, a number of EU-level defensive measures are being applied vis-à-vis the listed jurisdictions, and these can have financial consequences. The work in this area is also continuing with the assistance of the Commission.  And third, Member States are also free to apply national lists or defensive measures that go beyond what is agreed at the EU level or in the intergovernmental context of the Code of Conduct Group.  Finally, it is important to recall that the measures agreed in 2017 in the Council were reviewed in 2019 in the Code of Conduct Group, and Member States agreed to continue this work during this year. This reflects the fact that Member States have different legal systems, different laws and it takes time to design new measures. Work on defensive measures will not stop. Coordination will continue, and it’s likely to increase in the near future. Should the Commission choose to table a legislative proposal in this area, it will of course be examined by the Council in accordance with the treaty requirements and taking into account the limits of the EU’s competence in these matters.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable members, first of all let me thank the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) and Subcommittee on Tax Matters (FISC), and the rapporteur, Mr Tang, for putting the fight against tax evasion and tax avoidance at the forefront of the agenda. The EU list of non-cooperative jurisdictions will continue to play an important role in the years to come. And, I think, especially at this moment in time, in order to help overcome the economic and social crisis also caused by the pandemic, we have to strengthen these tools. The Commission announced a commitment to work to strengthen these tools in July 2020, and this commitment will continue. Of course, there is a need to improve tax good governance, not only globally, but also within the EU. Member States are subject to reviews under various tools, and these tools include the Code of Conduct for business taxation, whose reform is an absolute priority, and infringement procedures in the areas directly covered by EU law. I count on the European Parliament to continue pushing for an ambitious agenda. I am glad to hear the Council’s commitment in this direction.  The Commission actively engaged with Member States in the different Council groups to discuss the follow-up to the communication on tax good governance in Europe and beyond. As a result, the Council adopted conclusions, as it was reminded, which take note of the communication and reiterate the importance of the principles of tax good governance and the need to enhance the EU listing process. This is an important step as it recognises that more work is needed. I have in mind, in particular, the revision of the Code of Conduct for business taxation. Any change in this respect will have a major impact on the EU listing process. The progress on the discussions of minimally effective taxation in the context of Pillar Two of the OECD’s report are accordingly crucial for the code and, consequently, also for the EU listing process, and will have an effect on our fair taxation criterion, including zero-tax jurisdictions.  The EU listing also requires improved administrative cooperation, in particular through the exchange of tax information. This is why the Commission will continue to work on extending the EU list criteria to cover effective exchanges of information under the Common Reporting Standard, country-by-country reporting between tax authorities and beneficial ownership information. I believe that it is also necessary that we focus on the right jurisdictions, and consider whether any relevant jurisdiction is missing from our radar. This is the reason why the Commission is working on a revision of the scoreboard, and uses enhanced selection criteria for identifying jurisdictions and prioritising their screening under the EU listing process. The Commission is also looking forward to assessing the actions undertaken by Member States towards enacting domestic defensive measures vis-à-vis listed jurisdictions. I reiterate on this occasion that we are ready to take any necessary initiatives in case the results are not in line with our expectations, including by way of legislative proposal. Finally, I believe that the Council should report regularly to the Parliament regarding its work on non-cooperative jurisdictions. This would improve the mutual understanding of the process and would help to focus on improving the EU listing process.

name: Lídia PEREIRA
text: on behalf of the Ppe Group. – Mr President, in a time of crisis when we need all the resources that we have been able to mobilise, starting with the financial budgets, our national budgets cannot continue to lose 20% of the revenue stemming from corporation tax on transfers to tax havens every year. Every penny we stop receiving is left to help rebuild and relaunch the economy and jobs. We need competitive European companies. It is companies, especially SMEs, that are the engine of our recovery. It is therefore important to continue to rely on the internal market, also fiscal, fair and fair competition. It is precisely because we believe in this justice and loyalty that we cannot compromise in the use of tax havens to conceal income and to avoid paying taxes that are due.  The blacklist of tax havens is an indispensable tool for flagging states or regions, promoting reforms in these jurisdictions and disencouraging their use by citizens and businesses. But we need more and better criteria for identifying tax havens. We need transparency and we need a list that effectively contributes to combating flight, tax evasion and money laundering.  We need to stop this pandemic of tax evasion. This Parliament has had the ambition to point out a way. National governments are required to follow it!

name: Pedro MARQUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Dear Commissioner Gentiloni, Dear Secretary of State Ana Paula Zacarias, Colleagues, the difficulties that citizens face in the current crisis make the injustice of our tax system even more glaring. Citizens are making many sacrifices, small and medium-sized enterprises, but at the same time, some millionaires and many multinationals take advantage of tax havens to evade tax payments. This is only unacceptable and the European Union must do a much better job of combating tax havens. The lack of ambition, consistency and transparency of the blacklist of tax havens has to be overcome definitively. As our subcommittee chairman and rapporteur Paul Tang has already said, the Cayman Islands have recently been removed from the list of tax havens. Citizens see, but they don't believe.  It is estimated that this jurisdiction accounts for more than 16% of tax losses globally, a daunting figure higher than the GDP of many Member States. It's not admissible! We cannot continue like this and we welcome the determination revealed here by the Presidency of the Council.  With this resolution, we propose to revise the criteria of this list, with greater transparency and democratic scrutiny, with a criterion that includes in the list any country that does not simply cover taxes, as well as those with very low taxes, below a minimum rate set by the Union. But the Union must also set an example and not allow similar domestic practices in unfair competition, which always results in a race to the bottom in public policy financing. We hope, therefore, and we will be aware, that this resolution deserves a very broad consensus here in Parliament, revealing everyone's commitment to these proposals.

name: Gilles BOYER
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, thank you for your words. Of course, the European list of tax havens was a first step in 2017. And many of us here regret that its potential is not being exploited, you have also talked about it. The territories listed represent less than 2% of the global tax revenue losses, which obviously raises questions about the effectiveness of this list. This list must therefore be reformed in order to provide the European Union with a genuine legal, coercive instrument. This will require strengthening its criteria and tougher and better coordinating sanctions. Finally, if Europe wants to be legitimate at the international level in the fight against tax evasion and harmful tax practices, it must of course set an example and we therefore call for a coherence between the criteria that govern listing and the criteria for harmful tax practices within the European Union. Commissioner, Madam Secretary of State, we Parliament will be vigilant for you to act and thank you for your encouraging words in this regard. You know that Parliament is a demanding and vigilant interlocutor, but it also knows how to recognise when action is at the rendezvous and we will be by your side, if the reform lives up to our expectations.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: Mr President, For better, I would like to make a name for my free Mr President, I would like to thank the Tax havens cost honest taxpayers EUR 360 billion worldwide. And of this EUR 360 billion, just 2% of the countries on the EU's list of tax havens are covered. It is therefore good that we have a broad parliamentary majority here to thoroughly revise this list of EU tax havens. Countries that have 0% corporate taxes, countries that allow shadow companies with little economic substance, should automatically end up on this list in the future. In the same way, the list must comply with European standards, in other words, it must be drawn up transparently. That is why the demand for the Commission is: be courageous, put forward a courageous proposal and, if possible, one that, unlike some people here in Parliament, openly admits that we also have tax havens in Europe, in the EU.

name: Beata KEMPA
text: – Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Schwa European Union countries lose €170 billion each year in tax havens and on cross-border profit shifting. On average, they receive 13% of the annual budget of individual European Union countries. As estimated Polish Economic Institute, the mere elimination of artificial transfer of profits by multinationals between different jurisdictions within seven years could lead to the recovery of €420 billion. This is more than the amount the Union has spent on cohesion policy over the next seven years.  Today, solidarity is needed in this area. These financial resources are needed to save our economies, especially in the fight against COVID-19. That is why we must demand firm joint action by the whole Union. Enough of double standards, enough silence. There are six beneficiaries of these murted transactions in the Community, preying on harm and belt-tightening by others. The greatest profits are undoubtedly achieved here by the author of the Netherlands.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: on behalf of the band The Left. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I suggest that you play a very instructive game of seven mistakes. Here is Oxfam's ranking of the world's worst tax havens for multinationals and I suggest you quite simply compare it with the European list of tax havens.  First, we have Bermuda, which is not listed by the European Union, second the Netherlands either, Switzerland neither, the Cayman Islands neither, Singapore neither, Ireland neither, Luxembourg either. Well, I stop there because I could have gone to the end of the list with the same result: none of the most notorious tax havens are listed by the European Union. So here's what's left of your European list of tax havens: a carte blanche to tax evasion. We are told that the coffers would be empty to help people who are struggling, so start by calling a spade a spade, by really naming tax havens, including within the European Union, and let's get the money where it is: in the pocket of tax evaders.

name: Markus FERBER
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Madam President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. In May 2016, the Council decided to establish a blacklist of tax havens. Four and a half years have now passed. Since then, the list has been updated several times. A whole series of jurisdictions have been added to the list and taken down again. Most of them were small island states in the South Pacific, whose non-cooperation on tax issues was probably due to the fact that they do not have an efficient tax administration. It is time to think fundamentally about the meaning and nonsense of this list and also to see whether it really helps us to combat tax havens. I believe that we have three problems, which I shall also raise briefly. Firstly, with a few exceptions, the list does not meet the right states. The Council has always been courageous in putting small states on the list that are somewhere on small islands, but has always shied away from tackling large chunks. Why is the state of Delaware – after all, one of that state has been sworn in as president today – not on this list, to give just one example? Secondly, the so-called defence measures linked to the list are simply not enough. So here too we should think about what it really means to create sanctions. Thirdly, the list is not credible unless we ourselves in Europe start to fight our tax havens. Madam President-in-Office of the Council, I recommend that you follow the Commission's advice and take a look at Madeira. I believe that this is part of Portugal – this is also a tax haven.

name: Jonás FERNÁNDEZ
text: – Mr President, I believe that the Council should start this debate by recognising that the current list of tax havens is not working. And we could probably agree on two big reasons. The first is that there are no clear criteria, so that diplomatic issues, foreign policy issues or other considerations that have nothing to do with monitoring control of tax havens, are always introduced.  The second big element is the absolute absence of transparency, accountability, control by this Parliament, so that if we take into account that the Council incorporates assessments or criteria that have nothing to do with the fight against tax havens and that, moreover, there is no democratic accountability, we have a list that is not credible. And a list that needs to be thoroughly reviewed, because, at the moment, in this harsh crisis that Europe is going through, citizens need to see greater exemplaryness on the part of the public leaders. I therefore trust and hope that the Commission, Commissioner Gentiloni, will soon present new initiatives that improve transparency, improve predictability on which States may or may not be on that list and that we will not be at the albur of countries that enter and leave that list without any criteria, without any control, without any democratic traceability. And let us hope that in this proposal it will incorporate greater transparency, greater control by this European Parliament and that the Council will, of course, accept it.

name: Kira Marie PETER-HANSEN
text: Mr President! Thank you for the floor and thank you to colleagues for also making a great deal of good comments. When it comes to the EU tax list, I hardly know where to start. For what is the EU's list of so-called non-cooperative jurisdictions? According to the European Council's website, it is a list of non-EU countries that encourage harmful tax practices that erode eu countries' tax revenues from companies. This may sound OK on paper, but the reality is that only two percent of the lost tax haven-billions are lost in countries on the EU list.  Honestly, what the hell is that list at all? In the fall, the favourite destination of the Cayman Islands fell off the list, and already the list includes only one of the world's 20 worst tax havens.  It is a bad joke, how miserable the criteria for getting on the list are, and an even worse joke, that the EU's own tax havens are not on it. The most obvious thing is that a criterion must be to put countries on the list if they offer a tax of zero percent. You can hear that Parliament is clear, and I therefore hope that the Commission will be up to its task, so that tax-fids will pay their price.

name: José Manuel GARCÍA-MARGALLO Y MARFIL
text: – Mr President, on 31 December, the United Kingdom and Spain closed a principle of agreement on Gibraltar. I'm not going to talk about sovereignty, because if the Spanish government doesn't care about that, I don't know what it was going to matter to you. What they do care about is avoiding unfair competition. The pre-agreement wants to remove physical barriers to the mobility of people and goods. Not easy, because they are two territories with different tax systems.  In Gibraltar there is no value added tax or taxes on tobacco, alcohol and oil. Corporation tax does not tax profits obtained outside the Rock at all. Today there are 80,000 companies in Gibraltar, 25,000 of which are financial institutions. And Gibraltar has come to control 60% of the world's online game. The pre-agreement enshrines this tax regime.  Which company is to be established in the adjacent European territory, if it can access the European internal market without paying taxes? We were concerned that the UK would become a Singapore and we are shocked by Barbados. There's no point in us touching a tax haven on the front doors, removing the lock, or handing over the keys.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: – Mr President, the European list of tax havens is a great idea that is very mis-applied. Paul Tang said someone forgot to put tax havens on the list. I can't agree more. I think there are three urgent things that need to be fixed. The first is the criteria used to introduce countries. They are more political than technical and objective, and need to be corrected urgently. Second, sanctions. There are very few sanctions on listed companies. Those on the gray list practically come out of rositas, without any sanction, and that can't be. And third, transparency. The list will never be credible if we are unable to explain it to the citizens and if this Parliament does not have the capacity to control how this mechanism is done. Finally, on this whole issue the most important thing is that we have to tackle tax havens within the European Union, which this list does not solve. And the resolution we will vote on proposes a measure that would greatly help, which is a minimum European corporate tax rate. That is why I regret that there are groups that have tabled amendments to remove that part of the text, and I want to invite all my colleagues to vote tomorrow to keep that part going.

name: Claude GRUFFAT
text: Mr President, Madam Secretary of State, dear Commissioner Gentiloni, ladies and gentlemen, the current crisis has put public finance across the European Union in the red and, mirroring the growing misery here, there is the insolent health of finance and tax evasion enabled by tax havens. Shame on them! Our response to this scourge: a list of minor countries that painfully accounting for 2% of tax evasion. Where's the rest? Where are the EU states like Malta, Ireland, the Netherlands, Luxembourg, which have nothing to envy the Caymans or Panama. In fact, the United Kingdom will soon have to be added, since it is said that on the occasion of Brexit, this country would see itself as a Panama on the Thames, on our doorstep. Colleagues, it is high time to put an end to the hypocrisy and amoral complacency granted to fraudsters. Let us sweep our door and impose our standards on those who want access to the internal market. Any value created in the Union must contribute to the solidarity of the Union: this is the essence of the European economic project.

name: Paolo Gentiloni
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I think in this debate it was very clear, first of all, the awareness of the dimension of the tax avoidance. Mr Giegold mentioned EUR 360 billion. This enormous dimension also moves very fast and quickly, adapting to different situations, different countries, frequently with new methods.  It’s a challenge for us. What can we say, I think, first, we have a tool. I understand the limits, the difficulties, the criticism towards this tool; but indeed for a few years we have had this tool. I assure you from the short experience that I have here in the Commission, but also from previous experiences, that this blacklisting is in any case something effective for the countries involved. This tool should be strengthened. We have to work on criteria to avoid the risk of formal decisions being inconsistent with substantial reality in tax havens. Second, I think we have to control defensive measures taken in Member States against blacklisted countries. Because if these measures are not there, or not rightly there, I think the Commission should propose to intervene, as I said in my introduction, with a legislative proposal.  Then we have a different file from the one of the non-cooperative jurisdictions, which is the file of what happens within our club, and within our Member States. Is there a problem with aggressive tax planning, with a race to the bottom? Yes, there is a problem. We have repeated this in our semester surveillance process for years, and I want to seize this opportunity to stress the fact that we not only have the process going on with Pillar II in the OECD discussion, but we also have the recovery and resilience facility with the commitment to be consistent with country—specific recommendations, and in a few cases these country—specific recommendations give some importance to the issue of aggressive tax planning. I think we should work to make this commitment practical and solve these issues. A final point: several Members asked for the Commission to be ambitious. I think we will try to do so. But quite frankly, to do so, we need your control and your support.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I’ve heard the honourable Members of Parliament and I’ve heard the Commission. I want to thank you for this clear and open exchange of views and it’s good to see that the three institutions think that good tax governance is a priority. So, as the Commissioner said, we have a tool and the work of the Code of Conduct Group is carried on a continuous basis under the guidance of the Ecofin Council, so things can evolve.  The issues discussed in this context are both important and sensitive, and the working group will continue to generate concrete and positive changes in tax legislation both at the EU and international levels. The results of the work of the group are made public systematically in a transparent manner, and they will continue to do so. So thank you very much once again for this debate, and thank you for your attention.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The vote on the amendments will take place today, Wednesday 20 January 2021. The final vote will take place on Thursday, 21 January 2021. Ladies and gentlemen, with your agreement, I propose that we proceed with a small deviation from the day-to-day order. In order to allow the political groups to prepare the voting recommendations for the next round of voting, I would not wait until the conclusion of the next debate to announce the results, but would do so now. That's 7 p.m. We are in the right place. I see no contradiction. We therefore come to the results of the first round of voting. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Marek BELKA
text: in writing. – Isn’t it ironic that in this House we don’t get bored of taxes? However, more than 80% of EU citizens agree that tougher rules on tax avoidance and tax havens are needed. And yet around 20% of the EU’s corporate tax revenue is estimated to be lost annually due to profit shifting to tax havens. Something is still going wrong. Firstly, it is not proven that black lists hurt tax havens. Paradoxically, they might even serve as guiding maps for wrongdoers seeking secrecy, lack of transparency and low tax rates. We need sanctions now! Secondly, a very low or zero-tax rate should be a basic criterion for these jurisdictions to be blacklisted. Moreover, we need more transparency from the Code of Conduct. The list should be less political, while the methodology must be easily explainable to our citizens. Finally, we can’t preach what we don’t deliver. Our own usual suspects when it comes to tax deals in the EU have to reform – not undermine a fair internal market. When one thinks of tax havens, we imagine a luxurious club of tropical islands. In this Club Tropicana drinks might be free, but it is our citizens who pay for them. Let’s make that Club bear a fair share!

name: Enikő GYŐRI
text: Writing. – We all agree that the fight against tax fraud and tax evasion is very important and we must do our usterly to encourage third countries that are on the list of tax havens to comply with strict transparency rules. We must therefore continue to put pressure on states that refuse to cooperate on tax issues. In this way, the adoption of this report could be supported, but unfortunately the left classifies the EU Member States operating with low taxes as tax havens in the text. Tax avoidance should not be confused with tax competition, with the legal means available to Member States in terms of tax reduction. Even in the extremely difficult circumstances of the COVID-19 crisis, we must see that reducing the tax burden on companies is now the key to recovery from the crisis and competitiveness - this must, of course, be planned and implemented by the Member States on the lines of responsible budgetary management, depending on the capacity of the country to carry out the burden. In this Hungary, as we have continued to cut taxes since the outbreak of the crisis, saving hundreds of thousands of jobs. The result is visible, as employment levels are only one per cent below the level of employment at the beginning of 2021, before the crisis erupted. In the light of these extraordinary results, it is even more irresponsible, in the current circumstances, to adopt a decision whose proposals and conclusions are completely contrary to the aspects and key requirements of economic crisis management.

name: Andżelika Anna MOŻDŻANOWSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Colleagues, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Fair taxes, non-payment, transparency and accountability are inherent features of our democracy. According to the study, EU citizens lose EUR 140 billion in corporate tax losses every year. This is money that can be spent, for example, especially in the era of the health pandemic. 86% of European Union citizens want the EU to fight tax evasion. We can no longer close our eyes to extremely irresponsible actions and hypocrisy! How can the Cayman Islands, the world's number one tax haven, account for 16.5% of global tax avoidance be removed from the list of tax havens? Why are we blinding our eyes to European tax havens , which account for a third of global tax avoidance? Especially now that the COVID-19 crisis is engulfing thousands of honest tax-paying companies, thousands of jobs for our citizens, this is unacceptable! We will not help SMEs by allowing giants to avoid tax. We will not accelerate the recovery from such a serious crisis by applying vague, economic and economic-ing principles. It is our duty to prepare and implement transparent and impartial criteria for placing and removing a country from the list. Integrity, integrity and cooperation between Member States in this matter are essential!

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Council statement on the lack of transparency in the Council's appointments to the EEA (2021/2501(RSP)). I would point out to Members that there are no spontaneous speeches and no blue cards accepted in all the debates in this part-session. It also provides for interconnection from Parliament's liaison offices in the Member States.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, first I would like to express the Council’s and the Portuguese Presidency’s attachment to the European Public Prosecutor’s Office. Ensuring that the EPPO starts functioning at the earliest opportunity is a priority for us. In this perspective it’s also equally important that the EPPO, with its important mandate of prosecuting the crimes which affect the financial interests of the Union, is a solid and credible office. This is in the interests of all stakeholders, including the EU institutions and the EU citizens. We all hope that the EPPO will start functioning as currently planned in March this year.  In achieving this objective, the Council has worked in close cooperation with this Parliament, which resulted in the appointment in October 2019 of the Chief European Prosecutor. The Council has actively worked on the establishment of the EPPO with a series of legislative texts, aiming at implementing the EPPO Regulation. In 2019-2020 substantive work was done with the objective of appointing European prosecutors. In July 2020 the decision appointing European prosecutors – one for each of the 22 participating Member States in this reinforced cooperation – was adopted by the Council, and this allowed the EPPO college to start functioning in September 2020. The work which led to the appointment of the European prosecutors was carried out in full transparency and in the full respect for the applicable rules. I want to underline here that the Council implementing decision on the operating rules of the selection panel states, and I quote, ‘the selection panel shall rank the candidates according to their qualifications and experience. The ranking shall indicate the selection panel’s order of preference and shall not be binding on the Council’. The Council thoroughly analysed the selection panel’s opinion on every candidate and followed the proposed ranking on 19 nominations. In the other three it decided otherwise, making use of its discretionary power. Moreover, in addition to the legislative acts published in the Official Journal, all documents pertaining to the process have been handed to the interested parties when requested and in accordance with the Council’s rules on access to documents.  I’m aware of the fact that some of the appointments have been contested and that there has been criticism regarding the designation of prosecutors of some Member States, including my own. I speak here on behalf of the Council and I do not want to go into detail at this stage. So I will listen to you carefully and I will be ready to answer your questions.  But ladies and gentlemen, let me state that the establishment of the EPPO has required much more time than expected, with huge delays linked particularly with the pandemic. It is now time to combine our efforts to allow the EPPO to become operational and start its activities on the protection of the Union’s financial interests against criminal offences. This is something that the Parliament wants. This is something that the Council wants. And we need to work together on this.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: PPE Group. – Mr President, Portugal is, for me, much more than a Member State. Share geographical boundaries, history and culture with my country. Together we came out of the dictatorship and entered the European Union. That is why I am saddened to have to condemn the conduct of the Portuguese Government. But the facts are irrefutable.  The Portuguese Government lied to the Council about the qualification of one of the candidates for the European Public Prosecutor's Office and, as a result of this lie, a decision was taken which should not have been taken. Honestly, I don't know what's worse: whether the excuse for administrative error or the theory of the international anti-Portuguese conspiracy proposed by Prime Minister Costa. These kinds of nonsense are typical of other latitudes and do the Portuguese Presidency a skinny favor.  The European Public Prosecutor's Office is an instrument at the service of all Europeans to combat fraud and to preserve the rule of law, which has now fallen under the shadow of suspicion. Two weeks ago I went to the European Commission, together with other colleagues, to request an investigation into this. Today I ask her again here and I am addressing the Portuguese Government to take responsibility for the Portuguese and the Europeans. Lies must have consequences and corrupting the rule of law cannot go unpunished. Mr Costa, the Portuguese deserve an apology, and we deserve not to look like idiots.

name: Isabel SANTOS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, I am more than myself here and I go above the top of almost 900 years of history to answer to Mr Pons, behind whom are hidden the real warps of this campaign of disinformation, whose sole objective is to achieve the Portuguese Presidency of the Council and, drag, to reach the European Prosecutor's Office itself. But let's get to the facts. Let's get to the facts. The Portuguese candidates for European Prosecutor were selected by the High Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office, an independent body. The European Council has named the first on the serial list by this body. The Communication from the European Council is clear: it says that the candidate appointed obtained the highest ranking in the ranking of the Superior Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office... (The President withdraws his floor to the speaker)

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, colleagues, I’m a bit shocked after what I just heard. Just today, a President who for four years has been dismissing all criticism as a conspiracy against him, has left the White House – fortunately. Can we please stop following his example? Because what happened here is, objectively, very shocking. Madam President-in-Office, you said that you are fully behind EPPO and the fight against corruption. We all are. Then I ask myself: why have not just the Portuguese Government but the Belgian Government, the Bulgarian Government and the entire Council jeopardised the function of EPPO? It is completely irresponsible. There is an independent panel of experts who’ve made a selection and they’ve made a recommendation. There was absolutely no reason why the Council should deviate from that recommendation, because that’s what we have the panel for. Because if you want to choose the best person for EPPO, then all the Council had to do was follow the recommendation. What other objectives could you have in deviating from the recommendation other than, I don’t know, creating jobs for the boys? I don’t know. Unfortunately, in the Council this is not an incident, but it is a pattern. What we need is full transparency. Portugal, first of all, has to provide full and accurate information and fully clarify the matter. The Council must provide full clarity on the process and the considerations for the choice of candidates. And finally, I would like to call on the Council – and I hope you will pass on the message to your colleagues – to commit here and now to refraining from ever deviating again from the recommended ranking and avoid this situation.

name: Saskia BRICMONT
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, the European Public Prosecutor's Office has powers of investigation and prosecution and therefore institutional safeguards are needed to ensure its independence and accountability to the union's institutions. The EPPO is not even yet in place that this first requirement for the independence of prosecutors from their country, the basis of the separation of powers, is knowingly circumvented by pressure from three Member States, Belgium, Bulgaria and Portugal, which, however, is expected, as the Presidency of the European Union, to lead by example and to follow the opinion of the panel of European experts. THE EPPO must be able to carry out its mission of combating fraud and corruption without the risk of political intrusion. Colleagues, the forthcoming revision of the statutes of the European Public Prosecutor's Office gives us the opportunity to turn our indignation into political action and to strengthen these safeguards to ensure the independence of the EPPO, in particular by making binding the opinion of the European selection committee responsible for their classification. And let us remember that this question has already arisen when the head of the European Public Prosecutor's Office Laura Kovesi was appointed and that it was the weight of this house that made the difference in blocking the partisan interference of the capitals.

name: Sandra PEREIRA
text: on behalf of The Left Group. – Mr President, the High Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office Portuguese has selected a candidate other than that indicated by the Committee at European Union level, and the Portuguese Government has chosen the candidate appointed by the Portuguese. We are not opposed to the selection made by the Portuguese authorities. On the contrary, we recognise greater competence for the choice of the European Prosecutor to be appointed by Portugal.  This process is marked by discrepancies between the information contained in the curriculum of the candidate chosen by the Portuguese Government and the document that accompanied this curriculum. It is important to know in what documentation the European Council was founded to appoint the Prosecutor appointed by Portugal. It is necessary to ascertain what has happened and to prevent such a situation from happening again. Let this situation be clarified, for the sake of transparency and rigour, so far we agree, but do not count on us to address this issue, which, above all, obviously has a political agenda behind it.

name: Jeroen LENAERS
text: – Mr President, this is a sad day, because the behaviour of the Portuguese Government has cast a shadow on the start of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, and this EPPO is an historic step and we should be off to a flying start, but yet we are faced with a false start because the Portuguese Government prioritised political preferences over fighting fraud. Now this is regrettable in its own, but the way that the Portuguese Government went about sending their yes-man to Luxembourg is even worse. The Minister of Justice flat-out lied to all her colleagues in the Council. What a start of the Portuguese Presidency! First, there was nothing to declare, because confidential. Then they weren’t lies but rather mistakes by civil servants and they were purely administrative, so not so important. Then we learned that those lies came straight from the political level and they were actually the determining factor for the nomination process in Council, and still the Portuguese Government refuses to take any responsibility. For the sake of the independence and the credibility of the EPPO, we demand honesty, transparency and accountability, and unfortunately we’re not getting any of these at the moment. And as law professors from all over Europe have reminded us with an open letter, the Union cannot claim to be a defender of the rule of law if its own prosecution office is born in violation of such rule of law. So we are looking at the Commission and the Council. You were misled, you were lied to, you must set this straight.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: – Mr President, one thing is legitimate and good faith doubts about the transparency of the Council's decisions in the appointments of European prosecutors, which is another thing the false, totally false accusations about the appointment of the Portuguese. First, they said that it was a scandal for the Council not to follow, in this case, the recommendation of the European Panel. Today, it is known that this opinion is not binding and that it has not been followed in the case of other countries either.  Second, they accused the government of making a political appointment. Today, it is clarified that the Portuguese was not chosen by the Government, but by an independent body. Third, they said the Council's decision was determined by lies and errors in the candidate's résumé. Today, it is known that the curriculum in the process had no errors and that the basis of the Council's decision, explained by the German Presidency, was not based on any errors. This was a naval battle and said it was three shots in the water, because this is just an artificial case.

name: Dragoş TUDORACHE
text: – Mr President, we have all fought hard in his House for the MFF the RF and for the right level of political scrutiny and oversight on how money is allocated and spent, but we must also make sure that EU funds are not spent fraudulently or reaching illegitimate pockets – and that is where the EPPO comes in. I hope we can all agree that it is essential to have a strong, efficient, credible and, above all else, independent EPPO. I praise Ms Kövesi for the work done in the past year to set up the office as quickly and as diligently as possible. But to ensure independence from the politics here in Brussels or in the capitals, the EPPO needs a body of prosecutors appointed with utmost respect for the rules established and without any shred of doubt as to their individual independence from those appointing them. And that brings me to the heart of today’s debate. Prosecutors in the EPPO are meant to be appointed based on the results of an evaluation done by an independent panel of European-level experts. The problem is that the Council disregarded those evaluations – and not only once, and on the basis of false information. Which begs the question: why would a political body overwrite the results of an evaluation based on merit and competence? Being a prosecutor is not about being politically astute so as to justify a political judgment; it is about being competent, about holding anyone to account no matter how powerful, whether it is politically opportune or not. That is what the Council needs to understand and that is what we as Parliament need to uphold with full force. (Applause)

name: Daniel FREUND
text: – Mr President, Ms Zakarias, the European Public Prosecutor (EPPO) is supposed to be a leap forward in the fight against corruption and fraud, but Council seems to be working against the success of EPPO. You do not want to provide adequate funding for EPPO; two Member States still refuse to appoint full—time prosecutors, and three governments have now heavily interfered with the selection process. Belgium, Bulgaria and your own government have chosen to ignore the ranking by the independent experts. Belgium rather wanted the guy that used to work in the cabinet of the minister that nominated him. Your Portuguese government provided false information to the other Member States – and I thought we were going to select the best guy for the job. I honestly don’t understand why the other governments in Council tolerate this, and if Member States are not able or willing to check the dubious personnel choices of their fellow governments, then I think Council is not the suitable institution to make these choices, because we need a fully—functioning, well—staffed EPPO to start its work. (Applause)

name: José GUSMÃO
text: – Mr President, the name proposed by Portugal for the European Public Prosecutor's Office corresponds to the first name selected by the Superior Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office and this seems to us to be an appropriate procedure. The serious mess that occurred, with the provision of false information in the curriculum of this candidate, must have, and has already had, political consequences, in particular with the resignation of the director-general of the services that provided this false information and with the assumption of political responsibility on the part of the Minister of Justice, who should have verified the information and not verified it.  I confess, however, that I find it a little regrettable that the parties that have raised this debate have hidden behind other debates, from other Members, to do so and I suggest to Members of the EPP, who are concerned about the rule of law, to look at their own caucus and the Fidesz Party that integrates it, and portuguese Members who have the same concern that they stop making alliances with the extreme right in Portugal , because it is more in this field that the future of democracy is played in our country and in Europe.

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I warmly welcome the Presidency of the Council and also my fellow Members. In accordance with the nature of its task, the European Public Prosecutor's Office must be independent as an institution, and national delegated prosecutors must, in particular, be allowed to act independently of their governments. And if the situation were to take place, they might even have to be allowed to investigate against their own governments. This means, however, that the cast and the nomination must also be correspondingly independent. We have a European selection committee that has done an excellent job and has proposed good candidates. It is unbelievable that the Portuguese Government then provided false information to give priority to another candidate of their choice, and that the other two have no transparent justifications for the nominations – I think it is wrong. I urge you, dear Presidency of the Council, that this must change. The European Public Prosecutor's Office must be credible from the outset and it must be able to act independently from the outset.

name: Ana Paula Zacarias
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would first like to remind you that I am intervening here on behalf of the Council and not as a representative of the Portuguese.  I shall say, however, this: allegations of political interference in the appointment of the prosecutor of the Portuguese. I would like to stress that this appointment decision was based on the opinion of the Superior Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office, a judicial body, independent of the executive power, provided for in the Portuguese Constitution, composed of nineteen members, of whom the majority prosecutors, but also includes members appointed by the Assembly of the Republic. This Council attributed the highest rank to the prosecutor José Guerra. I would stress that the candidates were also heard in the Assembly of the Portuguese Republic in full transparency. This appointment was independent. In addition, it is important to remember what i said initially. According to the applicable rules, the classification indicating the order of preference of the Selection Committee is not binding on the Council, which enjoys full discretion in this matter. In the Portuguese, the order established by the Superior Council of the Public Prosecutor's Office was maintained, in which there was no political interference. Thirdly, some comments on the letter where Portugal expresses its preference to follow the opinion of this independent Council, sent on 29 November 2019. This letter was considered by the Council, together with the reasoned opinion of the Selection Committee on the Portuguese appointees.  Unfortunately, it contains two lapses and let me clarify what those two lapses were.  The letter refers to the prosecutor José Guerra, using the title courtesy of Deputy Attorney General, although it is, in fact, Attorney General of the Republic. This reference is a mere element of identification and in no way intended to value their qualifications or serve as a criterion of preference.  The Council assessed the experience of prosecutor José Guerra not on the basis of his professional category, but on the basis of his experience of more than three decades in the Public Prosecutor's Office, which includes 12 years in Eurojust in various roles.  The letter also states that this prosecutor was involved in the investigation and trial phases of the UGT case, although in fact he participated only in the trial phase. These elements were clarified by the Minister of Justice in a letter to the Council on 4 January 2021.  These lapses, although regrettable, did not influence the Council's assessment of the merits and professional qualifications of Portuguese candidates, a fact which is evident from the letters sent to unselected candidates. In addition, the curriculum vitae of the prosecutor José Guerra was sent to the Council at the beginning of this process, and is totally correct, not containing any of the aforementioned inaccuracies. I hope that these clarifications have dispelled any doubts about Portugal's commitment to the European Public Prosecutor's Office in a spirit of full transparency, but also with the commitment of the Presidency of the Council and the Council's commitment to this enhanced cooperation project, as important as this one to protect the Financial Interests of the Union.  This is a major theme for Portugal, the Presidency and the Council of the European Union.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed. The sitting will be suspended until the opening of the second round of voting at 8 p.m. Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. – European Prosecutors, in order to be selected and appointed, must fulfil the conditions of independence and meritocracy which are the main guarantee for the proper performance of the duties performed. The proceedings should take place beyond any doubt or suspicion, but that has not been the case. For some appointments, the Council decided without following the recommendations and rankings of the European Selection Committee. This, while permitted, has raised issues that require clarity and maximum transparency about the decisions taken. The field must be cleared of any shadow of improper political interference. We cannot allow heated debates such as those that have arisen over the appointment of the European Public Prosecutor of Portugal to tilt confidence in the European Public Prosecutor's Office. The European Parliament, the Council and the Commission must protect its crucial role from undue influence. It was set up to combat fraud, corruption and crimes affecting the EU's financial interests, a fundamental mission for the credibility of the European project itself.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: in writing. – The Portuguese Government's action to de-credibility of the European Prosecutor's institution cannot be without consequences. We are dealing with a Member State's attempt, even when it is holding the Presidency of the European Council, to seriously harm the rules and values of the rule of law. We mustn't shy away from words. The Portuguese Government lied to the European Council when it presented the professional file of the prosecutor to be part of the EPPO. Lying and lack of accountability are not acceptable behaviours in the functioning of the European institutions.  I, along with my colleagues in the EPP, call on the European Commission to investigate how the Government of Portugal has followed the procedure for appointing the prosecutor to be part of the EPPO.  This government's attempt to promote its favourite prosecutor questions the credibility of the EPPO, the institution that must defend the EU budget, i.e. every European citizen's money, from corruption.  The facts are simple and clear: when a Member State officially submits false information on the basis of which the European Council bases its decisions, there is a breach of the EU Treaty on the Functioning of the EU, on the obligation of good faith cooperation. The EPP does not accept such abuse and we call for the withdrawal of the prosecutor concerned and the initiation of an investigation by the European Commission.
